description:
Great retro coffee shop to stop by while exploring Chinatown and Little Italy! 

Italian espresso is one of my favorite caffeinated drinks and this place does not disappoint! There is no surprise that it is consistently busy here. I would recommend enjoying your cup of coffee to stay just to experience the place.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
I've been a customer at Caffe Trieste for over 30 years  It's been a place to sit, read, or have a good conversation with a stranger or a neighbor.  I love the coffee, the Italian pastries,  the "old North Beach" feel of the place and the interesting people from all over the world you often meet there.  Of late, however, What the HI-FIDELITY!?? is going on with the music there.  The baristas BLAST their choice of music to the point that one has to scream to be heard by the person sitting across the table from you. Forget trying to converse with anyone.  When asked if they could lower the volume just a little, one barista replied, "it helps us (the workers) not to have to hear your (the customers') conversations."  

Maybe it would be better for Caffe Trieste if the customers were not there; there were no tips; the workers would not have to hear to the customers; and then they can play their choice of music as loud as they want to. Has someone lost sight of what customer service is here?
author: Nickie M.

description:
It was different being here by every mean. The Espresso was definitely different by all means. It did not hit me hard, it was smooth, and strong at the same time but not bitter.

Also let's put coffee aside many famous figures came here. Francis Ford Coppola wrote (The God Father) in this cafe. It just shows how good the coffee is here.
author: Ali S.

description:
"Forgive. Forget. Life is full of misfortunes." - The Godfather 

Pssst... come here. Want to know a secret? Are you (wo)man enough to know? Italian enough? Oh well, I'll share anyways... only 'cause I like you. Yo! 

*cues the theme of The Godfather* 

Did you know the classic trilogy, The Godfather, by Francis Ford Coppola, based on Mario Puzo's best selling novel, was written at Caffe Trieste back in the day?! Young Francis made this Italian café a regular stop in the 1960's-1970's. Legend in the Cinema world soon follow his name. Caffe Trieste on Vallejo St. near Columbus, est. 1956 is where it all began! Yup, she's as legit as My Cousin Vinny!

Perhaps my favorite café in the city, definitely my spot in Little Italy. The interesting factoid about Caffe Trieste is I've been here dozens of times, but it was the "other" Caffe Trieste on Market & Church St. I'd frequented a decade ago. The one on Market St. no longer there, nor was it the original, oh well. This is the original and after half a century of poets, writers, and romantics... it still flexes it's pectorals! 

Lately, I've been wandering around Little Italy trying to find the best bites in the hood. I mean all the regulars know me, like "little Gino" who's as big as your door, or "big Tony" who's the size of your Pomeranian. Yup, that wise guy humor! I mean even Joe DiMaggio who played ball up the street would crack a smile with all the funniness in North Beach! 

So I wander... and I wander... until I remember hey that Italian café on the corner! Like my Junior Prom date I have fond memories. Feathered hair aside, I recall strong coffee, legit Italian bites, and a vibe that can't be duplicated... Caffe Trieste! I walk in to that "mafioso vibe" and I feel at home, sans the olive oil on my lips. I peruse the café and see an eclectic bunch of Italians, Sicilians, pseudo Italians (Snooki et al), poets, writers, tourists, romantics. Ahhh all the romantics, like me with a baseball lid tilted to the side, Yo! Caffe Trieste!

I have been here two times the past two days and have ordered the following:

Cappuccino - Mmm so strong, yet smooth. Has that Uncle Vito kick, sans the swim w fishes. 5-Stars!

Biscotti - Mmm another winner. Not too sweet and perfect dipped in the strong Cap. 5-Stars!

Latté - No frills Latté. Creamy rich with the signature strong Trieste coffee. 5-Stars!

Combo Pizza Slice - Good, but no cigar. True Italian thin crust, just lacking the crisp & bang. 3-Stars!

Baklava - Yo Adrian! Maybe the best Baklava I've had and it's more Ottoman Empire than Rome. So buttery rich, albeit smallish, so delizioso! 5-Stars! 

In the end, I recommend Caffe Trieste to all. I admit it's my favorite café to just relax and be me with the other eccentrics. I feel la famiglia!  Giovanni Giotta aka "Papa Gianni" opened his doors in 1956! RIP Papa! So, close your eyes and think for a sec you could be sipping from the cup Francis Ford Coppola caressed when screenwriting The Godfather. Highly unlikely, but your chances are way better here! Nei tuoi occhi c'è il cielo. - Heaven is in your eyes. Ciao!
author: Eric R.

description:
San Francisco North End - What a cool little coffee shop in the heart of San Francisco's Financial District.  My brother is a coffee aficionado.  He lives in Berkley CA home of the original Pete's Coffee which was about 2 blocks from his home.  As you may know Berkeley is also the home of UC Berkeley which has many coffee shops.  

He bought me an iced cafe latte that was so delicious & full bodied without any bitterness or acidity, just a good strong robust flavor that was so smooth and delicious.  I asked the barista what type of coffee it was.  He told me it was their secret blend (I think he was the owner).  I enjoyed it so much I bought another round for my brother & 2 business partners for $20.  A bit pricy but it was delicious, but a little too much caffeine.  

One of my business partners bought an assortment of pastries which complimented the coffee perfectly.  He got the following baked goods.
     1) Pecan rectangle (this was my favorite)
     2) Dark Chocolate Biscotti that was very good
     3) Rectangular pastry w/some fruit topping
     4) Triangular Pastry w/nice buttery crust w/fruit 

I really loved this place as it had a really cool vibe.  It was a great place to kick back and talk to my brother and friends and listen to a variety of music from jazz to blues to country....  I loved just sitting there getting a much needed caffeine fix with delicious coffee  & pastries, watching people and enjoying the company & music.  I would love to go back to this place instead of the cookie cutter coffee houses like Starbucks or Caribou....

Awesome place if your ever in Frisco & you like good coffee I would highly recommend.  Checking out CAFE TRISTE in the North End/Italian area.  Great coffee & pastries w/a cool relaxing vibe.  The only down side is 30 min metered parking
author: Phil S.

description:
Customer service seems to be non existent here. At the coffee shop, you stand in front like a dummy and nobody ever says anything. If you want to order something you literally have to get someone's attention. 

And the annex shop around the corner. While different story. It seems to never be open, and how come nobody ever answers the phone!? You call this place 3-4 times and it just keeps ringing. 

The other thing that doesn't make sense at this place is that the people at the coffee shop don't have the ability to walk through the back door and sell something from the annex store. Even though it's the same shop, they can't sell anything from
There apparently. 

This place looks cool, use to be cool, but seems to be a pretentious corner shop that is staffed by a bunch of hipster transplants. The last three times I've been it's went down hill and safe to say I'll find what I need elsewhere.
author: Jared N.

description:
Completely old school, cash-only coffee joint. Has a vintage, unpretentious vibe. Catch up with friends, read an old book, soak in the sun from the light-filled room (with your cappuccino). What I love about this place is that it doesn't have any tech Zuckerbergs working here from home ruining your relaxing morning vibe.

The coffee is great. The pastries are great. What else can I say? It's been here for over 60 years for a reason.

Fun Fact: This is where Francis Ford Coppola sat and wrote most of The Godfather story!
author: Anjelica C.

description: An oldie but goodie, Trieste attracts a diverse clientele that are in themselves often worth the price of admission. Coffee always good, pastries and other foods fine, the Web works well, and there is plenty of seating.
author: Matt B.

description: Came into here the other day for the first time but definitely not the last! Chai latte with almond milk was great and atmosphere has a very homey feel to it! One thing I would say is to maybe put a label in front of the cup with dirty spoons in it because I had a funny and quite embarrassing experience as I grabbed one thinking it was clean and stirred sugar into my chai with it! Looked up and saw a regular customer laughing at me and then they kindly explained that it was dirty! Not a complaint just bad observance on my part. Can't wait to come again the next time I'm in the city :)
author: Sophia A.

description: Ok, their coffee is SERIOUSLY TASTY, and the customers there and barista are super friendly BUT......they only accept cash even if you're order is over $10.  Their largest cup size is still smaller than what you'll see at Starbucks smallest size.  After you ask for their wi-fi password, you'll learn it's is so low (or maybe even endangered) you won't even be able to look at your email.
author: Frugal C.

description:
I've been coming here regularly for over 30 years. I used to do my schoolwork there. I'm now 50.

The amazing thing about this place is how little it has changed. They've moved some of the photos around and have added a few new ones. The TV has changed from one with a picture tube to a flat screen. The menu has been updated with higher prices. Hard to think of much else. They've never remodeled. Smart move.

This place is completely legitimate. It's not a phony tourist trap. If you're from out of town and touring the City, you *should* pay a visit as this place has tremendous historic and cultural significance.

The coffee is pretty decent too. Newer hipster coffeehouses like Four Barrel, local chains like Blue Bottle, and a number of others have better coffee. But, they are bland places to hang out at.

Long live Caffe Trieste.
author: Chuck G.

description:
Ah, what can I say - I'm a sucker for anything old that doesn't take credit cards. Caffe Trieste is exactly that, a no-thrills old style cafe with a sepia looking interior and a larger menu than you'd expect. The prices are high for what it is, but again I'd much rather support a place like this than yet another Pete's or Starbucks or whatever the hell else yuppie frou-frou crap has popped up all around San Francisco nowadays. 

I got a cappuccino and a cookie and sat outside in the nice shade on a warm-ish day. I read a book, italiano style I eavesdropped on all of the neighborhood dudes sitting out there with me and I felt really relaxed. A great non pretentious and solid evening. That's how you do it, baby!
author: Jenna I.

description:
This is my hideout spot. 
now you know.
Anyway, it's a beautiful seclusion to a wonderful and historic area in SF today. Just down the street you have city lights and the pretty patina coppola building basing the marveling transamerica.
I usually go here with the routine paper of the day, cash (cash only but atm inside) balled up in my fist and a sleepy mindset ready to be tickled by the cappuccino they slay here. 
I love the bohemian, old world, stain glass surrender of the place. It's great for an intimate morning with yourself and caffeine.
author: Hannah M.

description:
It's relatively old dating back to the 1950's. Its beginning coincides with the rise of the Beat Generation so the following Beat authors may have frequented this venerated caffè. 

1) "Jack Kerouac, Jack Kerouac was an American novelist and poet. He is considered a literary iconoclast and, alongside William S. Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg, a pioneer of the Beat Generation. Kerouac is recognized for his method of spontaneous prose." 

2) "Lawrence Monsanto Ferlinghetti (born March 24, 1919) is an American poet, painter, liberal activist, and the co-founder of City Lights Booksellers & Publishers. Author of poetry, translations, fiction, theatre, art , and film narration, he is best known for A Coney Island of the Mind (1958), a collection of poems that has been translated into nine languages.

3) "Irwin Allen Ginsberg was an American poet, and one of the leading figures of both the Beat Generation during the 1950s and the counterculture that soon followed."

"Caffè Trieste is said to be the first espresso house on the West Coast." Founded by Giovanni Giotta who missed the espresso houses of Trieste in northeast Italy." 

There seems to be entertainment, cultural events, etc., but on our visit on a late Friday afternoon, it was full of us tourists and what looked like a few regulars. 

It feels old, historic, connected to the past. However, in terms of the level of the coffee, espresso, baked goods, etc., it is a-ok. Nothing exceptional.
author: Gary I.

description:
Reminds me of Cafe Reggio on Macdougal Street in NYC -- same sort of archetypal coffee house vibe with 20th century credentials -- serving excellent red-eyes and espresso.

Needed a break during our walking tour with my son and this was the perfect spot to chill a bit -- and mingle with an interesting melange of folks -- from picture grabbing tourists -- to locals -- to the ever present SF homeless.

The walls are just plastered with memorabilia -- worth taking a moment to just sip and read and take in the City through one of its more organic meeting places.  

Nice history lesson.
author: Yuri Y.

description:
Lovely coffee tucked in the Italian neighbourhood. We stopped by for coffee after lunch.

Loved the old quaint decor of the place and how comfy it was. Too comfy, in fact as we struggled to get a table :P . Didn't try their desserts but coffee was good. Want to to come back for a longer better experience and to try out more of their stuff!
author: Heliana M.

description:
This Italian cafe is an interesting place to see a lot of different people from different cultures and backgrounds. The walls of the cafe are clad with pictures of great artists and musicians from different eras. An official instrument of the Trieste music is also kept in a corner. 
However, the main intention of the place, I would say, has not been well kept. The coffees we had, cafe au lait and cafe latte weren't all that strong. 
Come here for different cultures and music, but not for the coffee.
author: Aswin V.

description: "The Godfather". Doesn't this phrase make you want to watch the movie every time you hear it?! Does it also make you wonder the amazing screenplay? How would you like to sit in a cafe where this movie was born and Francis Ford Coppola wrote the screenplay!!! As soon as I found out, I had to stop by this Italian cafe for a coffee, scone and chocolate cake. The walls are filled with interesting photographs from the 60s and the cafe also has an antique record player serving as a jukebox. It is a gem of a place and a must visit when in the Bay Area.
author: Malavika S.

description:
What a gem of a place! SO quaint, simple, full of historic culture, and all-around, an awesome landing ground for a cup of coffee. Didn't really order anything all too frilly (not sure if that's even available on the menu!), but coming in for a quick cup of coffee, along with an americano for my cousin was just what we needed for an afternoon pick-me-up on a lovely Sunday afternoon.

The barista was friendly, and it was refreshing to be in a lovely space that has so much history embedded within it! The ambiance is lined with pictures from the past, and customers were busy on their laptops getting work done (so it seemed!). Seating was not a problem, and the windows were large enough for some fun people watching, and assisted in determining what direction to hit up next in North Beach.

I'll definitely be back if I'm in the area, and next time, I can't wait to try some of their yummy treats. They had delicious-looking cookies available, along with some salty and savory treats too. Perfect for an afternoon stop in a non-chain coffee shop. Definitely recommend! Check out the place! You'll be glad you did!
author: Crystal C.

description: The servers were rude as fuck, but given Libya's history with Italian colonialism, I have learned to always take their food, enjoy their culture, and disregard their behavior.
author: Mohand E.

description: Love this cute little caffe! I have been here a couple of times. You should try to visit this cafe on sat nights. They have live music and it is very happening. The menu is amazing as well. Love the veggie pasta options. Decently priced. You need to order what you need at the counter and find a table by yourself.
author: Abeetha B.

description:
Crowded but good vibe for a neighborhood corner cafe.
Got stuck seated inside, but still good people watching. Macaroons are phenomenal as is the biscotti. Great coffee!
author: Jim G.

description: This place is unique! I am from out of town and it was very italian! Cash only and quaint. The pastries looked authentic and amazing. I had a cappuccino and it was fantastic. I highly recommend going in to check it out and grab a sweet snack.
author: Kate O.

description: The coffee delicious and the ambience even more so. I reccomend the double espresso and a seat by the window. Don't bring your computer and forget about the existence of your phone. Just enjoy the taste of your drink and absorb the whiff of Italy coming into your nose.
author: Olga G.

description: It is said that Caffe Trieste is the first coffee house on the West Coast to serve espresso drinks. In other words this is super old school, a shrine to the traditional Italian method. It demands respect and you must come to pay it. And The art has certainly evolved in the last 100 years but this is still a fantastic place to get an espresso, keep in mind this is a very dark Italian roast -- not the sweet medium and fruity you get at most independents in the Bay Area so be prepared for it. Absolutely get a latte here, the layered presentation is beautiful and I don't know of many places that still bother to do it that way. They steam the milk beautifully here and it absorbs the oily Italian roast well. Lines can be long, but if you are a coffee fanatic don't miss it. It's pre-tech, no credit cards so bring cash.
author: Jason P.

description: Amazing espresso drinks. Sure it takes them time to prepare your drink but it is so worth the wait to get a quality cappuccino. It is always a treat to come here, sit outside and enjoy a coffee. Always. Best in SF.
author: Erik L.

description: Omg I saw a pic on the wall when they were writing The Godfather's script in this cafe!!! Awesome place and live music, a must must try!
author: Jay G.

description: My favorite cafe in San Francisco has pretty much stayed the same throughout Northbeach's changing scenery. Excellent cappuccinos, good cookies and colorful regulars. A SF must!
author: Henry M.

description:
This is, arguably, the most Italian place in San Francisco! Awesome, in every regard: coffee is the best, food quality is superb, the pastries are huge, and the atmosphere is quirky and unbeatable! Stay for a little while, and you'll be transported to a place where everything is a bit more leisurely and a lot more stylish! 

Like good food and drink, music is of  primary importance to Italians, and Cafe Triest, has a vintage jukebox that my grandfather would have loved: it plays nothing but Italian-language standards and Sinatra. Like every other self-respecting Italian food establishment, the walls are covered with black-and-white photos of family, friends, and celebrity patrons. This place is authentic, right down to the smattering of first-generation Italian patrons, local residents of North Beach (easy to spot-they're the one with the impeccable-yet-understated attire).

Cafe Trieste is a must-visit San Francisco destination.
author: Steven P.

description: Actually went here twice in one day, my boyfriend loved their lattes that much. They are very tasty in a cute coffee shop that looks like a relic of little Italy with lots of history inside. Over all a cool place to stop by and study or grab a latte.
author: Natalie G.

description: Truly enjoyed my caramel latte as did my hubby enjoy his chai latte! The fresh cranberry muffin was good, but could have been amazing if it was warmed up. The baristas were amazing!!!
author: Zandra P.

description: A North Beach Stable. Delicious treats and coffees. Whether is 8 AM or 8 PM this place is always lively. It's completely old school and if you enjoy that - like me, you're going to love it.
author: Inci A.

description: Wow, just wow. My friend bought a small can of pineapple juice and it had grub and dirt on the rim. She politely asked the barista to wash it for her and he stuck it under the faucet then slammed it on the the counter in front of her. She even tipped him beforehand. Terrible service. Such attitude.
author: Jamie Q.

description:
I love this place and try to stop for a cappuccino every time I visit Sanfran. Had a great strong cappuccino!  Located in a sunny beautiful corner in the Italian neighborhood, this place makes you feel that you are in one of those old Italian classic coffee shops. Since I just had lunch i didn't have space for an alfajor (Argentinian caramel cookie), but hope I can try it in my next visit!

Sitio altamente recomendando para los amantes del café. Ubicado en un rincón bastante placentero del barrio italiano, este lugar me hace acordar a muchos de los cafés italianos que hasta hoy existen alrededor del mundo. En esta oportunidad me tomé un cappuccino que siempre ordeno acá cuando visitó esta parte de la ciudad. La próxima vez espero poder probar uno de esos alfajores Argentinos que tenían muy buena pinta.
author: Hugo d.

description: Was so excited to come here after having had many wonderful experiences at the location in Monterey, however I was met with very rude baristas. While looking over the menu out of the way from other customers, we were impatiently rushed to decide as they glares at us. Also, having never been to this location, I did not know it was cash only as I hadn't seen the sign. Instead of politely pointing that out to me as I went to hand my card over, I was rudely informed "cash only" to which the other man stated "do you know what that is?" I will not be returning to this location and I hope those men working learn how to be polite because that is not how you should uphold yourself in front of paying customers.
author: C C.

description: Truly great hole in the wall. Not overcrowded. Lovely diverse crowd. Divine espresso and bakery. Well done!
author: Jill L.

description: Servers are rude, we order one Latte and one americano, both were too strong in flavor. Chocolate cake was dry. Place is falling apart. I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Maria Herminia V.

description:
A San Francisco Institution! 

When Papa Gianni opened up the North Beach branch of Caffe Trieste in 1956 the last thing he had in mind was establishing the next internationally famed coffeehouse! Yet almost 60 years later it is exactly that!

If you are visiting North Beach San Francisco, swing by the cafe and imagine  Francis Ford Coppola sitting there and writing most of the The Godfather story! True story :-)
author: Afshin A.

description:
Come here for the old-school and classic vibes!! I would just come here to chill or do work. You can take calls here -- it's not dead quiet thank goodness.

Pretty good coffee. Cash only! Great service and reasonable prices. There are baked goods, sweets, and pizza available as well :)
author: Jenny H.

description: Caffe Trieste is so old school and its history + the interior + location in general made my visit a great experience! Cash only and simple - no frills - which added to the authenticity, and there's plenty of space. I had a cappuccino and an almond pastry, which were both really nice. It's a wonderful space and I'd love to be back here if I'm ever around the North Beach area.
author: Pooja K.

description: I enjoyed my experience here. They definitely have the best cappuccino. It's strong and it pairs perfectly with any of their little pastries. The atmosphere is welcoming and the ambience takes you back 50 years. I love the old school vibes amongst this modern city! The only issue is the cash only.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Busy cafe even for a Friday morning. Lots of local people and the staffs chat with them vividly. Good atmosphere for mingling, maybe not for working. Love the decor as well!
author: Zijing W.

description: Lovely little cafe. If, like me, you've been walking around SF all day and feel like your legs might fall off and your phone's about to die and you're exhausted, it's the perfect place to take a break. The baristas were very sweet, the cappuccino I got was so good I almost got a second, and the vibe was friendly and calm. Highly recommend!
author: Meghan W.

description:
My sister and I love cafes and saw this on yelp. Not a bad little place. We got a seat even though it was a bit busy. It's close to a lot of other restaurants and cafes alike which we like. 
I order the hot chocolate and my sister got a capaccino. We also got a biscotti and a cannoli.
My hot chocolate was good but nothing special, I was kinda dissapointed it didn't have a big dallop of whipped cream like I saw on other customers yelp pictures, but still it still tasted good. My sister's cannoli waa good and  so was my biscotti. But to rate the taste of our orders none of them really stood out. What we really enjoyed about this place is the location, it was a nice hangout place.
author: N D.

description:
Cash only. With one or two staff people to manage the line of people. The cafe itself is filled with people from all ranges (elderly seniors to dads coming with their kids to people in their 30s reading to people in their 20s chatting).

Charming place with character and history (you can tell as the ATM is in an old phone booth) although a bit grimy. Drinks are great and service are great though. Definitely would come back to try a pastry or two.
author: Mimi T.

description: March 17th 2018 , 9am. Not sure who hired the chubby blonde with the crack face, but someone may want to advise here that this area is multicultural and her bigoted "customer service" skills go back to her nazi genetics. If you get annoyed having to serve Latinos and Native Americans, maybe you should go back to nazi Europe. Shame on caffe trieste for hiring such rubbish. Disgusting!
author: Student P.

description:
Probably normal prices for the neighborhood...but as a local I will keep looking for more for my money... I feel like the Chai Latte was really small and expensive.  Grilled ham and cheese was nothing special...barely grilled...and over-priced.  Pot of tea was cute.  

I hate to support Starbucks but I never feel ripped off when I go there... 

Maybe bakery items are the way to go here they looked great and less pricey.  The 3 stars are for the variety of seating offered and it is in a great location.

I spent like $15 bucks and I'm still wanting more food and drink.  Expensive for an afternoon alone at a coffee shop.
author: Wesley W.

description:
If coffee was a religion this place is the promise land! Throw in the juke box with Italian music, random live music with mandolin and accordion Italian classics, or live opera on some Saturdays, this is a cultural mecca. The heart and soul of San Francisco is alive and well when you walk into Trieste. 

You can feel the creative history inside, the beat poets, Jack Keroac and in the distance perhaps hear the ghost of Francis Ford Coppola's typewriter ticking away as he wrote "The Godfather" screenplay in the caffe so many years ago. The food is delicious and atmosphere timeless and powerful. Family run since the 50s the heart and soul of San Francisco's international flavor comes alive in this one of a kind experience that is Caffe Trieste.
author: Mangelo T.

description: Excellent hand crafted espresso. We had a cappuccino, biscotti and an iced espresso with honey and a little bit of foamed milk. Absolutely fantastic experience.
author: Michael P.

description:
Coffee (And) The Barbarian 

We were staying at Hotel Bohème located around the corner from this coffee shop. The day before, we went Caffè Greco across the street from our lodging, but they left me wanting. I was in search of a better cup of coffee, so we came here.

I was charmed by this coffee shop on the corner. It was nothing fancy, but you could feel the history here. It was a true coffee house by my definition.

They had a few tables outside and plenty of tables inside. We snagged a table near the door that was beside the windows. Perfect spot for taking in the views down Grant Ave., and watching miscellaneous people start their day.

We got in line and made our way to the register. It wasn't crazy busy, but there was a steady stream of customers. 

The man working behind the counter was extremely impatient!  When he got to us, my girlfriend ordered first, then it was my turn. I paused for a beat, questioning my decision internally, when he looked at the next person in line and asked if they were ready. RUDE. I hadn't even taken 5 seconds before this went down. 

Anyways ...I had an Americano, which was one of the best I've ever had. Damn fine cup of coffee.

There were some older gentleman who we're reading their papers and chatting amongst each other. It seems that the regulars received better treatment.

Cash only transactions 

Good thing the coffee was good. Despite the ill manners of the cashier, I'll be back.
author: Brian D.

description: Nice place were you can relax and sip on great espresso and a pastry.  The place is definitely a spot where you can feel part of the neighborhood.  It's small and definitely aged.  The only reasons not a 5 Star is because I think it can use a little TLC.
author: J M.

description: This is a cool place to hang out and drink coffee and discuss whatever project you're working on or just discuss philosophy. I came with my friend Naureen after dinner and we hung out for a bit. The people who work here have no problem with you getting 1 cup of coffee and just chilling here the rest of the day, it's pretty cool. There's some history here also. Copola wrote Godfather in this place and they got pics of him too on the wall. Really chill though they don't make any of the food here, only the coffee.
author: Dang N.

description:
You ever walk into a place with a lot more presence than you expect, an aura of history and culture that you could only ever hope to help contribute to? Caffe Trieste is one of those historic places, celebrating 60 years and with the photographic and bathroom evidence.

My date who lives in the neighborhood wanted to take me to the best coffee spot in North Beach - though there are closer options, this is the one to go to. As we walked up there was a border collie and his owner outside and turns out my date's sheltie and this dog are friends - this shows you what kind of locals spot this is.

After watching dogs play we walked in to that something special kind of place. While definitely on the younger side in attendance, I appreciated this more. My date pointed to the pictures on the walls with people only reading newspapers, and then we looked around and saw papers on every table and I really liked that. 

But now on to food and coffee - you head towards the middle to get in line, which allows you to pass by the pastries and other baked goods. I saw a ham and cheese pastry and this being the day after SantaCon it sounded perfect. However the raspberry tarts were incredibly hard to turn down. Also got an espresso.

The coffee was solid, but the ambiance, staff, and other customers really made this place. Would definitely come back again, and if I lived in the neighborhood would want to be known by name here, like almost everyone else was.
author: Michael C.

description: This place is always on point! After a long day of drumming...My jam is a Dopio and a hand made half-chocolate dipped biscotti! It's Cash only! But you got to enjoy this gem when in North beach. I would also recommend getting coffee/desert here after a nice dinner as it's walking distance from the a majority of the restaurants in North Beach.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Super cute little coffee shop, but expect to wait in line. We saw the "espresso" sign from a block away and made a bee line towards it. There was a long line, but it moved pretty quickly and it gave me some time to look over the menu. Yes, I can't even order a nice cup of coffee. I'm too used to the fufu drinks from Starbucks, I guess. So I looked over the menu. I decided on a latte. Boring, huh? It was the tastiest latte I've had. 

The best part was that I got to enjoy my delicious latte outside, where hey have a few small tables on the sidewalk. It was great fun people watching because there were several regulars who apparently bring their dogs quite often to this little cafe. The doggies were especially cute.

The interior has very Italian character and I believe they serve food food, not just pastries and drinks. The staff was polite, especially considering how much effort and time is put into making each espresso drink perfectly. The line was understandable, but I was impressed with how well the staff maintained composure hehe.

This cafe is a little off the beaten path, but I think it's worth stopping by if you have the opportunity.
author: Krysten I.

description: I've been going to Caffe Trieste in San Francisco since moving to the Bay Area in the 1980's. I think this coffee is so very much better than the other well known brands that you can find almost everywhere. I used to have to make the trek into SF to get their coffee but now I buy it on Amazon. My favorite roasts are the Italian Roast Espresso and Dark French Supreme. Rich, full bodied, with no bitterness. Caffe Trieste coffee may not be available on every city block, but it's worth the trek to their shop or Amazon. Great coffee; great people. Bravo Caffe Trieste!
author: Aaron L.

description: The blond barista with the piercing on her chest is the RUDEST, CATTIEST person I've ever encountered. I was second in line, stood there patiently for at LEAST 10 minutes for someone to even help us. Finally the male barista helped the kid in front of me who just wanted an iced tea and then it was my turn. Ordered an antipasto plate and went to order an iced latte. As I was giving the nice gentleman my order the blond interrupted saying all drinks would be $7.50 since there was a concert. I told her that would be fine but asked if I could get the food for here and the drink in a to go cup since I would be taking it with me. I simply said, "does that make sense?" Because I knew I was being a little complicated with my order. She treated VERY RUDELY again that it would still be $7.50 for the drink and then through in a snobby "DOES THAT MAKE SENSE?" Mocking me...I told her "yes I said that would be fine.." then the gentleman came over with the syrup for the latte to put in the togo cup and AGAIN she mocked me saying snobbily to him, "DOES THAT MAKE SENSE?!"...I was appalled. Worst customer service ever. I told them just forget it and walked away.
author: Amanda M.

description: Terrible service. Overpriced and old/rusted  silverware. The barista was very rude when I asked if he has a plate. I don't understand why this place is so overpriced and overhyped. Rude service really ruined the experience.
author: Armita N.

description: Just like Italy! Real espresso and truly delicious cappuccino with perfect pastries.  Also amazing sandwiches and pizza for lunch. Lost my wallet with cell phone and my expensive sunglasses here and staff held on to all my valuables! Wonderful people. Thank you Abby. You are the best.
author: Jess S.

description: I am a nostalgic Italian expat living in LA,  when visiting San Fran I am always so thrilled to go get a cappuccino in the morning to get a bit of a feel of home. This morning I went to Caffe Trieste, came highly recommended here on yelp. Although I have to admit the cappuccino was ok - the 20 minutes wait to get it was not worth it + I was called an 'asshole' by the stupid barista for not having cash with me and threatened with pepper spray by an older oversized usual client with a pony tail carrying a mandolin. So unless you want to deal with Cash Only, long waits,  a female barista with anger issues and  coward grumpy old folks. I'd say stay away from this dump hole.
author: Tommaso C.

description: Francis Ford Coppola was not still writing The Godfather when I got here. I don't really know why they have all the pictures of him doing that because it can really confuse the casual espresso guest. I had brought my personal copy of The Godfather to be signed by THE Francis Ford Coppola and when I walked in there was just some espresso and tables and an ATM. After swallowing my pride and putting away my limited edition copy, I resignedly ordered an espresso and paid in cash. The anguish I felt was akin to the rapid and violent expulsion of air out of a balloon. The espresso provided some much needed relief.
author: Parker K.

description:
an institution since 1956.

I can't believe this is February 2016 and I'm the first person writing a review about Caffe Trieste!!!
Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg, and Lawrence Ferlinghetti frequented this place until the 60's.
Ferlinghetti still does.
and also, Francis Ford Coppola wrote much of the screenplay for The Godfather while sitting in the Caffè Trieste.

and the story of how the regulars here worked together to help Roy Mottini (RIP) to find a place to lived is incredible.
they were so patient with him.
they helped him.
Roy Mottini was a legendary eccentric resident of North Beach diagnosed as a chronic paranoid schizophrenic. (he passed away last week).

so, even if you're not into coffee, go for the history.

(I still can't believe I'm the first person writing the review for this very important place).
author: Rudy H.

description: The coffee is delicious. The atmosphere is comfortable. There's a mix of regulars and tourists. Bagels. Pastries. Cakes. Yum.
author: Susan S.

description:
Pros: had the super yummy key lime pie and turtle cheese cake. The cheese cake definitely was a highlight. 

Cons: its cash only and there's only one person taking care of coffee and other take out orders. So it takes FOREVER. 

overall a very charming little cafe. Would definitely try the coffee next time at a slightly less busier hour
author: Ashmita V.

description:
Pretty old school coffee shop

The place looks like it's very, very old. There are a lot of motorcycles parked outside, which at first made me thought it was a motorcycle bar, but it isn't! Inside you'll find a lot of memorabilia and old black and white photos on the wall. The tables are all tiny and wooden, which adds to the retro-feel of the place

The wait staff are pretty friendly. I got a iced coffee, which was pretty smooth and also had a pretty strong coffee aroma, which was nice.

Overall, a pretty chill place for a quick cup of coffee
author: Henry L.

description:
Above average local cafe, with an old-school vibe, famous for their Africana. Cafe Trieste is nestled in North Beach/Chinatown on a small side street off Broadway. Everyone there seemed to be a return customer, and there was a surprising amount of customers hanging out there on a weekday at around 11am.

I couldn't put my finger on what the Africana reminded me of, then I recalled - it tastes like Nespresso (which ain't bad!). An Africana is basically a short latte - it's incredibly powerful and rich. 

I like that they have a generous amount of indoor (and some outdoor seating). The Africana was strong but not too unique IMO - I may be back to try some of their other drinks.
author: Jess C.

description: The best no frills place! No need to say more. Coffee, cappuccino, etc. All great. Good cake too. Live music occasionally. Legit Italian. Cash only.
author: Saul L.

description:
Came here with a friend for some post-dinner coffee. Ordered a cappuccino (yes even though real Italians never drink cappuccinos in the evening) and my friend ordered a latte. Not that I really know anything about coffee, but the cappuccino was perfect and reminded me of my time in Florence. There was also a tempting selection of pastries, which I must try when I return. 

But the true reason for 5 stars is that they seemed very open to having people sit, relax, and slowly enjoy the drinks while chatting/working. Glad they didn't rush people out :)
author: Hali M.

description:
Perfect little spot for an espresso or a cold beer right in the heart of San Francisco's North Beach Italian neighborhood.

Come on weekend mornings or evenings and you might catch some mandolin players strumming away. It's a little taste of the old country, even though you're half a world away.
author: Evan Thoreau H.

description:
Authenticity to the Bone. This family-owned business exudes charm, and to my opinion, a bohemian vibe that is unequaled in the North beach area.

A block off the main drag of Columbus Boulevard, It's more than worth it turning the corner to find this hidden gem.

I had the Earl Grey tea and a Boston cream pie. Both were precisely what was needed for a casual afternoon time.

There are both locals and foreign tourists alike blending and sharing a moment of time together.

Despite ordering the Earl Grey tea Cafe Trieste (meaning sadness in French) offers a wide array of coffees and pastries
author: Zoey W.

description:
Came by for an Iced Latte the other day and it was a decent experience. There are numerous tables inside and outside the coffee shop. Seems like they own the store next door to sell coffee related merchandise.

The coffee shop itself is rather decrepit and they only accept cash but do have an ATM inside a phone booth inside the coffee shop?!?

The line was a good 5-10 people long and the line took ~5-10 minutes to get through.

Staff was very friendly and accommodating. 

The iced latte was pretty smooth and even had a nice layer of foam/froth to make the beverage more enjoyable!

$4.3 for an Iced Latte after tax.
author: Derek S.

description: Super cute spot to sit and have a cup of coffee. Also, the music selection in the Jukebox is excellent, I would go again just for that!
author: Daisy T.

description: Classic North Beach haunt. If you want local atmosphere. This is it! Coffee and pastries are good but be prepared to pay tourist prices. Was there last week, it was $20.00 for three cafe lattes and a biscotti cookie. Service ok. Oh and it is a cash only place. No ATM or credit cards accepted.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
The oldest espresso served in in SF, not to mention the best coffee. Dont think so? Just ask any of the regulars, also some of the oldest living SF residents. It might be the only place in SF where you can actually witness people reading the daily newspaper.
A must stop for anyone looking for the real deal SF experience.
PS try a desert.
author: Drew F.

description: Off the main strip authentic Italian coffee shop with the locals sitting outside. Great coffee, great atmosphere, great people.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Exploring SF and stumbled upon this place. It's a cute small cafe that offers fresh coffee and pastries. I ordered the Nutella filled donut, plain bagel+jam and a cappuccino. 

**CASH ONLY!! but they have an atm inside. 

For what you get/pay for it is a bit costly. But taste delicious. Not too sure if I'd visit again, probably explore other options.
author: Gina K.

description: This is what a coffee shop - cafe* - should be like. What they used to be like before free wifi and freelancers took over. It was so fun people watching. I loved how they served my latte in a tall, glass vase-like glass. Cash only.
author: Slater K.

description:
I love coming to this neighborhood gem for a spot of tea or sip of espresso. Such a cool place where you will find artists, poets, locals, tourists rubbing elbows.  Politicians use this place as their "office" for casual meetings. Trieste is where Strangers become Friends! There is no pretense here. Real people... Good people...

Espressos reminds me of those I sip in Europe.... Great coffee beans that puts out the most delicious aromas! My favorites are the Caffe Au Lait, Mocha, and lattes!
author: Sharon S.

description: Yelp has wrong hours - they close at 11 pm. We made it in the nick of time and the barista was very sweet and made our drinks  -Cafe Mocha Bianco and a raspberry shortbread to go. The best I have ever had. It's like coffee straight from Italy. I will have to come back and eat\drink here bc it's so cute and antique.
author: Isabel S.

description: Nice atmosphere, very touristy but without overtly showing the I love SF just acquired shirt, tons of pics on the walls that depict Italian history in SF and personal stories and great coffee. However, I find the service was lacking and I had to ask for a real plate for my Apple tarte, not just a paper one, as I was getting also my cappuccino in a real ceramic mug...there are that kind of small details that make a difference. Also, I found the tables dirty and then bathroom not very clean either. I guess they have too much traffic and not enough staff. Still a lovely place to stop for a coffee.
author: Carmen V.

description: Great coffee and quaint ambiance.   Some of the baristas are crabby but the drinks are worth it.
author: David W.

description:
Perfect cappuccino?  Done.  Prefer a latte?  Done.  I'm actually partial to their mochas.  They only offer regular milk, which makes my mocha so very decadent.    

Artists of all kinds have been gathering here forever.

It's true that Frances Ford Coppola was once a regular here.  And that he wrote parts of The Godfather screenplay here.  

I've walked in right behind Nicolas Cage before.

Live opera on Saturdays.  LIVE OPERA.

Old Italian men sipping espresso & chewing the fat.  In Italian.

Writers writing.  Artists sketching.  Poets being poets.  The baristas whipping out espressos & espresso drinks the artisan way.  

Pastries, focaccia, pizza for noshing.  

Trieste defines old school.  So Italian.

Small & unassuming.  What they may lack in aesthetics, they make up for in their rich history & culture.  In spades.  

You can go right next door to buy their coffee beans to take home.  The Italian espresso roast kicks a**; especially French pressed.  

They have other locations.  But come here first.  

History & culture.  With damn good coffee.  

A must experience.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Love this place for its history. The music and poetry it brings, friendships and bohemian gatherings whose chatter and music still linger echoing on its walls. I like having a cappuccino here. On a nice warm day like tonight an accordion player and classical guitarist serenaded the folks outside. Young and old out having cigarettes, cake, cheap wine, espresso. Overall great company and atmosphere thats really what I need from a cafe. A true-blue San Francisco jewel (Coppola wrote some of his screenplays here).
author: Shu K.

description:
Walking back from Pier 39, tired and looking for a caffeine high. We found Caffe Trieste. We've heard that they have some of the best latte and cappuccino in the city. 

So it's like 4:30 in the afternoon and there's a line of about six or seven deep. Wow. This late and a huge line. Seemed like tourist, locals, and SF police were there. Even though there was a long line, it moved fairly quickly. Barista was very fast and was pounding out those drinks really quickly. Lots of table to veg out at. Nice little deco. 

Anyways, I ordered the Latte and boy did I get a latte. Drank it and BOOM. It's like a triple shot Latte. Really strong. Serious caffeine high but seriously good. Very good and woke me up. 

Only bad thing about this place is the bathroom. Small little room. Almost reminded me of an outhouse. So if you have to use the restroom, I recommend you finding another place before or after you visit this place. 

So if you're looking for a great caffeine high then this is your place. BOOM BOOM good.
author: Doug T.

description:
Caffe Trieste in North Beach is a great coffee shop located on the corner of Vallejo and Columbus Ave. They also serve some amazing pastries and sandwiches. It's just a great place to grab a cup of coffee, sit down, read or surf the internet while watching San Francisco tourists and locals walk by. 

I would definitely recommend this coffee shop! This place is the real deal. Devoted coffee drinkers will surely appreciate it! Caffe Trieste is one of my favorite spots whenever I'm in San Francisco.
author: Steve N.

description: What a great atmosphere!! Seeping in the atmosphere where Ginsberg and Ferlinghetti drank espresso! Delicious coffees and biscotti.   Will definitely be back!  Sharon thank you for bringing me here!
author: Vyvyan B.

description:
Cons: cash only, line can be long, buffet style serve your own Pastry on a plate is a little unsanitary for my anal self. Can be loud inside. 

PROS FAR OUTWEIGH THE CONS. And it warrants 5 stars. This place is great. 

Occasionally Live music from patrons 

Awesome latte (AWESOME) and espresso. 

Pastries are really super yummy even if others may have looked at them too closely for my comfort.

The barista is a f*cking master bad ass pro and that is really what makes a good coffee drink. 

Also, a great part of town. I live here and can say that nothing about the tourist appeal of this little spot could keep me away. 

Also, outdoor seating! Come on! 

I love this spot.
author: Claire H.

description:
Cafe Triste is a staple in San Francisco coffee shop experiences. Located off Columbus St. in little Italy Triste brings back a forgotten feeling, familiarity and comfortability that has been lost in Suburban and chain stores. 

Triste has a beautiful store divided into two sections to buy a cup of freshly roasted coffee and to sit and relax with a cup on the other. It has a customer base of friendly and conversational clientele and every time I visit, I find myself pulled into conversations or friendly comments from another in the shop. 

I highly recommend their own personal blends and the Italian roast to go along with a nice relaxing day in the shop. As a shop, this place could stand alone, but as a store it allows you to bring the quality and experience along with you. I love this place and the product from it. This is a mandatory stop every time I make it to San Francisco.
author: Eric B.

description: Tried this place on vacation and was not impressed. The service definitely could improve, we asked an older caucasian man behind the counter for a latte and pastry. Not the slightest smile. Serious look and told us to grab the pastry ourselves (which was self serve) but it was his demeanor that was a turn off and lack of customer service. He also served us a hot latte on a handle-less single glass too hot to hold and therefore drink unless we sipped from the table. The pastry was just okay, nothing to write home about. Wouldn't recommend it.
author: Erika A.

description: Ran in for a quick double shot to go. This place is cash only and the coffee is perfection. Reminds me of Italy.
author: Kobi A.

description: Cafe Treista: walking from the Coit Tower, we saw this Cafe, busy, so we needed a little pick-me-up. Not impressed as other Yelpers rave about this place. The Barista that day couldn't of been more impersonal. We ordered a double espresso and single espresso, both couldn't have been any smaller. We also ordered the linzer cookie, which was very OK. Maybe as one Yelper said "she felt the staff was only nice to the locals and regulars that go there". I couldn't agree more!
author: Melody K.

description:
I just popped in here for a takeaway yesterday & it was great!! The guys were super friendly & from what I could tell the place has a lovely vibe. 
Good solid tasty coffee & standard prices!
author: Victoria C.

description:
Every Sunday, Cafe Trieste brings in local artists to play energetic tunes. I'd suggest to add the accompaniment cappuccino. Like the music, it brings tiny bursts of micro-effervescent joy.
The two Italian baristas man the entire line with efficient ease. It is a smaller space and perfect for the authentic Italian cafe experience. Strong espresso packed into a tiny cup of steamed milk made for a quick caffeine fix. Great coffee and small space = high demand. The implicit expectation is for you to enjoy your drink and head out with their consistent volume.
author: Mitchell R.

description:
Little coffee shop with great ambience. CASH only!
The coffee smells are heady and aromatic. We really enjoyed thd ice latte and black coffee was really good. Its cozy but no so small that you cant find seating. The clientele feels very San Fran (bearing in mind this is coming from a San Fran newbie learning the land), with an eclectic and artsy group of regular patrons. Great place to hangout for a while on a leisurely afternoon (catching up on yelp reviews!).  The pastries look decadent and they also serve wine and beer too. Saturday afternoon they have concerts too, which would be fun to come listen I would think.
author: Alice C.

description: Just a cafe that's been around northbeach for a long time. Reliable coffee and single person pots of tea. Just off Columbus to avoid hoards of tourists but close enough to drinking and golden boys. Mostly, I'm here to wait for a restaurant to call me when my table is ready. The staff is nice and great to chit chat with. I always appreciate a cafe with a communal table.
author: Elaine L.

description:
This was the perfect coffee house I was looking for in San Francisco. The Caffe Fantasia (latte with almond syrup) was so good, and I even had the option to spike it.  

The barista knew her stuff and was a delight. The only negative was that there was no one to clear the tables off.

Oh and for you plastic patrons, it's cash only here!
author: Bahman M.

description: This is one of the best coffee shop in town. Some of the employees make great Africano which is my favorite. However Blonde lady in morning shifts has attitude to tourists and immigrants, she just suddenly becomes rude. I witnessed her mood change many times, i paid attention to her actions to make sure to write this review... They should do something about this issue, otherwise they will keep losing customers.
author: Yusuf S.

description:
It's a nice looking place with lots of space to sit with a laptop all day, but the coffee is what I would imagine a warm cup of piss would taste like. 

I had to toss it immediately. It was shocking to find something worse than Starbucks.
author: Eric E.

description: Great atmosphere. Friendly older barista who appears to love what he does.  Quality latte.
author: Priscilla A.

description:
Well what to say. SF institution or not, this place could be a lot better.

Live music sometimes is cool and coffee is good.

The Asian man behind the counter is totally rude and unprofessional.

The wifi always slow and YES... IT'S EXPENSIVE.
author: Federico B.

description:
Café Trieste is a nice place in a vivid location. I wanted to get the grilled cheese sandwich, but they wouldn't serve it until 1pm. Instead we got the ham and cheese croissant with a cappuccino, which was good. The prices are reasonable (for San Francisco).
However, the fact that we got the croissant on a paper plate with cutlery that was still wet gives it a cheap feeling and I don't feel like the café lives up to it's hype.
author: Ben C.

description:
Love this place. Charm, great coffee, delicious pastry choices. 
Been there twice, love the atmosphere and location. 
Look forward to visiting often.
author: Lenny H.

description: I got what I believe was called a Cafe Fantastico. I think it was espresso, mocha, almond flavor and fresh whipped cream and it was the best coffee drink my fiancé and I have ever had. We still talk about it to this day (even as recent yesterday). There was live music and it was just a really good atmosphere to sip a really really good cup of coffee. I can wait til I go back to SF.
author: Cuc L.

description: I bought a bag of espresso beans from here for my Expobar at home. They were some of the best I've ever had. The didn't have such a strong acidic bite but they still had that perfect full bodied flavor.
author: Annie H.

description: This place is a landmark and the best cup of how in the city. Great desserts and affordable too. We just wanted to hang out because of its history. It's a block off the beaten path but it's worth it!
author: Linda V.

description:
Based on my one quick visit on a Saturday morning, I'm into it!
Stopped in early for a double espresso. Love the laid-back vibe, the corner location, the early opening (opens up before most other places on the weekend), and def loved the espresso at a chill price too. I'll be back to hang out when I have more time!
author: MaryKate M.

description: I would skip this place. pretty pricey...i paid 6 bucks for a small coffee and a bagel with cream cheese. had to be the smallest cup of  sub par coffee I have ever had. waited like 10 mins for my stuff and I had to put the cream cheese on myself so I'm curious why it took so long. try somewhere else
author: Zack K.

description:
When I first visited SF as a tourist,  Caffe Trieste was one of the most memorable moments.
The best coffee in the neighborhood- for sure.
So much character. So much history. A true gem. 


But now I live here, and I have a different perspective:

Customer service - non existent. Prices are ridiculously high and they charge me up a different amount every time I come in. Now when I crave a great cup of coffee, I just go to one of the places on Columbus
author: Julie W.

description:
Everyone knows Italians do coffee right and this cafe is a superb example. 

The Internet had already gushed about the cafe so naturally we went in expecting an arrogant staff and overhyped coffee. 

WRONG.

The cafe is legendary. 
The coffee is legendary.

The staff blesses us with the gift of ZERO small talk, focusing more on perfecting our order. There is surprisingly nothing pretentious about this place. You can immediately spot the regulars, quietly reading their newspapers and savoring their mugs. There is also an old-school jukebox that stands in one corner adding to the cozy feel. 

Loved this cafe. We're inspired now to take a trip to Italy again just to coffee hop.
author: Neesh Q.

description:
Always a great cup of coffee here. I switch between the cappuccino and the Africano.

The same faces have been here since I moved to San Francisco in 2004. I've been in Los Angeles for the last 7 years, and during my visit today, I saw all of the same characters!

The door and floor are aged beautifully and have seen so much history.

Definitely one of our favorites. I miss living locally.
author: Jess R.

description: I stopped here with friends for some coffee and dessert after dinner. I had a simple coffee and my boyfriend had tried the Tiramisu. he was unimpressed. My girlfriends ordered a canoli, which was yummy , but wasn't about to eat the whole thing!!  it was a nice little stop before my friend had to go. Hadn't seen her in 20 years, so i savored every moment I had with her.  When I lived in SF before years ago, I believe I had gone here for pastries as well. It had been so long I couldn't remember..but this place seemed familiar to me.
author: Selena N.

description: Cute little place. Cash only, and alright if you don't mind waiting in line for 10 minutes to order an iced coffee.
author: Andrea M.

description:
Damn good iced mocha! Coffee tasting how it should. 
Pretty neighborhood location and friendly service even though the lady making coffee and working the register was the same person, she got through the line quickly and made excellent coffee! 
Best coffee I have tasted so far!
author: Emma A.

description:
This is a special cafe. Each time I return to SF, having left 12+ years ago after living there for 4 years, I make a pilgrimage to select locations (Castro Theatre, Taqueria Cancun, City Lights, etc) and this cafe is on the short list. I spent many hours here savouring the greatest cappuccino ever - reading, writing, people watching, chatting/debating, listening to musicians, etc and each time I return I am ecstatic to find I am able to reconnect with the same energy.

The decor is simple and unchanged, except the telephone both now contains an ATM and there are two TV's discreetly tucked in the corners with volumes off. The patrons are still a mix of local regulars and tourists. There is music every Saturday from 1-5 (min drink charge of $8.50), which the cafe owners used to participate in, not certain of they still do but regardless it was always special.

So, if you want a sensational coffee in a mellow yet vibrant local cafe with true character and characters then you must make this cafe part of your pilgrimage while in SF.
author: Michael F.

description:
Caffe Trieste is a North Beach staple. It's been a part of the neighborhood for over 50 years. Expect it to be busy during the day. Although it's now mentioned in many travel guides, it still feels local.

My order is very simple, and I rarely stray from it. They make a really good cappuccino that's rich and extremely agreeable. This is what I recommend! Their espresso is nice too.

If the weather is nice, grab a table outside and enjoy this beautiful neighborhood. If it's damp, the seating area inside is pleasant. Talk to some of the people you see. Most are very friendly and have a plethora of stories to share.

It's also worth noting that Caffe Trieste has a good music scene on some nights. Check first before you go!
author: John F.

description: Rumored to be the first place to serve espresso on the West Coast--great treats and drinks, but cash only!!!
author: Nicole J.

description:
Came here the first time several years ago and I don't think it has changed much which is a good thing.

I am not sure how late it was when we rolled in here but they were open and happy to help us recharge for further shenanigans around SF...in all honesty this was our one legit stop in an evening of drink, gambling, cigars, fine dining and loose women.  Pretty much felt like a member of the rat pack there for 6-7 hours.
author: Jim W.

description: Ended up here after a long day of traveling on the recommendation of our cab driver. Love the old school vibe and the history. The coffee was bangin' and the pastries were delicious.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Dear Caffe Trieste,

You're a wonderful coffee shop, service a great cappuccino without pretense and offer a fantastic authentic SF atmosphere to enjoy it in. But it's 2016 and we're in the heart of Silicon Valley, with many low-cost cash alternative options [1], yet you're still cash-only. Please step up to the 21st century - you won't lose any of your charm, promise.

[1] http://www.inc.com/erik-sherman/square-hikes-fees-so-where-else-can-you-go.html
author: Alex L.

description:
Warning: cash only

The oldest espresso house on the west coast?? That is exciting. And the atmosphere is spectacular. 

I really liked that the barista knew a lot of the customers' names. 

Of course my cappuccino was delicious, and the croissant was to die for. I will definitely be back!
author: Kendra B.

description:
Triest is a favorite neighborhood cafe best enjoyed when you have time to spare and opportunity to relax in a friendly atmosphere with a delicious coffee of your choice. 

I like it early evening or early morning on my run curcuit up and around Coit Tower.

The Grande Cappuccino is my favorite.
author: Kevin T.

description:
What drew me inside was the loud jazz from a great quality speakers which I later saw its a music box machine. The old kind. So cool. Came in for the music and stayed for the coffee. 

The one (kinda big) downside is the cash only. I didn't have any cash on me, and because the guy had ready made my coffee I had to use their ridiculously expensive cash machine, in house. 

Coffee was good, strong, a bit burned but still better than I had here.
author: Eyal M.

description:
Great service and the cutest little women's restroom ever.  I ordered an americano with soy milk afloat, it was pretty darn delicious and I would definitely visit again if I was in the area.  The service was pretty fast, even though they only take one person at a time but it was a Saterday so the minimal amount of attendants is understandable.
Overall I enjoyed it and the venue is adorable, very vintage Italian with pictures of family on the walls and an interesting decor.
author: Sara N.

description:
Like so much of San Francisco, this place has character and a past. The coffee isn't bad either! 

I am sitting here on a late Tuesday morning for the second day in a row on a vacation from LA. At least a few of the old timers are back from yesterday and I assume spend several hours here a week. A man plays a familiar Italian song on his accordion that I can't quite place, and for a short time another sits next to him and, apparently uninvited, starts to hum loudly. 

I guess I am a long timer too. I first started coming here 20 years ago but have never been a regular. I heard that the original owner passed away and had worried it would close. 

It's good to be able to come back. The thick cappuccino foam that it seems you can't get in So Cal was deeper when the old man was alive, and it was better when I came yesterday. Alas.

In short, this place is worth a visit if you have the time and have never been, but it is not among the best cappuccinos in the city anymore. Sadly.

On to new adventures...
author: Ann G.

description:
This place seriously knows how to make good coffee. Their espresso drinks are the best I've ever had, EVER!!!

Also their rugelach (a pastry with chocolate) was a little piece of heaven.
author: Carla D.

description:
Cappuccino and latte were perfect! Nice walk from Coit tower but worth it!

Pizza slice was nice too! It went great with the bottle of Peroni :-)

Live music Sunday afternoon from 1-5pm is a big attraction here.
author: Mary C.

description:
Cafe serves up Great coffee and the staff is friendly, Unlike the retail store next door. We enjoyed the coffee so much we thought we would buy a pound to go. The man working this small empty shop seemed as he had just ate a bunch of sour lemons. He was curt and border line rude. No coffee is worth that attitude. 
 If you are in North Beach you cant go wrong with getting a cup of coffee at the cafe. Avoid the retail store at all cost.
author: Manny G.

description:
Consistently one of the coolest coffee shops in the world.  Cool atmosphere and "local" feel.  Most of the people there are regulars.  My friends and I (party of 8) all ordered different drinks and everyone was happy with the quality of their drinks.  
Always a favorite place to return to, when in San Fran.
author: Charlcye B.

description:
Bohemia atmosphere. 
Pretty good coffee. 
A little dirty, but still a place to be - above all, if you are a nostalgic person.

I would like a more friendly and smiling staff because, sometimes, a "Good morning!" can make your day.
author: Sara C.

description: Hands down my favorite cafe in the city and known as the oldest coffee house!! Their Africano is the house choice and won't steer you wrong. Follow with some nosh and you're set. Additionally, every few months they'll bring in their musical friends and family to put on a live show. Be sure to check this out as it's the last of its kind and may not be around forever.
author: Amy V.

description: If in Rome, do as the Romans do. So, if in North Beach, stop by Caffe Trieste. San Francisco is full of cafes and coffee roasters. I have some I like, and some that I despise. If I'm in North Beach, Caffe Trieste is my go-to cafe. A landmark itself, Caffe Trieste is what a coffee shop should be, a community place.
author: Zachary D.

description:
Coffee is as good as ever, I took it to go.  Highly recommend.

Honestly the place needs cleaned and redecorated, it would bring back most of the brilliance to the café.  Hot food also needs an upgrade.
author: Des D.

description:
This place is unapologetic about what it is and gives you great espresso.

I came here because we were in line for Mama's and needed something hot to drink in the rain.  Yelped if up and found Caffe Trieste.  Lo and behold this it the Caffe Trieste and it is basically where espresso was introduced to much of America.... wow.  And LUCKY!!!!

Anyways, I got an espresso shot which was straight good and strong.  Also got earl grey tea which was also good.

The atmosphere was laid back, artsy, beat generation feeling.
author: Duy N.

description: Overpriced and gross. I got the caffe mocha for a little over $5 which was really small but whatever I wanted coffee. I expected some type of chocolate flavor but didn't get any. I am very disappointed. There's many cafe shops in SF don't go to this one.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Let me start off with...I am a fan of Cafe Trieste...but perhaps only the other locations.   The guys that helped us last night were pretty much dumber than a door nail.   We asked if there was half and half for the coffee and the response we got was as if we asked what the stellar constellation was for the night.  

"Can I get half and half for the coffee?"
"we don't have half and half."
"cream?"
"we have milk"
"no cream?  really?"
"no just milk"
"not even creamer?"
"no, just milk"

how stupid is that?  Especially stupid because I usually get a double shot with whip cream...whipped CREAM...as in YES THEY HAVE CREAM.  

Then, right after we purchased some pastries, the older guy came out and put some pastries on the newspaper stand outside for anyone to take...right in front of us!
author: Matt V.

description: Unfortunately Caffe Trieste has gone downhill...it used to have character and history and now it just looks cluttered and dingy and on top of it the espresso is terrible. They are probably living off a few hard core regulars and tourists who find mention of it in their guides.
author: Renee T.

description:
The Emperor has no clothes.

Got an iced decaf latte around 1pm today. I literally cannot finish it. It is undrinkable. Burnt, offensive flavor. Painful to have on my palate. $5.08 that I'm never getting back. (Also, the latte is $4.15...how on earth do you get $5.08?)

Maybe the barista was still in grief from Giovanni's passing, but whether the old man could make a good latte, mine was the worst I've had in North Beach, and competitive only with Church Street Café for Worst Latte in San Francisco. Zero stars.

I'm in shock. How is this possible?
author: Bosie M.

description:
Well after so many many many years
Still doing well what can i tell u you get abused but we like it done with style funy funy coffee is good for sure you can not be in same location
Same coffee
If u r not hood
author: Angel M.

description: best place in town if you are into REAL Italian coffee and espresso (and not the lifestyle crap served at any second corner). this place is been here for ages and it's nice to see that coming back almost 20 years after my first visit that the place still has the looks and charm. the old 'mama' is long gone but the espresso is still a delight and tastes after actual coffee and not some genetically enhanced flavour potpourri. go there!
author: Zul A.

description: Quintessential old school north beach. Great espresso drinks. Good place to sit inside or out and catch up with a friend or bring out of town visitors. Cash only.
author: Mike T.

description: I'd or really that hard to find a working wifi? Don't advertise that you have it if it doesn't work. On to find a place to finish work.
author: Polina V.

description: Delish coffee just off the main tourist routes.  Yummy pastry.  Nice local scene differing from the green mermaids
author: Steve S.

description: Stood in line for 15 minutes and upon reaching the register, found out they didn't offer soy or almond milk. Complete waste of time, had to get a mocha elsewhere.
author: Kyle B.

description: It is ok. The cannoli was not fresh and the hot chocolate wasn't hot. Be aware, they only take cash. The building is cute, and everyone was nice
author: Madeleine S.

description: The authenticity of this place still makes it hard for me not to like. Cappuccino still good. We ve been spoiled by places like blue bottle, verve, philz so this is more a place to soak in the neighborhood feel
author: Lisa C.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday evening and it was so lively here! This caffe in the north beach neighborhood really makes you appreciate the concept of community. There was an array of characters here, whom were all very outgoing and friendly ( including the staff). I've been here once before but today's experience made me realize how much of a gem this place really is. 

They offer caffe food-sandwiches, salads, drinks. They also have a variety of delicious desserts including cakes and pies! And of course beer and a bit of a variety of alcoholic drinks. 

This is a great dive into the North Beach neighborhood culture for those who are interested and want a reminder of the beauty of humanity.
author: Antonina B.

description:
Fantastic place, great vibe, and terrific latte!!

Staff is friendly and I will be back!!
author: Patrick O.

description: Dear Fabio...I have been frequenting your establishment and known your family for nearly 40 years, I have seen your brother pass, your father, as well as the departure of Yolanda back to Italy. I have lived in North Beach on an off since the late 70s. I have spent a veritable fortune in your establishment. I was sadly enraged by some comments on your FB page. I wrote a critique of the changes that have occurred since the former days when the Trieste was managed by family members that welcomed artists such as myself. As the third and last official bassist for Sly & the Family Stone I also weathered the tantrums of the special people that frequent the establishment. Over the last years the service and hospitality, compared to the past has literally gone down the toilette. Ida has interfered with my private life outside of the establishment and interfered with my former marriage and through salacious comments she made in Lodge 120 leaving my ex-wife felt too embarrassed and humiliated to set foot ever again in your judgmental hall of shame, where gossip precludes good service and a genuine welcome. Your service employees look down on the majority of customers. They are the rudest Baristas I have ever come across. Paul take delight in his nasty quips in full earshot. I haven't frequented your establishment for about a year. I now live in Sacramento and work close to the Governor. Whatever was good about the Trieste is no more. I don't miss it all, however I passed by last week to say hello to some old friends and acquaintances, especially to pay my respects for James who just passed. I was rudely confronted and told I was not welcome in your establishment, most likely because of my critique of how what was an extended home has become a salacious harbinger of some of the lowest form of Beach society. I am appalled and disgusted. I am sure you know me as you rammed my ex-wife's brand new white Mercedes in the rear on Potrero Ave because you were distracted on your cell phone. Never once did she get an apology. Personally I could care less about your over ratted coffee and tepid ambiance. I was a friend of your late brother and your father was always a gentleman. My mother and Yolanda were good friends many moons ago. As a business you need to be aware of criticism and a Cafe should not trample on my personal life. As a musician you have never really stepped out of your own domain. It used to be fun to come in and see the neighborhood, maybe from deaths, the cost of living and the aging out of  many former customers, the Cafe changed and change sometimes is not welcome, but that is life....I hope you reconsider the rudeness and the slap in the face as you personally didn't have the guts to come and speak with me face to face? Obviously you are not like your father and as for Ida, she needs to understand there is such a thing as Defamation.
author: Alexander D.

description: This is the hipster spot to get an authentic Italian coffee. Great sidewalk seating. Quality coffee served at an Italian pace. I happened to visit while an acoustic group was playing.
author: Erik L.

description: I was in San Francisco for vacation with friends and we came across this caffè. The customer service is splendid and the coffee..my God!!! The coffee was so delicious and the pastries were just the perfect breakfast convo. If you're in San Francisco, you must go definitely worth the trip!!
author: Ana G.

description:
This is neighbourhood cafe with a whole lot of history.  It's been around for years and tons of celebrities have visited evidenced by the pictures on the walls.  There's even a jukebox for the real retro feel. 

There was a decent food selection.  You could get a decent lunch by the looks of it or something sweet if you were craving it.   I only had an espresso which was too harsh for my liking.   I would be willing to visit again though to give the food a try.
author: Julia D.

description:
Caffe Trieste opens 6 a.m. every morning, even sundays, dispensing expressos, lattes, cake slices, bagels, muffins, pastries, crossaints, etc. (all outsourced). vino is also in da house,.

seating doesn't hold more than a couple dozen people, in and out. prices steep.

pour: (m,2.45)
-dark roast, bold husky body, very italiano!

drips:
-pricey but this is north beach
-no competition in the early a.m.
-line moves slowly
-one person takes orders/cashiers, other person makes the latte/coffee.
2ish star for value, 4 stars for being north beach.
author: Victor G.

description: Awesome spot!  Favorite coffee and atmosphere. Band on the weekends is amazing and coffee awesome.
author: Charles G.

description:
This is the original Cafe Trieste location where FF Coppolla wrote the script for The Godfather --allegedly--.

I have been here previously a while ago but the things have changed since. The place still has a classic  Italian cafe' feel to it, even though not so prominent any longer. There is all sorts of interesting photos and newspaper articles on the wall for customers to explore. The baristas are a bit too into themselves: surprising considering that they're evidently not Italian. 

Besides coffee drinks, they serve also food and beer and wine, just like you would find in Italy. It's an interesting combination for a coffee shop. As far as coffees it's mostly standard Americanized menu...there are lattes, Americanos, mochas; but they still retain some of the original Italy influenced simple drinks: espresso (variety of 1, 2, or 4 shots), cappuccino, macchiato...The coffees are served "for here" by default, if you want a paper cup to go it will cost 15 cents. Make sure you have cash as they don't take cards.
