The food on offer did not look too fresh or appealing so I skipped and went with Espresso Grande...The barista issued a warning that it will be 4 shots of espresso. Unnecessarily doubting me...No caffeine overdose here! The espresso was really good-strong and flavorful-coming out of the hand operated machine (unlike Starbucks where they just hit a button).

The bathrooms are in the back and totally inappropriate, I just have to take a star off for it. I am by no means a large person and could barely fit in. I can hardly imagine anyone over 6' being able to squeeze into the restroom. 

Next time I'm in North Beach and in need of caffeine fix, Cafe Trieste will receive my patronage. However, if I am not in North Beach I will not  go out of my way and seek it out. It's good, just not something you would visit specifically...Unless you're crazy about Corleone family and everything related.
author: Vedran V.

description:
Almost every long day ended here. Had a beer, had a coffee. Smalltalk with strangers, relaxed atmosphere. You'll get a real coffee and a homemade muffin. You'll find tourists here, but they don't behave like tourists ;-)
I've heard it's a legend - I'm sure it's true! ;-))
author: Thomas M.

description: Great and Quick Service. Smooth and frothy espresso. Could not ask for more.
author: Mark P.

description:
Came in here to get some quality espresso. Waited almost 15 minutes then got yelled at by the employee who thought I was taking a picture of him!Coffee and food should be made with a positive attitude! Let me quote
Papa Gianni"Brew each cup like it's made for you" I definitely wouldn't want my coffee to be made with anger especially waiting on Christmas Day!
author: Oliver S.

description:
How have I not reviewed this place yet?! Probably felt there's enough reviews...but then again, I didn't get the info I needed off yelp when I was sitting RIGHT THERE. Technological age - instead of going and looking, I yelp first. How sad.

Caffe Trieste is bomb. Amazing. I used to work around the corner from it, and would venture over on one of those long, or early days for my coffee fix. Now I venture here when I'm able to be mobile and work remotely. 

What I needed to know: electrical outlets. There are TWO that I'm aware of that are open (for a total of 4 sockets): One next to the jukebox, and the other on the left side of the ATM (if you're looking AT the ATM). The outlets that are above the ATM on the right side are not functional. So...fully charge that laptop if you're coming (to be safe). I had mine nearly die before I realized I needed power.

They only have one size of coffee...so if you come by for your fancy orders of whatever it is from starbucks...just begone.

The vibe around here is very mixed. There's a good amount of local people who's been coming here for years. There's the tourists who come in briefly for a beer or to experience the Trieste history. The musicians who come to strum some notes or play together. Just a wide range. Its most awesome.

Best part? They play the Giants game on their TV.

Wait. Best part is Paul, the barista.

Too many best parts. Just come by for a bit!
author: Lily W.

description:
1.5 out of 5
---------------
The coffee was alright, but the staff here was absolutely inhospitable. It was nice to stop here and rest a little, but the people behind the counter made me feel unwelcome and I hurried, finished my drink, and left. 

When I went to pick up my drink, they shouted at me multiple times and then said "what, you don't want it?!", as if I was trying to get a refund on a cup of tea I had sipped out of. All because I couldn't hear them above the noise.

There are some nice chairs outside to sit at though.
author: Nicole O.

description: Awesome coffee. It was really crowded which is a double edged sword, but definitely worth a visit. I had a Cafe Fantasia (espresso coffee made with almond syrup, had to try it since it was something different) and it was delish, a little sweet, a little bitter, and a whole lot of fresh. They have lots of pastries too! The chocolate mousse cake was phenomenal. You can tell that they take pride in their brew and in their history/reputation. If you're a coffee nut and looking for something special, definitely check it out.
author: Jen G.

description:
Me: "I'll have an espresso grande, please."
Kind gentleman behind counter: "You know that's four shots of espresso..."
Me, smiling: "Yep, I know."
My friend: "Oh, yea, she knows..."

It was the perfect espresso. 

Old school coffee/espresso shop, no pretense, no attitude, no cookie cutter experience. Nice folks too. Just the way I like 'em. Family owned and operated since 1956. Old photographs of family and customers adorn the walls, they have live music (I will be back for that!) too.

Next time I'm wandering around North Beach, I'm coming back. Thank you for existing, Caffe Trieste.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Caffe Trieste is what you'd get if you drunkenly tried to explain Starbucks to a suave Italian gentleman. 

He then goes, gets a shop, and starts making delicious Italian style coffee drinks, simple sandwiches, in a bar-style place that occasionally has live music. He opens a few more locations and suddenly you can get this same, wonderful experience in various places around the city. And you're so happy, even if you're a bit hungover.

This location is cash-only. 

Try the chai latte.
author: Liuyin S.

description: I love Caffe Trieste! Paul, Kim, Spencer, Isaac and Abby are always helpful and attentive. It is my morning ritual to get a delicious cup of coffee from that place on my way to work! Live music is real cool too.
author: Salisa K.

description:
First almond hot toddy here. 

Will not forget it.
author: Ryan K.

description: Me and my boyfriend encountered this cafe on our way to a bar. It seemed so pretty from outside that we couldnt resist. It is as pretty from inside as well. People are very nice and canolli is fantastico with americano! :)
author: Damla G.

description:
Very good coffee. The caffe mocha had very frothy steamed milk, not too sweet, and not acidic. It was smooth to say the very least, and definitely will stop here for more next time in the area.

The cannoli was standard, nothing special but tasty nevertheless.
author: Ian L.

description:
Caffe Trieste is what a coffee house should be. Old photos proudly line the walls and while I was there I saw lots of "usuals" stop in and the barista would have their drinks ready to go before they got to the register. It also seemed like everyone in the seating area knew each other as well. Even though it was constantly busy, it was still a relaxing and friendly setting to enjoy a drink!

Easy parking: There's usually plenty on Vallejo Street.
Large drink under $5: Yes
Friendly staff: Yes
Indoor seating: Several skinny tables in the middle and wooden booths along the walls.
Outdoor seating: A few small tables against the windows outside.
Decor: Lots of historic photos covering the walls of people that have stopped by in the past.
People with laptops: Good old fashioned newspapers!
Hipsters: Not really
Famous Faces: No
Foam Art: No
People watching: Great
In & out quick: Yes

PS. CA$H ONLY!!

The challenge continues!
author: Kevin R.

description: I came here with a friend while visiting San Fran to check out the oldest espresso house on the West Coast. Definitely lived up to it - the drinks my friend and I had were delicious. We were hungry since we hadn't had lunch, but unfortunately everything that was on the menu seemed to be out or unable to be made, I think their grill was out of order. We ended up having pizza, which was also very good. I loved the coziness of the place, and the live music (musicians sitting in the corner booth/tables) really added to it. It was a rainy day, though, so not much indoor seating.
author: Saifra S.

description: Best coffee so far in the States but there is a shit load of bad coffee. Try the Africano. Trieste  is a great little hang out in North Beach. Worth  the visit.
author: Simon V.

description:
coffee stronger than my mother in law.

Luckily, not as ugly.

Ya feel me?
author: Johnny L.

description: Caffe Trieste is an institution.  To the person who thinks you wrote the first review, think again.  There are two listings, one at 601 Vallejo one at 609 Vallejo.   Just sayin.
author: Rosy P.

description: We got a croissant and it was actually pretty good. The reason they only get three stars is the horrible service. We had to wait at the counter for 5 minutes while the barista chatted casually with a friend. Then when he finally served us it seemed he did so only reluctantly. Will not be going back.
author: Ruth R.

description: This cafe is very different from your standard contemporary cafe where you would see more than half of the customers sitting down and on their laptops.  This place doesn't have the contemporary decor, but very unique because it brings you back to history.  I got the cappuccino and it was solid, and the waiter was super friendly.  While we were at the cafe there were many writer-type-looking folks there, writing poems and looking for inspiration.  Pretty interesting crowd, and it was a fun place to people-watch.  We had a great time there.
author: Sarah W.

description: Cute small coffee place with nice ambience. It's a tad bit crowded however lattes are completely worth it. Baristas were nice and helpful.
author: Zuly V.

description: It's an institution. What's not to love? Filled with tourists and locals alike. That says a lot ( cuz yeah, I generally avoid really touristy places.)
author: El B.

description: Cafe Trieste is a must for a visit to North Beach.  You can catch former rock stars, poets who know it, politicians without a party, and many other locals who talk to one another with a familiarity you'd expect in a low-bottom bar or a metro police station.  Cappuccinos rule supreme and the pastries will get you through your first monologue by the window.  Go for a coffee and stay for the attitude.
author: Timothy H.

description:
Access to reliably good coffee is a pretty high priority for me... but with SF rents and rental shortages the way they are, choosing a home based on its vicinity to cafes isn't really viable. Lucky for me I live just near Caffe Trieste so I don't need to worry!

Caffe Trieste is the no muss, no fuss, no frills answer to all your coffee needs. Don't go in expecting to be able to grab an almond milk chai frappe... likewise, it's probably not the place to go if you're feeling the urge to eat a sit-down style meal (sandwiches, a few bakery goods and pizza is the extent of your food options)... but for a great cup of coffee, friendly-but-no-nonsense staff and a good SF experience, this is the place to be.

The whole cafe reeks of history and the good-ole-days... and the clientele give the impression that they've been sipping the same cup of coffee since the late 60s. Keep an open mind and eyes peeled... you're sure to see something interesting when you visit!
author: Guida B.

description: Ok so:)))).  BEST.BEST. Coffee in town. Wait there's more!!! The pastries are heavenly to die for. Fresh and amazing the type of stuff that reminds you of your childhood. Love this place must visit if in town.
author: Harout J.

description: If I could I would give this place no stars. THIS PLACE IS AN ABSOLUTE RIP OFF. I ordered two ice coffees to go. On the menu it said its 2.60. Then they add an additional 75 cents for the to go cup and 95 cents for PLAIN sweetening syrup! The guy didn't even mention it's an additional for the syrup and cup! I ended up paying $8.60 for mediocre coffee. I COULDN'T EVEN TASTE THE SWEETENER! This is the first time EVER that a place would charge for a paper cup and sweetener in a drink. Blue bottle is even better than their coffee...
author: Mikey N.

description:
My friend and I decided to stop by this place because we wanted to try out a cafe in North Beach. Pro: they have free wi-if and the iced latte I ordered was pretty good.

Con: the staff members were rude and contemptuous. One rolled his eyes and sighed when we tried to decide what we wanted to order. There wasn't even like a line so I don't know what the rush was. That was a red flag. As mentioned I ordered an iced latte and my friend ordered a chai tea latte--but they said they ran out of chai. The older staffer, seemed almost offended that we tried to order chai.  My friend decided to order a tea and that made the man unhappy. Maybe it was pride in coffee, but why offer it on the menu if you feel the need to make your patrons feel bad for ordering it? 

Basically, we got bad attitude the moment we stepped inside and that should have been our red flag. We should have walked right out. 

Don't patronize this place!
author: Critic X.

description:
Note to tired, jaded bozos working behind the counter this otherwise fine evening:

When presented with a foursome of Asian-American patrons, who have chosen not to pay attention to you for whatever reason, do not say loudly to the other staffer: "They probably don't speak English."

As a start, learn by never referring to someone present in the third person. Let alone customers. Let alone resorting to ethnic slurs.

Such a shame given the institution & history of this place. The episode was an embarrassment to the city of San Francisco.
author: Richard C.

description: Very comfortable coffee shop in North Beach. I miss it when I'm not in SF. Great place to sit and chat, work, or people watch. The fresh OJ is a nice vitamin C punch and the coffee and tea are piping hot. This historical site is a spot I like. 3 stars because it's kinda divey, just the way I like.
author: Kelley S.

description: This was recommended to us by a friend who had been there several times. When we got there, we stood in line, grabbed pastries and waited to order coffee. I have a hard time digesting cow milk, so I asked the woman behind the counter if she had almond milk for a latte. After she sneered at me, and told me they only have light and full fat milk, she treated me like I had asked her where my red carpet and tiara were. I was not impressed with the service, the prices, or the coffee.  I would not recommend this place for tourists. I have a feeling they are nice to locals only.
author: Kimber B.

description:
I came here twice because I loved CT so, so much. Their coffee is delicious, their mocha deliciously smooth and chocolatey. The clientele is a joy, always happy, and extremely polite. Saturdays they have live music from the owners and his fam (drinks cost $7 though). Their frutti di bosco is delicious. I saw red velvet, but I regret not buying it. 

Speaking of customers, my friend and I met an elderly couple, married for 57 years, and they've been at CT for a long portion of that. Decided to celebrate their anniversary there.
author: Cindy W.

description: A bit cheesy for an Italian - the music they play wasn't cool even during my grandma's times - but it's definitely really picturesque and in a great spot. Their pastries are cafes are a bit too americanised, but they're all right.
author: Carolina V.

description: Living in Europe, and having my fair share of good, no great, Italian coffee.. It's pretty hard to impress me (and my Italian friend). However, this place definitely does what it says on the box. GREAT Italian coffee. We had cappuccinos and lattes. Best in north beach.
author: Safa T.

description:
I'm not sure what was up with my barista but my mocha to go tasted horrible.  Watched her make it and saw her steaming the chocolate and espresso then scooped the steamed milk out of the pitcher??  The drink tasted like dirt water, could not finish it.

Gave one star because the house-made whipped cream on top tasted okay.
author: Jimmy M.

description: I've been coming to Cafe Trieste since I was 8, when my Dad, an Italian American with 3-generations of family from North Beach took me for my first cappuccino. I sat at the middle table by the window, had a biscotti and 3-brown sugars. I'm almost 40 now.  Everything is EXACTLY the same! All those old guys (the beatniks) were there then, and the last of them are there now.  You could still hear good Jazz in NB then.  I go to Cafe Trieste when I'm in town now, and remember the good times.  It's getting harder and harder to get a good cappuccino in the city... Most of them taste like crap.  Cafe Trieste is still the best in the city in my Italian traveling cappuccino drinking experience!
author: Joseph T.

description: This was a favorite of mine when I lived around the corner in the sixties but I won't be going back. The barista was surly and the tiny, lukewarm espresso was the smallest I've ever seen. It looked like the Cafe Trieste of memory but it didn't feel like it.
author: Peter Y.

description:
Decent coffee, but nothing close to the high standards set my most other high-end coffee shops in San Francisco.  There were flies buzzing around inside that made the experience a bit sub-standard.  The place could also use some investment and a face-lift.

They were also cash-only (a throw-back to a bygone era), which was also a little bit annoying because I had to hit up the ATM (which charged me $3)...so that I could by a $4 americano.

I know the place is part of history...but time passes and the quality of product needs to improve with the times.
author: Ben H.

description:
Cute, coffee shop! BUT be warned: it gets very loud in here. Though Caffe Trieste offers free WiFi, it's definitely not the most ideal atmosphere to be studying in. However, it is a great place to go in for a cup of latte and soak in the ambiance. There's artwork hanging on the walls and more likely than not, the stranger sitting next to you will try to strike up a conversation with you. Oh, but don't worry. People are friendly here. I believe most of them are tourists or locals.

So the next time you're in the North Beach area, I recommend you to drop by and check this place out. Based on the amount of people that came through the door (ahem, A LOT of people), this place seems to be a crowd favorite.

One more thing - this place is CASH ONLY. Don't say I didn't told you so!
author: Annie S.

description:
I have to have their cappuccino whenever I go to the North Beach and always loved it. Sometimes, my roomie and I would drive all the way here from the other side of the bay just to have their coffee. It is my favorite coffee place, I wish it isn't too far. 

I love the history of this place as being the first espresso house in the west coast in the 1950s. More than the history, the coffee just stands out from any coffee I've had. How they do it? "Buy the best beans, roast them yourself, and brew each cup like it's
for you." - Papa Giani (Founder)

The place can be a little crowded sometimes and usually has a long line. Oh, I love their cannoli too!
author: Lora M.

description:
Every time I am in San Francisco this is a must stop.

I, along with many others, like to come here on Saturdays after the Ferry Building farmers market.

On Saturdays they have live music in the back of the space.  For years local musicians have been coming here to "jam."  The lady on the accordion is worth the price of admission alone. Just kidding, no admission.

I sat, with my latte in a tall glass, at an old, broken, tile topped table, shoulder to shoulder with the woman next to me swaying to the music.  It truly was magical listening to old Italian music, which I do not know the words, being sung by those around me.  I even cried. Quietly.

Yes, supposedly the Godfather was written here.  "Hide the body, take the cannoli" graffiti can always be found in the little bathroom. LOVE.

After the music, or any other time of day I come here I always sit outside.  I drag an outside chair to the corner of Grant/Vallejo right next to the Chronicle newspaper box.  There I can set my too hot latte down for a second to cool plus I can soak up the sunshine too.

Last time I was here I sat at my outside spot.  A very San Franciscan looking man came out and pulled up a chair beside me.  We chatted for over an hour and he told me he lives in SOMA but comes here every day for his fix.  He was retired, 70, with a thick, long beard and wild hair.  

Our conversation stayed with me most of that glorious day.  And looking back I hope I too can one day have my daily fix at Caffe Trieste.
author: James S.

description: Best corner espresso in town thanks for the conversation last night Kim you are a real siciliano and a good man Marina MS did you right!
author: Michael G.

description: This cafe is where you come to bask in the amazing conversations that are always happening. Get a latte and enjoy.
author: Junebug J.

description:
OMG best espresso I've had in San Francisco!!! All those other "espresso shops" are all hype!!! It has to do with status I think! I've tried them all hoping for a GREAT ESPRESSO and all I've gotten was crapaly pulled shots that end up tasting like drip coffee watered down by milk! Sorry the truth hurts, I know! At least someone's admitting these other espresso shops arnt as good as everyone PRETENDS they are I guess to be cool!! 

But I did make a mistake and had them add some white chocolate syrup! Big mistake! The espresso can stand alone as a latte or cap!  

I noticed some of the reviews said some of the employes are unpleasant but honestly I believe the owner an older man with blond hair was helping me and you know that's just how some people are! And I could tell he was a nice person with a hard outer shell! People like that you must just be nice and pleasant too love them for who they are and you'll see there true side come out!  And you know what the workers at all the other "hip" espresso shops are rude like they're too good to even talk to you, with they're smug attitudes! At least this guy at this shop tells you what he really thinks!! Haha! Love it!!!!!

Anyways the 4 shots were a real 4 shots how they should be!! I usually get 4 shots expecting it to equal my 2 shots I pull at home on my Rocket Espresso machine (epic machine by the way) and man oh man this little espresso shop on the corner blew my mind!! 

Thanks for the GREAT drink! I'll be back next time I'm in SF!!!! And I'll pass on the white chocolate! 

To the older man with the blond hair .... You rock!!! 
Younger guy with beard pulling the shots.... One word... AWESOME!!!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description:
"And so it Begins..."

SITREP

No, I'm not making a reference by this famous quote to either the Lord of the Rings (spoken by King Theoden before the gates of Helm's Deep) or to Babylon 5 (spoken by the Vorlon Ambassador), but rather to my COFFEE ADDICTION.  I have come full circle: Caffe Trieste, you see, is my personal GROUND ZERO where my entire love for coffee was kicked off.  [And I have my two buddies, Michael Grosse and Shane Wesbrock to curse for that!] ;^)

I should clarify that my "awareness" for coffee happened quite early as a youth in Seattle when dear old mom would take me to the original Starbucks at Pikes Place Market when there were JUST ONLY a handful of Starbucks at this moment in time.  So you see, you haterz out there are NEVER going to get me to vilify Starbucks because for me that would be like cursing my mom.  It ain't gonna happen. But even with my decades-old appreciation for Starbucks, I still enjoy and prefer classy cafes & independent coffee houses when I get the chance to frequent them whichever city I'm in, and it doesn't get any classier or more fulfilling than visiting Caffe Trieste.

THE SETUP

It was a night of firsts that Michael helped happen.  We actually came down to San Francisco for a SONIC YOUTH show (my first) at the Fillmore (my first time at this venue) this particular night in the late 90s.  [The show, by the way, was spectacular, and Kim Gordon was to DIE FOR.]  But before hitting the Fillmore, Michael wanted to stop by Caffe Trieste - a place as of yet I'd never been (so again, another first) - and this is where we met up with our buddy Shane Wesbrock.

Up until this point, I was mainly a soda freak all throughout college and law school.  But I had a mocha here and immediately fell in love with coffee, for the first time.  [Soon thereafter, Americanos, Lattes, and even espressos entered my lexicon of caffeine.  Ah, the good life!]

HISTORY

But this place is much more than just coffee.  It is part of the living, breathing history of coffee in America.  Caffe Trieste opened in 1956 by Giovanni Giotta (aka "Papa Gianni"), who in 1950 had emigrated to San Francisco from the small fishing town of Rovigno, Italy (now part of Croatia).  Missing the espresso houses of Trieste, Italy, Giotta opened his own cafe.  And Caffe Trieste is said to be the first espresso house on the West Coast.

Caffe Trieste is also a tribute to the living history of authors and beat movement philosophers whom once congregated here in North Beach and solidified their manifestos for social reorganization. Michael told me that authors such as Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg found and expressed their inspiration to others here while sipping on coffee.  Shane shared that Francis Ford Coppola wrote most of the Godfather screenplay while finding solace here. 

And Trieste's "Artist" vibe has always attracted famous artists and entertainment personalities including Bill Cosby, Joey Reynolds, Michael Douglas, Chris Isaak, Armando Peraza, Paul Kantner, Boz Scaags, Robert Vaughn, and Vincent Price to name a few.   In 2009, Israeli poet Roy Arad visited the cafe and wrote about it in his diary.  

THE LOWDOWN

Caffe Trieste is MORE than just a place about getting a cup of coffee.  It's the caffeinated heartbeat of alternative and artistic America, and one can't help but wonder what current authors, future artists, etc., are getting their inspiration here as we speak....*turns the page*...
author: Michelangelo S.

description:
Needing a breather and a caffeine fix after climbing Telegraph Hill, we dropped in on the hip and historic Caffe Trieste in the North Beach area.

According to their website, Caffe Trieste was opened in 1956 by "Papa Gianni" Giotta, as the first espresso house on the West Coast.  Soon thereafter, the forefathers of the budding Beat Generation, such as Allen Ginsberg and Jack Kerouac, took over the café to compose and recite their poetry.

Modern-day poets on laptops in search of the perfect word still occupy many of the cafe's tables.  Black and white photographs dangling from the walls affirm the cafe's popularity with famed writers and actors.  Supposedly, Francis Ford Coppola worked on the screenplay for The Godfather while sipping espresso at Caffe Trieste.

Caffe Trieste was a switched-on place for a coffee break during our visit to North Beach.  We found the baristas surly and short-tempered, but their espresso drinks were spot-on.  Caffe Trieste deserves three stars for its storied history, bohemian vibe, and robust espresso.  A little smile from the staff would have warranted a fourth star.
author: Joe R.

description: Hip, Trendy, just plain odd make up of patrons makes for some great people watching! The coffee is on par with some of the best I've had! Nice selection of baked goods and pizza. Cash only!
author: Randy C.

description:
I liked the pizza!  I enjoyed my combination (it had zucchini) Sicilian!  I don't see a lot of Sicilian-style pizzas in San Jose so whenever I'm in North Beach, I make an attempt to have it.  

Only con: cash only

I know this is a coffee joint but I did not need caffeine.  When you reach the guy (long ass line), you order (if you order a sandwich or pizza, he will place your item on a panini press, and after just 2-3 minutes... you'll be in dough heaven.
author: Tram N.

description:
An Irish coffee at Caffe Trieste followed my browsing at City Lights, which was preceded by drinking at Vesuvio.  This combination of drinks and browsing made me feel like the awesome beatnik hipster that I'm so totally not.

Caffee Trieste is a small-ish cafe, and the drinks are inexpensive.  I think my Irish coffee was $2-3?  Independent coffeehouses are hard to come by in the Chicago suburbs, so I fell in love with this place.  And my coffee came in a real cup, not a paper cup with a travel lid.  Oooh, impressive!

Awesome spot I'd love to revisit.
author: Angela P.

description:
I had a really really good espresso doppio here. 
Don't forget to visit the coffee store next door! There they sell their perfect beans and coffee paraphernalia.
author: Joris L.

description: Great coffee and atmosphere, but they tend to kick you out after you've been there for a while. Don't recommend it as a place to study unless you're going to be buying coffee after coffee after coffee.
author: Leslie J.

description: Forget the acidic, bitter, "challenging" espresso drinks from the new hipster coffee joints; I'll take a smooth espresso from the cozy confines of Caffe Trieste any day.  My favorite spot for a latte in the city.
author: Ivy W.

description: Cappuccino was good, but service was weak. I understand that you want to have an attitude as a barista but at least be funny. I may be being hard because I didn't feel the force ghosts of any jedi beats.
author: Steven C.

description: Very good espresso, beans seem to be roasted a little lighter than some more commercial places, yielding a lighter, less acidic, and sweeter taste...good enough to get a couple pounds of beans to take home for my everyday machine!
author: Jim W.

description:
If u are a tourist like myself and searching for the best coffee shop in SF...do not go here! This place was nothing special! The coffee i make at home tastes better! The staff was not friendly either! The barista had such a morbid attitude,
like seriously hating his job, that he over charged me( was charging me over $30 for 2 coffees and 2 cookies) he didn't do a double take until he saw my face. Yes, like wake up dude! It's Wednesday and ure at work, put ure game face on and make someone's day! U are in tourist central! They should so let go those type of people! So dissatisfied! Wish I would of gone somewhere else!
author: Nereida G.

description:
3/3 locals recommended Trieste for the best coffee in North Beach.

Unfortunately, I think this place is more hype, tradition, and legend than it is quality.

I gave it two tries and wasn't wowed either time. The coffee was so-so, the workers weren't friendly, the place is hot, crowded, and dirty, the bathroom is teeny and gross, and the one redeeming quality was the dapper, nautical-looking man-of-a-particular-age in there with some of his buddies on a Friday night. No really, I really liked his outfit. Why are these men so cool and hip? I hope I'm cool and hip when I'm of-a-particular-age and (hopefully) nautical-looking, but at a place that serves better coffee.
author: Marie L.

description: Super cool and OG coffee shop but the coffee is way too bitter! Got the cappuccino and couldn't finish it
author: Vida E.

description: Self proclaimed as an International landmark in San Francisco's North Beach Neighborhood and purportedly the first place for Espresso on the West Coast back in the 50's my stop at Caffe Trieste was brief but enjoyable; the baristas clever and the prices good. Sure there is the traditional "coffee shop hipster" sort taking up the some of the cracked leather/vinyl furniture but the Americano I ordered was bold yet balanced, steaming hot, and otherwise excellent. Arriving late in the day there were no pastries to be sampled on this visit and the gentleman in the retail shop next door was a bit surly, but all-in-all a good place to grab a quick cup of coffee.
author: Michael U.

description:
I don't know if it's sacrilege for a neighborhood local to give anything less than undying love for Caffe Trieste, but I think it's decent but not extraordinary. 

To be fair, Caffe Trieste is a very charming coffee shop. If you have the time to slow it down, it's a nice spot to enjoy your coffee. You'll quickly figure out who the neighborhood regulars are and which are the gawking tourists. It's actually a prime spot for people watching in North Beach. I think the lines can get long though and they move pretty slow here. The lines also seem to make the baristas a little grouchy. The combination of the two prevents me from stopping in to grab my coffee especially when most of the time, I just need a grab and go cup of Joe. Smile optional. 

Perhaps I am the wrong customer for Caffe Trieste but it will have its charm for others. On a sunny day, it is a nice spot to grab a seat outside and relax. If you like coffee, you might want to come by to benchmark it. My thought is the experience here is more than the coffee.
author: Jon L.

description: Strong, strong coffee!!! Excellent.  Not as full bodied as before. Very good if you want to wake up for sure. Very hot too! Need to double cup or get a sleeve.
author: Kitty D.

description: Yay! Someone in SF knows how to make a ristretto that is thick, smooth, and not overwhelmingly acidic. And that someone works at Cafe Trieste. Best espresso for COFFEE lovers (not milk and sugar and whipped cream lovers)..
author: Jackie P.

description:
Great indie coffee shop.  Why go to Sbux when you could go to a place like this?

Right on the edge of North Beach, this place had a line out the door both times we visited.  The two baristas worked like a couple of well-oiled machines, but with humor and grubby charm.  :-)

NOTE: they do not accept credit cards - cash only.
author: Richard R.

description: Great place for coffee ab and pastries! Love the service and dedication of the employees!
author: Patricia H.

description:
Another North Beach must stop...

Now dont stop here if you're in a hurry.. Talk about busy, busy, busy.. Esp wben local artists play music..  I always get the Mocha.. Even tge coffee is amazing.. The chocolate they use os delicious without being too sweet.. And the whip cream deserves a review and 5 stars on its own- obviously house made. Everytime i frequent this coffee hot spot i always get a cup of whipbon the side... Sometimes i also get a,,2nd mocha.. 

A couple things.. On"concert" days, it's a bit more pricey to drink in house.. 

The drinks are delish, the pastries, devine, the whip  cream sinful, and all in all I LOVE NB..
author: Lisa H.

description:
I worked in coffee service for quite a few years before graduating college.

I'm not offended by a barista taking their time, but there reaches a point where it starts to get ridiculous. I also am not a big fan of all the regulars being served over and around me, while im standing there in line. Why serve 3 regulars who are behind me their drinks, and then even have them pay before me? I got shit to do too. 

Don't bother if you can't drink regular milk, that's all they offer. 

Also, if you get it to go, they charge you extra for the cup.

I tried to go a few times, but I can't deal with all of that anymore.
author: Joelle B.

description:
I don't like coffee so I guess it's not fair for me to review this, right? Well, I'm going to anyway because I use to live in North Beach right around the corner from Trieste. 

I've only been in a few times, but it's a cool environment. If I wanted to sit down and drink tea, I wouldn't mind doing it here. Though i must say it's often very crowded because of all the dumb tourists that hang around here.

As for the coffee, everyone i know who's had it says it's like crack. If that sounds good to you, then you'd probably love it.

But I must say, if I had to choose a cafe to hang out in North Beach, just for the experience of being there, I'd go to 901.
author: Jon T.

description:
yuppie dude: "can I get a non-fat latte?"
barista: "we ain't go no non fat?  get out of here"
yuppie dude: "what about soy milk?"
barista: "seriously"
yuppie dude: "sorry, it's not for me, just a regular coffee"

espresso grande: best espresso ever.  they still warn me everytime that its 4 shots...
author: Kevin L.

description:
LOVE this place - said it before and will say it again and again.

One of my favorite tables is the one next to the jukebox.  There's nothing like enjoying a delicious cup of latte with Italian music in the background while reading the Sunday's paper...it just makes me feel so calm, peaceful and blessed.

Walking by last night before 9pm, the place was unusually empty - we took advantage and went in but settled at a table next to the window.  Besides our usual drinks, we also got a slice of the carrot cake.  

The guys behind the counter were super nice.  They were having dinner - cous cous w/ some kind of chicken stew.  We were offered some and a taste of this spicy sauce - delicious.  

The place packed up after 9pm and there's nothing like hearing the passionate conversations of the locals although we have no clue what they are saying.

LOVE this place!
author: Gloria H.

description:
Caffe Trieste was featured in the action/emergency show filmed in SF (I'm blanking on the name!) which makes it pretty cool in my book.

However, I have to deduct stars because I'm somewhat lactose intolerant and they don't have soy milk or any milk without lactose. They also don't have nonfat milk... so, I can really only get straight coffee as a coffee beverage here and their coffee is good but nothing incredible. With so many other coffee shops around North Beach that do carry soy, sorry Trieste, but I'll usually go elsewhere!
author: Meghan P.

description: The most classic of classic cafes in San Francisco! So much history and so much atmosphere! In the fantastic Italian North Beach district on one of the best little fun streets Grant Ave. This place is so nostalgic, I love the big old red espresso machine.
author: Peter K.

description:
What does it take to get a soy latte around here? Nothing at all, apparently. They don't do that here. It's cow's milk or bust. Too bad for those who would prefer that option. 

Lactose intolerant? Prefer to avoid the white stuff from the udder? Then mooooooove on to some other place. And trust me: there are alternatives aplenty. Can anyone say Philz? Can anyone say Blue Bottle? Can anyone say Four Barrel? You get my drift.

But, if you accept the old school, "we don't do soy" macho/grungy/Beatnik milieu, then Caffe Trieste is a fine place to spend your money and a bit of your time.   

Me, I'm not fazed b/c I drink my coffee black. And the espresso I ordered was decent enough, except that there was no crema to speak of and it looked and tasted as if it could have come from a stovetop espresso/Mocha machine. The heavily milked latte came in a glass w/ long-necked spoon and tasted of brown caffinated goodness but without knocking anyone's socks off.

The vibe here is of course neat, with lots of history on the walls and great old light fixtures, stained glass, tables, wood paneling, and the like. No mistaking this place for anything other than a coffeehouse. 

And no mistaking it for anything other than Caffe Trieste, either. It's not a chain, It cannot be copied. It belongs here and nowhere else. It has a history.

My favorite slice of that history? Well, it's captured in one of the photographs hanging on the wall: a visit by Bill Cosby in 1976 when he (according to the picture) made his own cappuccino.

That's cool. Jello Pudding Pop cool.

Just no soy, please. That wouldn't be proper here. If you want soy, bring your own.
author: Bradley N.

description: Historic business with perfect espresso drinks, almost or sometimes perfect Italian pastries, OK munchies, beat era and tourist crowds, located in a gorgeous neighborhood, with so-so customer service--a cash-only caffè.
author: Raymond F.

description: I first visited Caffee Trieste on a weekend afternoon. It was time for a pick-me-up and the thought of a good warm cappuccino was appealing on this cloudy afternoon. It was cozy and a small band was playing in the back. The barista was friendly and efficient and the beverage came out perfect. It's cash only, but the prices aren't bad.
author: Blair S.

description: 4 stars?   Seems like a run of the mill coffee shop full of retired people with 3.00+ pasteries.
author: Mark O.

description:
Matt was at North Beach's finest cafe early Sunday morning for a cup of Latte and hopefully get some reading done. 

Every time Matt comes here, the line is too freakin long and debate whether to stay here or get his drink/food elsewhere. But this time around, the line wasn't too bad with 3 thristy caffeine-junkies ahead of Matt. 

Finally Matt got his tasty and creamy Latte and with all the patrons BULLSHITTING loudly and rudely about there arrogant lives, Matt decides to take his drink and reading elsewhere. This cafe's atmosphere, when crowded is NOT a good place to read, unless you bring ear-plugs, in which Matt usually bring but forgot that day.
author: Matt G.

description: I love the atmosphere but don't know why they are supporting a corporate puppet like Julie Christensen for Supervisor.
author: Kooky B.

description:
My friends and I went here with much anticipation since a few of my coffee lover friends had recommended this place and the webpage claims that this was the place that brought  espresso to the west coast. We are from Portland, the land of Public Domain coffee and Spella Cafe, so we know good coffee.

We ordered cappuccinos and a couple of rugelachs. The rugelachs were quite yummy and the selection of pastries good. The cappuccino was reasonably good but definitely not the best I have had, and the claims of this being the best espresso shop in town is an overhype.

Things I liked about the cappucino: The foam was smooth. The good size (~8 oz). A nice leaf design.

Things I didn't like about the cappuccino: The espresso was a bit bitter either due to over roasting or the brewing technique. Would have like more foam in the cappuccino.

Summary: Wouldn't mind going back to this place, but my quest for the best cappuccino in the bay area continues.
author: Anupama C.

description: Wifi is not good.  I had a $5 iced latte which seemed a bit small and not particularly special.  Both of the baristas seemed impatient...  no easy outlet access which doesn't make it a great place to work.  I prefer Caffè Grecco about a block away.
author: Alex G.

description: It's tiny but very French if you're looking to get "away" :). Cappuccino is good and so are their pastries. I would say this is an average place not over the top awesome.
author: Kim M.

description:
Oh Mustache Man... you craft espresso drinks with the care and attention of an alchemist from times past.  You have the strategic mind of Napoleon, yet the heart of Jimmy Carter. When Mustache Man is working the counter, I never leave Caffe Trieste feeling ignored or unloved (and I always find out the wifi password).

Mustache Man... your mother raised you well, and whomever hired you made a wise choice.

Thank you Mustache Man.
author: David L.

description:
What a stinky attitude from a mustache man! 

I asked the mustache server man if I can get the internet code for the Wi-Fi and he said in a rude tone, have you bought any beverages yet?  I responded by saying I will eventually, but the line is so long.  Then he said the code that made me feel uncomfortable, I accessed it, but went to line up for a coffee beverage because I felt bad not buying a drink first.  You would think at this point he would step out of his offish zone and apply customer service by asking me what I wanted to drink.  No.  The line was not moving and never bug a person, like me, who has not drank their daily coffee yet!  I got grouchy being asked by an unfriendly, mustache man if I have bought a coffee yet and had to stand in a long line for it!  The mustache man even helped a senior man at the end of the line, instead of the next person...what the?  It's nice to help a senior, but seriously, you're not going to help the next customer in line?  grrrrr...that just ticked me into walking out!  

I am not going to put in my money for the rude service I get - no matter how reputable your place may be!  Yes, you may have Godfather on your back, but that's history now!  This coffee shop looks super worn out and there are so many other competition around the block!  

I love mama-papa cafes and I have grown up around this area since childhood, but never tried this place until today.  Probably another 5 years until I step into this place again to try their coffee or when they have changed baristas...for the better! 

Mustache man!  You give me the creeps!  Who hired you? 

 ***HELLO INTERNATIONAL-FRIENDLY STARBUCKS!!!***
author: Tiffany D.

description: One of the nice stumbles: the walking down a street find. And just a great cup of coffee. Wait, plus a gazillion pieces of history behind a very old cafe. I saw sepia- tinted pictures of musical greats. Turns out,  Francis Ford Coppola wrote much of the screenplay for The Godfather while sitting here.
author: Yavnika K.

description: It has great pastries and deserts. Coffee was okay. There is a jukebox player and it has an old vibe.
author: Justin D.

description: The two younger guys that work there are really awesome, the older white haired Italian guy (the owner I'm assuming) is always stoned face and mean makes it seem like he doesn't even want people to order anything and is bothered by doing his simple job of pouring espresso shots. Really makes me not want to get my coffee there even if though it is close to work.whoever you are, fix your attitude or retire already. I have heard other people complaining about the Same thing.
author: Marsha H.

description: A bit chaotic but worth the experience. The vege pizza took forever to be heated up and was average. Our capuccinos were fabulous. What a mix of characters.There was a guy wandering around the cafe in some type of costume. Took a pic of him and another customer. Never figured out if he was there to entertain or just one of the regulars.. .
author: Joe M.

description: Great place. Steamed milk in my coffee was a nice change. A bunch of screwballs on this Sunday evening make this place a gem.
author: Joseph P.

description: One star - and that's being nice.  This was my first visit to San Francisco this past Thanksgiving weekend and stopped in here to get a much needed cup of coffee only to be met with poor customer service and attitudes.  It was very disappointing.  I wouldn't go back and will not recommend it either.  Not even if you paid me.  It's a shame too, lot's of history ...
author: Dawn R.

description: Amazing coffee,Nostalgic place,Good music ... Every time I go to SF,I always stop by  ! My fav Spot!
author: Pelin S.

description:
Great local Coffee shop in North Beach, It has a very old school "beat-up" look and feel. You will find plenty of beatniks still hanging out here. It is truly a old souls kinda place.
They have live music and poetry reading on a weekly basis.
Expect to wait in line awhile, if there ain't no line, buy yourself a lotto ticket because it's your lucky day
author: Séamus C.

description: Step it up people! I was just in there and not impressed with the customer service. I received no reply when I asked the man behind the counter, 'how are you' and instead, got a very burly grunt when I ordered a drink. Caffe Trieste, if you don't want people flocking to Starbucks, Pete's or other coffee chains where they know good customer service usually involves being pleasant, try and smile once in a while.
author: Caryn M.

description: Love this place.  I've been coming here for forty years.  Authentic Italian neighborhood charm never goes out of style. Awesome coffee;  sit and read or hang out with friends. Coffee chains can't compare to this.  Come get the real thing!
author: Jamie M.

description: Terrible watered down folgers type coffee. It has a nice atmosphere though. But if you want decent coffee at a reasonable price pass it up and go to peets!
author: Roman W.

description:
This coffee shop proved to be a worthy stop on our way to Chinatown from Coit Tower. 

Cafe Trieste has a lot of character and its history proves it.  It's been around since 1956. Memorabilia and pictures from the past line their walls. Charming wooden furniture for seating have seen many a folks who've stopped by to pass time here: perhaps to read a newspaper, share a pastry with a friend or simply rest your tired feet. The barista was friendly and made drink suggestions for my sis.  Service with a smile is a definite plus.

My small cafe Americano had a very robust flavor and my sis liked her vanilla flavored Italian soda.  

For you caffeine addicts who need that cup of java late night, this place is open til 12 am on Friday and Saturday nights.
author: Janice C.

description:
I've heard this place is really crowded during peak hours, but I've only been there around 6pm, when it was quieter. They've got seats outside, which are fabulous for people watching, but they're usually taken, so don't hold your breath. I'm not a hard-core coffee enthusiast, so I can't vouch for the quality of their joe, but I did enjoy my drink, for whatever that's worth.

And ladies, Caffe Trieste also seems to be a favorite spot for older Italian "gentlemen" on weekend nights. Whether you like it or not, they will enthusiastically greet you, ask about your destination for the evening, and inquire the reason why you won't join them for a drink. But maybe you will! I don't know. Just a heads up.
author: Amy M.

description:
Located on one of the best corners in North Beach, Caffe Trieste is a mainstay for coffee hounds and cool folks of all ages. 

There is a palpable history. If your sixth sense is off, the photos of many a famous person on the walls will clue you in. The floor looks well broken in, also. I love that look. Kind of a chipped paint deal. Large windows and a great view of the immediate intersection give you plenty to observe during your visit.

The staff isn't overly amicable, but so what! This isn't Disney World. These guys have real lives and real problems. f you want a fancy coffee, beat it! Just order something normal, pay and sit the f*ck down. Kick back and relaxxx and watch some odd hominids walk by. I will return on my next SF visit.
author: Jeff O.

description: I love the old 'we've been here for 50 years and ain't goin nowhere' feel to the place. I enjoyed the atmosphere more than the product. The coffee was alright. The coffee cake was more crust than actual cake. But, I do imagine that this would be a nice place to be for one of there shows, and all the fun that there is to be had there.
author: renje g.

description: Mmm good cappuccino. It was pretty strong, which i like. Cool place with tons of pictures to look at. Lines can be long.
author: Evan L.

description:
Reading the no soy milk reviews here, I'm beginning to wonder if the lady in front of me just ordered it for sh!ts and giggles or she really was that clueless. I prefer the latter.

I learned my lesson and ordered a drip cafe au lait and it was wonderful.
author: Rachelle Q.

description:
Okay, fine. The espresso is the best around. The digs are better. The nostalgia and North Beach itself are the best. 

I began coming to the Trieste in 1977. North Beach looks and feels pretty much the same.

The ATM in the phone booth - that's new.

Loved being here again. What's not to love.
author: Michael S.

description: The place has the best coffee in town but they need to cleanup the place.   It is actually filthy anywhere you look inside.   It would be a much better experience if they spend a little money on cleaning and minor upgrades.
author: Seth T.

description: Out walking the dog at 7am and thought this would be a good coffee spot given the history and reviews. I was wrong.  The server was rude and unfriendly, the coffee bland and the pastries were at least at day old!   I'll keep walking next time.
author: Michaela H.

description: Cafe bustling with locals serving bitter and strong coffee, pastries, wine and sandwiches. I was turned off watching the staff touch money and then food with no gloves or hand washing. Empty tables were all dirty. Bummer
author: Val R.

description: Great service and coffee. I am a big coffee fan and that place was great for that. It is local hangout and it has it own personality. Barista was very professional.
author: Al G.

description: Came here after a recommendation from a former North Beach resident and I was not disappointed. I had a very tasty and strong  cappuccino! Appears to be a real neighborhood institution; staff and customers know each other by name, lots of banter and camaraderie!
author: Lauren M.

description:
My trips to SFO are never complete until I visit this cafe.  The coffee never disappoints and the pastries are delicious.  A prized location for people watching and eavesdropping on hilarious and witty conversations.  Witnessed a verbal cuss match that soon blended in with the strolling passerbyers and their scruffy dogs.  

A comforting place that has offered much comfort and inspiration to the likes of Jack Kerouac and Francis Ford Coppola.  Maybe I think I'm hobnobbing with brilliance.  Maybe I think I'll be inspired to write the next "On The Road" or "Godfather" script.  Whatever it is, I like feeling a part of something lasting and cool, way before it became commodity.
author: Kalani C.

description:
I find one or two small inconveniences or annoyances about a restaurant pretty tolerable, and this usually doesn't affect my yelp ratings too much. I frequent cash-only places, greasy, dingy, hole-in-the-walls, places with weirdly aggressive or apathetic staff...but somehow my recent experience with Caffe Trieste compounded a lot of small annoyances into a generally unpleasant time. 

Caffe Trieste is cash-only, which is surprising for such an established place. But not a big deal if you plan ahead. The menu was nice, varied with okay pricing. I happily ordered a NY egg cream and my partner got some sort of sandwich, an espresso, and a beer. I watched the barista put my egg cream together with some half-hearted whipping of the chocolate and milk. He then overflowed the drink with carbonated water and slid it over to me without wiping the glass down. No napkin or straw accompanied my order ...which again...is fine. I toddled over to the back half of the restaurant and discovered disgusting cafe tables made up of a DIY mishmash of colorful ceramic tiles. The 1/4" gaps between the tiles were embedded with what was pretty much soil -- a  deep, dark brown build-up of probably old food particles and human skin flakes and dirt. I looked closer and saw tiny, 1mm long translucent bugs making their home in this "soil". I quickly moved back to the more crowded front-end of the cafe where the tables were of the generic metal sort. Let me break it down:

Pros: 
- They had free, somewhat spotty wi-fi.
- Pricing was decent (~3 for a caffeinated drink, ~8 for a plate of food)
- Food was not bad (I admittedly can't really tell the difference between an okay espresso and an amazing espresso. The sandwich was meh, with half of the fixings on the side, which is a thing, I guess? The NY egg cream tasted fine, although it was room temperature)
- Big windows in the front

Cons:
- Cash only
- Checked out employees and mediocre service
- Gross tables in the back, grimy sort of place in general
- Crazy people wandering in and yelling at the baristas/bothering the patrons


So I probably won't be coming back here and I really don't get how this place is so well-established. Maybe their coffee is mind-blowingly awesome and I lack the refined palate to taste it? I am at a loss.
author: Jasper P.

description:
Trieste is charming and apparently famous. The coffee is good and drinks are made properly; I hate ordering a cappuccino and getting a latté, but my drink was almost exactly one-third foam. 

The customers are friendly and there's a neighborhood-y vibe. I was doing some work on a recent trip, and the next thing I knew I was participating in an in-depth conversation with an sweet little man about the abolition of the slave trade in England.

A few tips:
-Don't order your drink in Italian, unless you are Italian.
-On a related note: know what you want or the baristas will sneer at you.
-Make sure to bring cash, or use the ATM inside.
-If you bring a laptop, fully charge it beforehand. I only saw one outlet.
author: Sarita A.

description: I hate to give this place, which played an important role in the Beat movement, 1 star, but I gotta say that the barista was pretty much an a-hole and their dessert not so good. Plus, the chai tea we ordered came from a box. In short, not much spirit or soul in this place. And the Oakland shop is not much better. Both of them have an overwhelming "dirty" feeling. And I am one who doesn't really care about dirt, but these places make me think they clean with a week-old dishrag in cold soapless water. So many coffee shops in these cities that there is no real reason to ever go to Caffee Triste.
author: Pablo A.

description:
This is a really cool coffee-bar in Little Italy.  I come here every time I'm in the city.
The ambience is great - very 1950's avant garde, with many interesting photos on the walls.
The coffee served here is great.  It is strong.  I mean that in a good way. As in authentic.  

They will laugh at you if you ask them to yuppify it.  And they will be justified.

Don't come here if your favorite coffee-shop is Starbucks; unless of course, you have never been exposed to coffee better than Starbucks.  In which case you should debate about coming here, because you won't want to go back into a Starbucks.

There is music on the weekends (with a cover / min drink charge).

I believe they only take cash.

Right next door, you can buy their assorted coffees by the pound.
I like the fact that they go through it so quickly they are literally keeping 35 gallon garbage cans of a few of their roasts.   Bags are filled to order.  As an FYI, you may use a credit card if buying coffee next door.  I don't know if there is a minimum charge to use credit card; I live out of state, and usually buy at least a few pounds on my visits, so it's never been an issue.
author: Maggi K.

description: Very cool coffee shop-worth standing in line for a cup of coffee... This place was recommended by the person at the book store nearby. I tried hot chocolate with almond syrup and cafe americano-both were delicious! Also tried an oatmeal cookie and another little pastry-nothing out of this world, but good coffee accompaniment. I would definitely come back for another coffee whenever I come back to San Francisco! Very authentic, local and old-fashioned coffee shop ambience...
author: Natalia A.

description: I first went here in 1977,when my sister came to visit. I had no idea what North beach was or where it was!  love this place on saturdays,when it is packed with locals and love the music performed by the family members. finding a seat is hard sometimes,but there are usually places to sit outside. try the Italian sodas if coffee isn't your favorite beverage,and the food is so good,especially the pastries and pizzas. when the music is being performed, drinks go up to $6.00. it is a bit quieter on weekdays,but still is a great place for people watching.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Very Italian. They are serious about their Italian coffee, which I respect. However, they don't have non-dairy products (i.e. soy milk) for the lactose intolerant like myself. I went ahead and ordered a cafe latte though so that I could try this coffee shop that was deemed one of the best in SF. Carefully prepared, and if I wasn't so full from Mama's beforehand I would have definitely tried their pastries that were lined up against the counter window sweetly calling my name.

I'd say this is more of a come and read the morning newspaper or chat with a friend or stop by to kill some time type of place. Not necessary study-inducing because it can get rather busy. Also attracts an older crowd, so it's kind of nice doing some old-people watching. :)
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I love Caffe Trieste, it is right in the center of north beach and right by my mom's. It's a super cute and crowded neighborhood coffee shop. I like the almond drink and their lattes, the espresso flavor is just right: STRONG! The drinks are not very big which  I guess it's a good thing, I don't need a venti drink everywhere I go. They also serve pastries, pizzas and sandwiches, they heat it up for you in their Panini press which is nice. 
4 stars because they move kind of slow and they don't always have the best customer service. I swear sometimes the guys are PMSing. Sometimes, their super nice and then sometimes they snap at you like mean girls in high school. Oh wells, I still love them. btw, cash only and no customization. Parking is also a pain.
author: Suzzie B.

description: Just wait your turn patiently and enjoy the best cappuccino in San Francisco .. I try espresso drinks all over SF ..  This place ranks number one ... Funky little neighborhood .. Love North Beach ! The Baristas are unmatched ..
author: Spyglass H.

description: Caffe Trieste is great; I love a place that serves lattes AND wine- a little something for everyone :)  I ordered a vanilla latte and it was smooth and rich and GOOD.  My friend ordered a red wine which he seemed to enjoy.  The ambience is nice, it feels like you're in an old cafe.  There is wifi, and the patrons were working, or chatting, etc.  Trieste also had some yummies, including pastries, bagels, etc.  I really enjoyed the place, but had to deduct a star for the bathroom.  I'm a short person and I could barely move in the bathroom;  the bathroom also seemed like it hadn't been cleaned in awhile.  It was dark and musty, and could stand to be updated.  If I was ever in the area again, I would stop in for a delicious latte, but skip the bathroom.
author: Melissa L.

description: A coffee shop that clearly has been here for awhile. It would be nice if they cleaned it once in awhile.
author: M C.

description:
Love, love, love this local hangout place.  We have been visiting SF annually for the last 4 yrs, didn't find out about it until last year when we had breakfast at Monterey's site.

I love their Cafe Mocha - strong coffee w/ very good choc, sweet enough but not too sweet.  Hubby loves their Americano.

Note: this is a place that you cannot "customize" your drink - first time we were there, I ordered w/ extra shot & told bluntly "no, you don't want extra shot".  He's right as the coffee is very strong already, don't need that extra shot as it will kill the good marriage of that choc taste.

Their pastries are awesome too, and they have the same yeast-donuts from that lady @ Ferry's Building - who only available on the weekend.  We love their "bear claw" pastry filled w/ marzipan.  Hubby is not big in marzipan as most of the time is too sweet, but for this, I'm lucky if I got couple bites of it, and it's big pastry.  They have lots of yummy looking cookies too that we haven't try them yet - that's our goal for the 2 days left of this trip - I think we can achieve that goal.
author: Ivy S.

description:
Awesome coffee.  Unbeatable history for SF.  

You walk into this place and really get a sense of what North Beach & SF felt like a few decades ago.  In a good way.  Tons of pictures on the wall, some of famous people that performed there back in the hay day.  Regulars who have been going there for probably as long as they can remember.  

Nowadays, though, it's also a very popular spot to bring your computer and get some work done.   

Pros: The espresso is among the best I've had. 

Cons: Prepare to wait in a bit of a line.  Also they take cash only. 

Pro Tip: Don't go here during prime time  if you are claustrophobic!  It's a pretty small place and always PACKED.
author: Monica T.

description: Awesome coffee and great atmosphere. You might have to wait in a long line for coffee and it's cash only, but it's so worth it.
author: Addison M.

description:
If it's people watching you are after, this is not the place, because besides the occasional European tourists who are diligently looking for the best off the beaten path spots in SF, you will mostly see older men sitting for hours, smoking and chatting with each other. 

But, if it's absolutely the best capuccino or latte that you are after, this is the place.  
I like Philz and Blue Bottle as much as anyone else, but sorry - they are not quite where Triste is when it comes to flavor and intensity.
author: Arkady I.

description: All hype, no substance! Read that this place was supposed to be one of the top 5 cafes in San Fran (Huffington Post article) - you must be kidding!! Don't get what the fuss is about - my coffee was average and my husband's chai latte was made from pre-packaged syrup!!! The pizza tasted like something from Pizza Hut the night before! Worth giving this place a miss! Very grungy and dirty as well.
author: Rhianna C.

description: My single espresso reminded me of the many I enjoyed on a recent trip to Europe.  A crowded, bustling and tiny cafe..thanks for the memories, CT!
author: Kristi C.

description:
The only reason why this isn't getting an extra star is because it's cash only. Also, they don't have soy milk.

Now, on to all the awesome stuff...

I met up with my girl friend on one of those few "warm" summer nights. I'm on of the lucky types that can have coffee at night and not be up for hours. I ordered a cappuccino and my friend ordered a cider. A cute Italian type guy made my drink and it tasted fantastic. i didn't check to see what kind of espresso they use but it was delicious and strong and thick and made with care and a smile. 

we took our drinks outside where there were two older men playing guitar. it was lovely to be outside and enjoy the night air as the music made it's way around us and we caught up with each other's lives.
author: Daisy S.

description: Excellent coffee, and  Ernie makes a mean cappuccino an  the staff is always friendly.
author: Geoffrey B.

description:
A North Beach/San Francisco landmark.  

Yes, there will be a long line but it will move fast.  

Nevermind the surly servers behind the counter.  Their unhappiness doesn't need to rub off on you and you only have to tolerate them for a few moments.

Grab a seat when and wherever you can and note that the whipped cream on the sweeter drinks is real whipped cream.  The pastries are fresh and good, too.

The inside can get a little warm but if you can grab one of the very few seats outside, it's primo people-watching, trust me.
author: Craig W.

description: we love this neighborhood cafe, great coffee and pie.
author: Susan S.

description:
Pros: coffee tastes good, place has some character

Cons: only accepts cash, didn't appreciate the service

I ordered a coffee to go and felt like the shorter Asian guy who served me was definitely not friendly. I'm pretty sure that he scolded me for putting the spoon I used to stir my coffee in the wrong place when I was done using it. Maybe I'm being dramatic?  Overall, it's good for coffee, but the little things (service and debit/credit) knock it back to 3 stars.
author: B B.

description:
It is the second time I have been here- first time I just stumbled upon it... and this time I made the effort... SO worth it! 

Parking is such a pain in the a** and I needed more coins to get my full 2 hours... so I stroll down to the glorious Cafe Trieste after parking and order my (amazing) latte, and after getting my change in quarters I filled the meter while he made my coffee.. luckily he was a very understanding barista. Plus the city is just cool like that... 
I brought my computer back with me and settled into a table by the window- gorgeous sunshine beaming on my legs as I listened to the 3 piece band in the back of the cafe play their accordion and other folk instruments. A little loud for my liking, but a nice addition to a saturday morning. Everyone gave them a little golf clap after every number and then continued on with their reading or drinking.. Exactly what I was looking for on a saturday morning. Thank you Cafe Trieste... just like Schwarzenegger- Ill be back..
author: Courtney M.

description:
This place rocks the friggin' house. I've gotta say that I didn't really know what North Beach was really about, but this place gave me a pretty good idea tonight. I spend most of my time in SF in the Financial, Duboce Triangle, and Mission district areas and this Caffe Trieste was a warm welcome to North Beach.

From the endless pastry/food selections to the excellent coffee and live music (every Wednesday night courtesy of Café Americain), this place was an all-out great experience. It seemed like everybody was there to get to know each other, not divide up in groups as happens frequently between hipsters in the Mission.

Could not recommend enough.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Ohhh my heavens, the coffee here is good!!  I am a coffee addict - as in, when I visited Seattle last year I had 5 cups/day just to try every single tiny coffee shop I could get my hands on in Seattle (shoot, gotta drink coffee when you're in the coffee capital of the US, amen?!).

Anyways, Cafe Trieste's roast is just vibrant and dark and delicious.  One of the best I've had in the city - LOVED it!  I easily, HAPPILY give this place 5 stars...!
author: Angela C.

description:
I seriously love their coffee. From the local feel; the tiny indoor and outdoor cafe tables and seats; the yummy snacks; and the REAL DEAL baristas that make your order from scratch, this place is honestly as good as it gets. 

What to order: 
I highly suggest an iced or hot caffee mocha or the almond fantasia (OMG DEELISH!) iced. I apologize in advance if I am butchering the names as I swear to you I cannot PRONOUNCE half of the items on their menu. Which, by the way, is how you KNOW this place is legit--when you can't pronounce any of the of italian words on the menu board -_-. 

Anywho, please add this place to your cafes to place a visit to on a beautiful SF day :). I promise you will be pleased. 

Oh, and another up to this is if you feel like you've just consumed a boat load of calories from your caffeinated beverage of choice, just take your hyper self to the top of the hill and hike the steps to Coit Tower. It's just walking distance away ;).
author: Jasmin W.

description: Usually my boyfriend will get an iced mocha to-go for me or let me sip off of his.  They make those really good!  Recently though I went inside, which I've only done a handful of times.   Got a grande cappuccino, added sugar and sprinkled some cinnamon on top.  Mmmm very delicious.  Just that cup alone really made me want to get another one soon.
author: Paige W.

description: The original Cafe Trieste is a classic from which I measure all other coffee shops. I also have a low grade dairy allergy and since I've long switched to black coffee, the dearth of soy, almond, or rice milk choices don't really concern me. Either does having a little cash to pay for my caffeine stash. I still love the neighbourhood, watching interesting people, making a space in the crowd, and listening to the music.
author: Eric B.

description:
Best Cappuccino in the city.   No question about it.
Coffee - ok.  Everything else - ok.  Have I mentioned the Cappuccino?  Try it.

Great atmosphere.  Expect to wait 5-10 minutes in line to order.  Expect not to have anywhere to sit.  Take it for what it is.  Great place despite these factors.
author: Shawn M.

description: I'm surprised there are some cute young people working at this place now, especially in the evenings. I've lived in North Beach for a decade and I recently started going back to Trieste because the coffee is awesome. FYI, greasy pizza and a lot of pastries with nuts and chocolate etc.
author: Avram K.

description:
One of my best friends is so damn addicted to Cafre Trieste that he goes EVERY DAY.  Seriously, he gets parking tickets just to grab Africanos here.

I won't go that far, but I highly recommend the Africano.  Get it.  No other cafe can make this drink the way they do here.
author: Jin D.

description: Objectively speaking, my father and I have very different sets of taste.  He was right about Trieste though, an old relic from the North Beach Beat era that prides itself in aromatic coffee roasts and preserving old-timey frescos while you sip away.  My dad gets a kick out of the old fogies that adorn the walls, while I get a kick out of the shots of Francis Ford Coppola as he wrote the Godfather...so it's a win-win.
author: Michael D.

description:
Famous coffee place that is cashing cowing its brand.

My pooch and I checked out this place after seeing Mario Batali down a coffee fantasia on TV.  Looked interesting and we found an open table.  25 minutes later after waiting for 3 people to get their coffee, I finally sat down with my fantasia (espresso, almond syrup and cocoa powder). 

Drink was good but service was chaotic. While waiting a ridiculous amount of time to just order, it was frustrating to have   "regulars" cut the line upfront to pay which then spawned this flurry of chaotic activity each time. The staff got orders confused. Some people pay up when they order while others pay afterward. The same guy bussing tables, was toasting bagels without washing his hands.

I think their service sucks because it can. As long as the Marios of the world stop by, why try?
author: Kim W.

description:
Highly overrated.  So, it's a famous place.  Paul Kantner  from Jefferson Airplane is sitting outside every morning at 9am--he's in his chair, with his glasses on-- usually reading and wearing black-- with a grouchy look on his face... He obviously wants to be left alone, but why put your chair at the street corner and stick out like a sore thumb if you want to act grumpy?  Maybe if he wore a green Grinch costume - at least I would enjoy the experience when I walk past him.

And the barristas at Caffe Trieste--they are unfriendly, rushed, seem SO irked that they have to help you-- and basically--do the minimum to keep the line moving.  They don't have to say good morning or be friendly to new customers, or smile-- because the place is just SO DARN FAMOUS.  No wonder why Paul likes this cafe - the workers there act just like him. 

The coffee is just so - so, and that's being kind.  Peets Coffee is far better. Their only saving grace in my opinion--is that the people that hang out there are an interesting bunch and it's spacious enough to find a seat.   But Meh...I'm actively looking for a better place for my morning cup o' joe...
author: Rosalie V.

description:
Just happened upon this gem while walking through North Beach and really needing some coffee.  I knew right when I walked in and saw the crowd of regulars having their morning coffee and pastry I was in the right place.  The barista was greeting many customers by name and was very efficient.

The espresso is strong and delicious.  I took mine outside and enjoyed it at one of the three tables they have.  Definitely coming back.  Good espresso is hard to find and this place definitely isn't a tourist trap like some in the area can be.
author: Lisa K.

description:
They are not lying about the "superb coffee" bit. Enjoyed the best caffe latte of my life yesterday during my first visit here. Luckily a friend of a friend works in North Beach and needed a ride to work, giving us a reason to swing by this place for some coifffeee. My latte came in a pilsner glass and, other than its warm temperature, could have easily passed for a coffee milksteak. I mean shake. 

It was crowded and the service was a little rough around the edges, but with all of the tourists day in and day out, it's understandable.

Go here for some of the best coffee in your life.
author: Leigh W.

description: Very good, but not the best cafe in the area in my book. I loved the feel of the cafe though. The pastries and the coffee were good. There were seats outside, which was very nice. It made for a very peaceful cup of coffee
author: Mary W.

description: Yummy cookies and tea. I'm a fan. They also have a jukebox so I'm pretty much sold on this place.
author: Amy J.

description: Ok, so the coffee was typical..it would have scored better if it was organic (coffee is the number one sprayed crop in the World I read, yikes!) and it was twice as expensive as other little shops.  BUT, the HILARIOUS story to follow is why I have to bump up from a 3.5 to a solid 4. Allow me to explain=) Hubby and I go in last minute after we ate a crappy dinner at the Stinking Rose (we needed a good laugh!) We come across this platinum blonde, frizzy haired old rocker dude. A true SF veteran, spending his nights tending coffee bar. Sounds like a cool dude, no? Great guess because he was. He served us a cup of coffee, even though they were closed. My husband then asked this man (who is obviously in a hurry to go home) if he knew where to get good pie, this barista apparently misheard what he said because he starts pointing to the homeless guys across the street and says, "Down that alley I'm guessing"....UM...?? Took us a second to realize this guy thought we were asking for POT. LMFAO!!!!!!!!! BWHAUAHAHAHA! We explained pot wasn't on our list for the evening unfortunately, but pie would be a good start=) Thanks for the funny story Sir, we applaud you!
author: Prescila B.

description:
Me and my chums happened to stumble across this place after getting off  at the wrong stop on a tram. The amount of local Italians hanging out outside chatting and smoking cigars really attracted us. The decor and vibe of this joint was quite vintage. Old frames hung on the wall, older men playing chess, and the restroom that was lit by a lone bulb stood out like a sore thumb, in a good way of course. I had myself an espresso and took in the city, one breath at a time. 

Apparently the area was a place where Kerouac and other Beat movement writers came to hang out. Francis Ford Coppola even adapted one of the greatest films of all time, The Godfather, in this very location! I knew this place had a rich history, but didn't expect that history had been made at this very spot! I'll definitely come back, with a new perspective and hopefully be inspired to make a little history of my own!
author: Randolph L.

description:
I'm not a fan of coffee, but this place was okay. Since it was on one of the to-do list for SF, I decided to try it. Great customer service, a lot of regulars.

I ordered a Iced Mocha and it was pretty decent. not too creamy, not too watery.
author: Sara D.

description:
Today, there are two cannoli left and I am able to obtain one.  
On the surface it looks pretty stale.  The maraschino cherries have a faded, almost translucent look to them which turns me off.  How long does a cherry have to sit for it to take on that color and heinous appearance?  

Their San Jose cafe informed me that someone else makes their cannoli.  At the North Beach cafe I discovered the staff were "men of few words" so I didn't bother to ask.  The cherries are stuffed in each end, powdered sugar is on the shell and the cream is very thick and tastes pretty good with an almond extract taste to it.  

There are "some" chocolate chips, the shell is not soggy but is soft and flimsy.  This isn't surprising as the stale cherries alerted me to the fact that this pastry was likely made many hours ago.  I toss the shell and eat the cream.  

There is no citrus taste but the cream seems tastier and slightly more interesting than Greco's.  Additionally, I curb the stale formaldehyde soaked cherries.
