The cream is dense and heavy, with almost a pasty quality.  It is about as smooth as Greco's and noticeably smoother than Cavalli's.  It is the sweetest cannolo I've tasted today and definitely pushing my upper limits of acceptable sweetness.
author: David E.

description: Great coffee but the fat, ugly, brunette  working the counter this morning has the worst attitude. She is definitely giving Caffe Trieste an awful reputation so I wouldn't bother leaving a tip.
author: Mike W.

description:
Loud, chaotic, full of local color and tainted by the sweet smell of marijuana smoke pouring in from the locals sitting right outside the door, Cafe Trieste is a very North Beach experience.  

The coffee's decent (I always order a cafe mocha, which is tasty), the tantalizing choice of baked goods are reasonably priced and appease the sweet tooth sufficiently, and if you can actually find a place to sit down because a local has pried him or herself off of one, consider yourself in for some great people-watching!

Now, if only I could get a smile from the barristas...*sigh*  They are at best curt, and you always feel like you're taking too long to order and pay for their liking.  You know, like perhaps they are doing you some kind of favor by letting you buy coffee from them?  I also notice that if they spill a little bit down the side of my coffee glass, they don't generally make an attempt to wipe it off before my fingers get sticky...it's little things like that that make Cafe Trieste one place that I don't always have the stomach for!  The one thing I can't blame them for is the fact that parking nearby is a cruel joke...but that does mean that I generally don't come here unless I first ate dinner nearby, and wouldn't ever attempt to come here with more than a few friends, since seating is at a premium!

Still, if you're looking for an interesting place to start writing your first great San Francisco novel, I can't think of a better location to park one's behind and await inspiration...
author: Amy L.

description:
Very awesome Cafe Mocha ($3.25)!!  I don't quite know how to judge coffee but I know that when something tastes good to my taste buds, then it must mean something!  After my first sip, I noticed that it was more bitter than I prefer so I was really tempted to add sugar but I didn't.  I kept on drinking and it just kept getting better!!  Who knew coffee could do that?  For some magical reason, the bitterness went away and I could really taste the richness and depth of the coffee beans.

I didn't notice any particular bad attitudes or service while I was there.  In fact, I noticed the barista chatting it up with a random guy in line about the Mystery Spot in Santa Cruz.  Perhaps I didn't go during an overly crowded time when tensions might be higher.  I did notice that the place has a slightly dirty feel.... with over flowing garbage cans... that sort of thing.  So I would definitely come back for coffee and not really for any type of lounging.  This place is right around the corner from Buster's which made for a perfect combination---cheesesteak and coffee.  Okay, not so much.
author: Shannon L.

description: GREAT COFFEE. Despite the fact that it's annoyingly hip and the promise land for tourists, the coffee is great, the staff is friendly, and I feel very happy to know it's down the street...It's a treat!
author: Hm M.

description:
Hey Goomba!...I'm walkin' here, I'm walkin' here.

If you can get a seat here, well, good for eff-ing you...I never get that kind of luck here because the eccentric regulars park themselves here on a permanent basis, I imagine. I come in here to get a latte ($3.25 for a cup even though the wall menu says $2.85...hmmm) and then I usually stroll over to Washington Square Park since it takes that amount of time to let it cool anyway.

You come here for the thick atmosphere. It epitomizes North Beach more than the tongue-dangling crapfest at Steps of Rome. The barista is even surly in that "Gee, I coulda been Martin Scorsese"-kind of way. None of the expanding chain of Caffe Triestes in the city can approach it for the thick paisano vibe you get here. It's small and crowded but worthy of a stop on a North Beach stroll.

COFFEE - 4 stars...nice, strong cup for ya's
AMBIANCE - 5 stars...crowded for sure, but it feels like North Beach, goomba
SERVICE - 3 stars...kinda rude, but I guess attitude comes with atmosphere
TOTAL - 4 stars...I'm goin' to the mattresses if I rate it any less.
author: Ed U.

description:
My boyfriend and I popped into Caffe Trieste to do some work and grab some coffee and apparently everyone else in the area had the same idea! It was mid-afternoon and the place was still fairly crowded... which is probably a GOOD sign! The coffee was good, the seating was pretty good for the space and they have free wi-fi to get some work done (ask the barstaff for the code)! I think my favorite part of the place is the neighborhood though -- smack dab in the heart of North Beach, you can't help but want to walk around the area after grabbing a coffee for the road!

Note: Street parking sucks, but there is some free, 2 hour parking on the side streets if you get lucky.
author: Shannon E.

description:
My introduction to Caffe Trieste began during a teen obsession with Josh Hartnett. There is a scene in 40 Days and 40 Nights where he is sitting inside Trieste; my friend and I were on a mission to find every place that he had been in the movie and visit it... hmm sounds a little weird now that I look back. Anyway, Caffe Trieste is the only place that we kept returning to, not for Josh but for the coffee and the atmosphere.

Trieste is located on a small street right off of Columbus - In the heart of North Beach. It's a great place to grab a cappuccino (my drink of choice at Trieste) and relax out on the sidewalk, where you can enjoy the very diverse and interesting crowd that frequents this place. 

Definitely worth stopping by if you are in the North Beach area.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Good coffee, but I wish they would just put the cream cheese on the bagel instead of the little airplane like packets they give you. And they only give you one, which is barely enough to spread on one side. But I did like that they salted and peppered the tomatoes.
Nice staff too. Definitely a regulars spot
author: Nicole C.

description: This place was VERY overpriced! Tourist trap! The cashier over charged us...$15 for a coffee and three small pastries, then waits for a tip. They are cash only, so they don't have to report the overcharging on their taxes.
author: Angela C.

description: The place is sort of dark and dingy. The coffee is sort of subpar and I'm not sure what there is to like about this place. The pastries look like grocery store style pastries with tons of sugar.
author: Ali B.

description: My grandparents regularly frequented Cafe Trieste well before the chain coffee houses emerged.  It's a favorite place of mine when I am meeting someone in the afternoon. Particularly mid week- it's not too busy and my out of towner family, friends and business folk love it! As well they should. It's old school SF.  When I'm in North Beach - I always stop in for a coffee or a coffee and Italian pastry. If it's crazy busy - I take it to go.  The coffee is delicious and has stood up over the years. Great, authentic, SF beatnik vibe and North Beach Italian all in one shot. I hope the franchise concept works for them - it's a fiddly transition.  Love the flagship store!
author: KT T.

description:
I went here after it was recommended to me by fellow locals.

Like always, I get a mocha where ever I go.

This was the quickest cup of coffee I ever had besides going to Mc Donalds. 

From order to pickup was under two minutes.

The mocha came in a water glass.

It didn't have much taste and it appears that they used powdered chocolate which kept settling to the bottom instead of real melted chocolate like every other boutique cafe so I had to keep stirring it before shipping.

Not sure how they cycle through all the food that they had on the counter. I did not get anything to eat as it looked stale even though it may not be.


Will I go again? Maybe if I'm in the area.
author: Evan W.

description: Cute coffee spot off the main road...unfortunately my coffee was burnt (as were my parents) but nice, chilled vibe.
author: Mellie J.

description: My boyfriend really wanted to come here because some famous dude wrote a book here or something. Jack Kerouac? I'm still not sure. Anyway, the surly barista will make you an amazing cappuccino and Irish coffee if you ask nicely and pay in cash. Otherwise he will make you feel like shit with his cuttingly witty sarcasm and shame you for being a capitalist. Just kidding. On an unrelated note, I saw Albert Einstein's doppelganger reading the paper and sipping some joe here.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Just moved up the street! As a total coffee snob....The coffee is amazing! 
My usual order is a small size latte with 2 shots (Africano). Coffee is the perfect mix of strong, creamy deliciousness... My only complaint is that they do not have NF milk. Cute atmosphere that is very North Beach. Hate to say this for fear of the lines getting longer but.... It's definitively a "must try"!!
author: Gina H.

description: This was one of our Stops on our North Beach Crawl.. We stopped to enjoy the Swing Band that was holding a jam session on the Sidewalk outside of the Caffe. They were getting down and there was a huge crowd Hooting and Hollering.
author: Eugene L.

description: Great neighborhood coffee shop! Cappuccino was great, the quiche was okay. Pastries looked very fresh. The vibe in this coffee shop was cozy and relaxed.
author: Lauren G.

description: I absolutely love this place, even if they've made themselves a small chain around the city and other parts of the Bay Area. It's too bad they take cash only and rarely have open tables, but they do coffee right. This location also has an annex retail store attached for your coffee-fixin' goods, like those cute mugs they they serve in.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I will preface this by saying I am biased.

No I did not live in Little Italy in NYC, but I did live in the North End of Boston long enough to get free produce from the little Italian man down the street who liked to make dirty comments about my boobs.

I never felt that North Beach here felt as authentic as home.  A cannoli should be $1.50 at most and should NOT have marichino (sp?) cherries on the ends.   I've uploaded a pic where I look like I am threatening to throw a forkful of cannoli at my roommate's face.  

Three stars for the espresso though.
author: Jen I.

description:
Not the best cappucino in town, but it definitely has some good 'sphere goin on. The cookies are all right, too. nothing to write home about. The guy in the front making drinks isn't known for his superb customer service, but he keeps it real.

Cool knowing that the likes of Coppola have hung out here for inspiration.  Good place to check out, check off and move on. 

FYI - CASH ONLY.
author: Marie S.

description:
Caffe Trieste is what all those hipster SF coffee places (you know who you are) want to be when they grow up.  Think about it.  Back in the 50s and 60s beatniks and writers and poets hung out and drank espresso there, which was revolutionary to SF and the entire west coast at the time.  And beatniks were the hipsters of their day.  60 years later this place is still going strong, and I'm pretty sure that some of the locals  I see when I stop in on my way to work have been coming there every morning since the place opened.  The people who work there are a little gruff, but when they realize that you are not a tourist who read about it in Lonely Planet San Francisco, they are nice and helpful, and always willing to let you know what pastries are the best that day. 

And they serve their espresso strong, just the way I like it.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Superb as advertised. Popular cafe spot in North Beach, good place to sit back, relax, or if not relaxing, to get work done (when it's not busy of course, which is rare). Had two servings of drinks, not much of an espresso-esque drinker, but their stuff were pretty good. Had a Caffe Mocha, and after that a pot of Earl Grey tea. This place is definitely one of those places I would want to go back to again just to try the rest of their Espresso menu alone. 

Don't worry they also have pastries and caters pizza from nearby Golden Boy's Pizza on Green to accommodate your beverage.
author: Ethan T.

description: The espresso here is wonderful, the espresso grande and a rugelach are my favorite combination.  A wonderful afternoon boost when a long day begins to lag.  Bustling, busy, but still relaxing.  Whether sitting by the window, or at an outside table, a pleasant place to pause. Bring a friend and talk for a while.
author: BL W.

description:
Legendary. I come here for the lattes, to catch up on the local gossip (it's North Beach 'Cheers'- they know all the clients & crazies and what they are up to), to get updates on the latest conspiracy theories, and to find out why the Giants lost (see previous comment on conspiracy theories).
This is where you come for caffeine and education.
Also, I love it when tourists duck in here to get out of the rain, enjoy a latte, flip open their guidebooks, and smile when they realize they've ducked into a landmark.
author: Johanna S.

description: This place is as San Francisco as it gets.  With all the history of the greats who used to hang here, you can relive those memories by all the photographs hanging on the Caffe Trieste walls.  The coffee is also pretty darn tasty -- I had a nonfat latte, which was delicious.  The clientele ranges from SF locals to tourists -- something for everyone!
author: Mel G.

description: Great coffee and very friendly service. I had a coffee to go, but the decor inside was nice and there was a guy (customer) playing guitar, so it seems like a nice place to stop and take your time too.
author: Jack C.

description:
I would rather get a stick in the eye  from a fallen branch in Washington Park swung by a wino, than get served an overrated cup of coffee by one of the rude A-holes working behind the counter at this place.  

I'm a coffeehouse kinda guy, but I'm not masochistic enough to pay for their abuse or their dirty tables.

There are other places in the neighborhood more deserving of my hard earned money.  

Hey Trieste baristas!  Piss-off!

Okay, maybe I was too harsh on my previous review.

After years of self-imposed avoidance, I decided to give it another chance. The baristas aren't necessarily any friendlier, but you just can't beat that North Beach bohemian ambiance. As the neighborhood burns to the ground to make room for luxury condos, we've got to protect what's left of the glorious past. Long live Caffe Trieste!
author: Charlie B.

description:
They don't have soy milk.


I'm lactose intolerant jerks!!



The tea was good.
author: Shel Z.

description: Just espresso this morning, people watching.  Great local vibe. I'm a tourist here so sitting with locals listening to their life woes. I drink a lot of espresso and their's is a bit more bitter than most.
author: Rob D.

description: I mean, to be in business for this long I would assume they would need to be doing something right! I went there twice in one day! People that work there are great and the clientele are great people! Will be back as soon as I move to the Bay Area
author: Elijah H.

description:
I am a coffee shop junkie. It's literally around my corner. A review was due!

When I moved to SF, I was dreaming of a place where I could hear the birds in the morning, see the bay on my way to work, and have cafes all around me. This specific Caffe Trieste appeared in many of the movies I rented before moving, dreaming of a SF lifestyle. And I couldn't believe it when I got a place just a block from it. I felt like I was living the dream.....until I went there for the first time and though 'OMG'!.....to finally realize that I DO live the dream! :-)

Like many people have said, it's not the place for the coffee snob - when it comes to COFFEE there are better places in SF. And you do have to run into lots of tourists, as it's a SF landmark. When I first moved from SoCal I felt unsafe and overwhelmed by the local characters who were always in the place. Then there was the service - which I am ALL about. I wondered what was wrong with those people that seemed like they hated their lives and couldn't even look at  me in the eyes and acknowledge my order? Why would I go to a place to be treated like that, to be surrounded by people that looked 'crazy' and to have a mediocre coffee?!?!

Then it was the day before my birthday. I walked by it and thought it would be a good idea to have an iced coffee before going home, so I stopped by. I mentioned casually that it was my birthday. All of a sudden I got the barista's attention, who decided I needed to have some wine to celebrate my big day, and I then I saw myself sitting outside, with a nice glass of white wine in my hands, surrounded by my new friends, laughing until my cheeks hurt,  contemplating a nice warm sunny afternoon in my neighborhood, just hanging out and appreciating my new life in SF! My Big day couldn't have had a better start.

Rabah and Hakim are now special people I call my friends. The ones that seemed so hostile, now are the sweetest people in the world! Did they change? Nope! I was the one who changed the way I looked at them. I now can SEE them! They are the nicest people, with a 'keepin-it-real' attitude. I always bring my friends here. I also bring dates - unadvised - to see how they react to such a peculiar place. And Caffe Trieste, with it's eclectic clientele, historic ambiance, old songs, and REAL people, became an extension of my home! I DO live the dream!!! :-)
author: Simone W.

description: I live a few blocks from cafe Trieste and have tried it a few times only to be disappointed every time! This last time I visited will be my last, unfortunately. I can put up with employes having no personality and so-so coffee, but my last visit I ordered a latte and the guy used already steamed milk and shots he'd pulled who knows how long before! Needless to say it was subpar and lukewarm at most. I'm not one to make a scene so I left my completely full glass and won't be back. What a waste of money. You'll have better luck around the corner at cafe Greco on Columbus. Sad, I really wanted to like this place.
author: Abigail L.

description:
This is not the place to go if you are barely emerging in the San Francisco scene. Actually, most Italian establishments, and particularly North Beach, is a neighborhood to avoid in that sense.

The staff here is as friendly as the taxi drivers honking at pedalists and wheelchair-bound homeless men alike, as they incoherently process the orders of each customer at an inhuman pace and present a confusing and inconsistent menu. The clientele is equally horrid. I stood behind a woman in line and suddenly an older woman who looked like the type who collects Disney figurines said, "Excuse me, move to the side. This is how we do things around here." I felt alienated and belittled.

I like the pastries. It's a little sickening to see flies swarming atop the cookies, however. I suggest visiting the Caffe Trieste in San Jose for a much more pleasant experience, with more room to breathe and a friendlier staff.
author: Peter H.

description:
Get an espresso or two or three - $2.30 a shot
sit outside and people watch all the colorful flavors of north beach

Be prepared to order - the baristas here don't shower customer service, if you hesitate on your order he'll give you attitude and skip to the next person in line :)
author: Noah P.

description: I have to give it five stars.   The place looked kinda sketchy from the outside. One guy sitting at an outside table, looking like he was so far gone he never came back from a 60's acid trip. A few more were on equally far off places inside. Upon getting to the front door, one of the baristas came out and handed a grumpy older gentleman a fiver and told him not to be rude to the customers. I gathered he's a regular. Joe, I think she called him. Inside delightfully tacky with real life in pictures on all the walls. The staff was very nice, polite and helpful. The selection of sweet treats amazing. I personally got a caffe mocha that was the best I've had, served in an Irish coffee mug. You could see the layers topped with just a dab of whipped cream. Delicious. Upon leaving I had to get one to go. Not quite as good, it takes the whole experience to truly enjoy. Would recommend whole heartedly.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Decided to try a different North Beach cafe for dessert, (we usually go to Cafe Greco.)
This place is a bit more divey inside than i expected, but i liked my dessert. My BF's wasn't very good though. Also, the guys behind the counter couldn't even tell us what some of the desserts were. I realize they aren't house made, but really, you should know what you're serving. 
I had what they told me was Boston cream pie. It kind of was, but not exactly. It was pretty good, but i probably won't be returning.
author: Amanda G.

description:
There aren't too many places in SF I can get an espresso that tastes as good if not better than the ones I make with my trusty moka pot, but at Caffe Trieste, I am always happy! First off, they serve all their coffee by default in ceramic, second, they take pride in their coffee, and third, it always tastes good. I like how they have the Espresso Grande on their wall menu, which is 4 shots of espresso. It's so good it goes down like water!

You should also try their pizza at lunch. It's simple and not made on the spot, but they crispify them in their grill and its so scrumptious. Also, for breakfast, despite how busy they were, they accommodated my friend and I and custom made croissant sandwiches grilled with cheese, and ham for my friend! 

The opera on saturdays are stunning. It's also nice to see families with kids come out to enjoy this little piece of Italian/American culture!
author: Janel A.

description: I love this place. If your are not a local, their brew is worth driving out of the way.  You will stop in your rush and a take the time to "smell the coffee". And if you are lucky enough to be  there when live music, then you will enjoy a most memorable  experience. Don't expect fancy. This part of the Italian charm.
author: JMichael G.

description: Poor experience. Ordered a house salad that turned out to be soggy browning iceberg lettuce. The cashier was harried and rather rude. With all the cafes in the area, it's not worth going to Caffe Trieste.
author: Joe N.

description: Bad service and food. Atmosphere is ok but the coffee is pretty good. Bottom line, ill come back for some coffee to go.
author: O J.

description:
This is a mocha review.  

Best Mocha Ever.   Whenever I'm in San Francisco, I try and come out to Cafe Trieste every day, and drink their mochas.  They use fantastic chocolate, their espresso is great, and their foamed milk is just the right balance of smooth vs. foamy.  It's also not too sweet - more a dark chocolate than a milk chocolate on the sweetness scale.   I've tried to recreate their mocha recipe 100 times, and every now and then I'll try mochas at other cafes just to see if they can compare - and they can't.  This is hands down the best ever.  

A little warning though - there are a couple of other Cafe Trieste's in SF, but it's only the one in North Beach that makes the mochas so good.  I tried the one on Market St. and they unapologetically use a different recipe - using chocolate syrup in there instead of 100% chocolate powder (which is KEY), and they acknowledge that they use completely different recipes.  WHY?  WHY VARY FROM PERFECTION???

Anyways - cafe trieste northbeach has the best mocha ever.
author: Charles G.

description: This is my favorite coffee house in the city. There's a lot of great cafes here (Ritual, Sightglass, Blue Bottle, Four Barrel), but this one beats them all. I started stopping by occasionally in the morning and it didn't take long for the barista to remember my order and have it ready before I got to the register during the morning rush, right as I stepped in the door! Whenever I have come here, I've always felt welcome and this place has been apart of the neighborhood for decades. The coffee is always rich, well-prepared, and delicious as-is with no added cream or sugar. This place is classic to San Francisco and holds a lot of history. It's the best in every way, and although new competitors seem well-equipped, you can't beat the service and quality Caffe Trieste provides.
author: Leigh H.

description:
This place has atmosphere. I mostly remember the folks outside with their dogs. From the cafe you have a view of the park and the church where Marilyn Monroe married Joe Dimagio. 
In side the cafe, you can take your time on your computer, or reading the local newspapers. 
On certain Saturdays, at 1pm the family will sing opera. I've missed it so far, but i am determined to hear them.
author: elizabeth a.

description: Stopped in for a coffee while I was in the neighborhood. I'd climbed Lombard, the Greenwich Steps, The Filbert Steps, and had been walking for a few hours, so coffee was more than necessary. It had a great, old school cafe feel to it and I got to park it outside at one of the little tables and people watch while I re-upped my caffeine. Seemed cozy enough on the inside that I could imagine hanging out with some reading material when the weather is chillier.
author: Renee E.

description:
I realize I was a lot more high strung a year and a half ago when I wrote my first review.

I think my initial change occurred on my trip to England in May. For those who don't know, I have a strong aversion to mayonnaise and had to deal with the fact that it's on or comes with just about everything in the UK. I adapted and I've become a little less high strung since then.

The last time I went to Trieste, I threw a Yelp bitchfest about the lack of outlets, the lack of nonfat milk, the rude service, the poor quality pastries, etc. 

But I've gone back several times and have come to the conclusion that the problem before was me, not the cafe.

There are few outlets in the shop, but it's a place that's more conducive to conversation and reading than computers. The pastries are poor, but apparently their savories are good (never tried them). They may not carry nonfat milk or soy, but the coffee is really good anyway. On top of that, they have the nihilistic history of Jack Kerouac and beat idealism  as well as Gypsy-esque music every Wednesday. 

They create an atmosphere. And if you look past the little things, you can appreciate this place for what it is. It's an old building with a lot of history and old ideals.

I normally order nonfat caps, but I went in this afternoon and ordered a double cap with presumably whole milk. It was rich, frothy, flavorful and exquisitely made. I took it to go and it was hot when I got back to the office to have my homemade blueberry lemon scone (which I made this morning).

It's not the best espresso I've ever had and it's not the best coffee house environment, but I like it in the evenings. I like the history and I can look past little things like soy milk now to appreciate the place for what it is. It feels like old North Beach and if you care that much about soy milk, go to a damn Starbucks or learn to bend a little from time to time.
author: Stephanie H.

description: I saw this place from afar while walking somewhere else, and I could tell it was my kind of place (meaning soo NOT Starbucks). It's no-frills and a bit crowded and I guess you either dig it or you don't. My double-espresso and cheesecake were just awesome and I enjoyed the ambiance very much. My only complaint is that the few seats near the window were coveted and snapped up quickly. After that espresso I could have moved quickly enough to get a window seat, but by I then was already done.
author: Michael P.

description: People come here for the history and atmosphere.   To me, it was just a big room.  Coffee was great but hmm... you can just look at the pictures to get a feel of the place or just walk on by and take a peek.   I didn't feel that I was missing anything.
author: Albert W.

description:
I'm in love with all their baked goods and their selection of loose teas.  Every time I'm in North Beach I have to pay a visit to the Trieste.  Even my snobbiest of coffee-snob friends from Seattle was impressed!

Soak up a little literary history and spend a lovely afternoon here.
author: S J.

description: Love the coffee real north beach all the way,tell them eddie sent you for a deal...
author: Ed M.

description:
There are cute outdoor bistros and romantic cafes lined all along the streets in North Beach, and crowds seem to be mostly locals milling about enjoying their afternoon riposo...perfecto! Caffee Trieste is just this funky little coffee house in the middle of it all. The java is quintessentially Italian, and simple, and amazing. Omg, so good.

Want more info about my coffee experience? 

http://bayareababyblog.blogspot.com/2009/03/in-law-interludes.html
author: Catherine B.

description:
Caffe Trieste is a okay coffee house in North Beach and is also one of the oldest.  It has a very old-fashioned vibe; definitely not a new age coffee shop where it's "organic" this, "gluten-free" that and you're subject to listening to some hipster's iPod playlist.  The employees are not that friendly: they remind me of guys in Brooklyn who will tell you to [four letter word] off.  Felt just like home.

The espresso is alright, expensive for the quality and what you receive.  The pastries and cakes are a waste of calories.  As a pumpkin pie fanatic, I had an impulsive moment and regretted my purchase after the first forkful (it was abandoned thereafter).
author: Dana F.

description: Classic place in North Beach. Amazing espresso and cappuccino in a Beatnik style environment. Prices are reasonable. Just be aware that it is cash only.
author: Ben U.

description:
We saw this place from across the street from where we had lunch and decided to come here for an afternoon caffeine fix. We didn't know anything of the history or background of the place - but we just wanted drinks. Once inside, it felt like the typical hipster cafe. While waiting in line, we decided what we wanted and our order was taken by a grumpy looking fellow and the conversation went down something like this:

friend:   "Can I have a soy mocha latte?"
barista: "No. It's either mocha or latte."
friend:   "Oh, can I get a soy mocha?"
barista: "No. we don't have soy."
friend:   "regular mocha then?"
barista: *stink eye & head nod*

As the line trudged along like a slow factory line, I scooted down and gave my order:

me:        "Can I get an iced cappuccino?"
barista: "Do you want sugar with it?"
me:        "Yes please."
barista:  *hands me cup* "sugar is over there, add it yourself".
me:        (-_-)  *adds sugar*
barista:  "paying together?"
me:        "Yes."
barista:  "No credit cards."
me:         *scrounge for bills*
barista:  *stink eye* "Lids are right there".

I couldn't get over the feeling I was dealing with the soup Nazi from Seinfeld, except in this case it was coffee.  Drinks weren't too bad though and they had a good selection of food.
author: john l.

description:
This cafe is well past its expiry date. The coffee sold besmirches our city's reputation for fine coffee. It lacks body and is bitter from burnt beans (no quality control?). I would rather drink the motor oil in my car. 

There are never enough baristas and those on hand are dour enough to melt a mirror (perhaps because they have to drink their own bilious product?).

The only saving graces are the tin-pan opera on weekends and the wide-eyed tourists that make an easy pick-up.
author: Sempro S.

description:
I finally made my way to this charming little cafe in North Beach yesterday late morning.  The line was 8 people deep, but by the time I reached the front, one of the coveted tables by the window opened up so I grabbed it quick to enjoy my mocha with homemade whipped cream while I leisurely read my paper.  

I loved my surroundings -- you could just feel the San Franciscan history emanating from the walls, old pictures, rickety tables and chairs, hardwood floors, dark wood walls with old-time Italian music playing in the background.  

Lots of regulars come through on a daily basis mixed in with curious tourists who read about this place in books and equally curious locals like me wanting a taste of the old Italian legend that is part of my beloved City.
author: Maile N.

description:
In the high stakes world of coffee places coffee restaurants and coffee cafes (sounds redundant, does it not?), there are many things that can go wrong. At this place not much does. So, in the world of coffee cafes, I really like the attention to detail, the service, the ambiance, and the rest of the menu. 

Old school decor. Do not change a thing.
author: Ben F.

description:
Atmosphere/history = 5 

Coffee = 3.5  (staying true to tradition and only having cow milk doesn't bother me, but sediment and lack of crema gets a little ding from me, even if the flavor of the coffee was good)

Posse of smokers at every single table outside, causing us to sit inside and still getting blasted with their smoke every time a breeze blew = 1

Weird dude next to us making us so uncomfortable that we left = well, that was just weird and uncomfortable, not their fault. Plus, it made for a good story later.
author: Julie S.

description: It's a funky old coffee shop that has probably been on that corner for more years than I have been alive.  The neighborhood is wonderful, all those hills to climb and then carefully descend.  When you get to the bottom of Vallejo, stop and have an espresso.  It's just the way espresso should be, very thick and strong. The ambiance is not your Starbucks, but that's ok for this old part of town.  Enjoy the history. Enjoy the espresso. Live in the moment.
author: Delaine Z.

description: Delicious espresso to recharge me during my exploration of San Fran! Such a neat environment and very friendly staff.
author: Charlie H.

description: Great latte in this place. And environment pleasant and I like it. Especially morning.
author: Unyo N.

description:
So, the 50 year old hippies that inhabit the place in the morning are not really my cup of tea, but I guess are preferable to business suit crowd in starbucks.  And the place is a bit grimy.  But when you walk in, you just get a sense of something special.  And Paul is a North Beach treasure.

The coffee, that's the real attraction, and all the expansion and self promotion has done nothing to diminish the quality that they dish out.  When I say coffee, I mean of course the cappuccino.  Perfectly balanced flavor, an impossible amount of crema, and perfect microfoam.   A jolt of caffeine that doesn't come with all the side effects of too much caffiene.  This is the standard by which all cappuccinos should be judged.
author: craig F.

description:
This was the best cappuccino I've had since I was in Italy. It had a strong, earthy taste like Peet's, but even better. And the white foam streaked with brown espresso on top looked like a work of art. 

But I had to wait in line for half an hour, and the only reason I got a seat was because my friends had gotten there an hour earlier. It's got a nice atmosphere, but you've gotta come right when someone else is leaving if you hope to enjoy it.
author: Nick P.

description:
We ordered a cappuccino, cafe fantasia and a cannoli to share.  they were all very good, although the cafe fantasia (an espresso-chocolate concoction) is a little sweet and heavy.  This place has an old school authentic Italian vibe.  The walls covered with old pictures of the founder, some with famous writers such as with Francis Ford Coppola during the time he would visit and write at Caffe Trieste (apparently the Godfather scripts). The seating was simple, several chairs and tables set up cafeteria style.  

Although it's was quite touristy and was crowded, it beats some of the touristy North Beach cafes by providing good solid coffee and Italian pastries.  Known as aw writer's cafe, I would find it tough to get work done here unless I was able to sit in the corner.  This place was a perfect break from strolling through North Beach.
author: Raana A.

description: A classic. The Baristas might sound like they are yelling at you, but suck it up. They are treating you like family. Wine, beer, coffee, great soundtrack, and the authentic old men of European descent with big personalities are always making noise. Want to feel like a beat poet or revolutionary writer from the 1960s? Spend an afternoon here. You might even meet one. They may very well have free wifi and electrical outlets here, but I'm deducting a star because I was afraid to ask.
author: Kristy L.

description: Best ever.  Not only terrific cappuccino but we got some pan pizza to tide us over before dinner and that pan pizza was pretty much the best thing we ate the entire time we were in San Fran! Love coming here.  So much history.  So much interesting people-watching.  Great place.
author: Kathryn G.

description:
We love this place and have to go back!!  It's packed all the time, which says a lot for them!!  We'd never really ventured through North Beach and decided to make a day of it.  First thing we found is the shops do NOT open until after noon, so we dropped in for a cup of their much-talked about coffee and weren't disappointed.  There's a great vibe to the place, whether you're having your coffee inside or out.  

Don't forget to visit their store next door to take some coffee home with you, but make sure you pack it in your carry-on...you don't want it to disappear!
author: H I.

description:
Great old school North Beach spot. The drinks are amazing, the atmosphere is, well, perfectly North Beach. (and I don't mean shitty broadway NB) Everything has been said good about this place already. 

My only complaint is that they don't have soy milk as an option. That is one behind the times aspect of the cafe that is not so much charming as it is a reason not to go there because milk makes me sick. :(
author: Dani O.

description: Loved the Caffe Trieste that used to be located at downtown San Jose. I was pretty excited to find one in SF. However waiting in line then being ignored for 10 minutes once I was at the counter. Didn't know if it was racially motivated but from the reviews it looks like they give preferential treatment to regulars. Now I see why they had to sell off their SJ cafe.
author: Calvin B.

description: This place is certainly a hub in North Beach. It draws in the tourists, hipsters, old italian men, faded beatniks, yuppies w/ strollers, hippies, and anyone else who appreciates good coffee! Yes, the line is long and slow, so don't try to make this a quick stop when you're running late for work. Come early on a weekend and enjoy your time in line--there's plenty of people watching here and the cafe is filled with fun photos and knick-knacks. I've been underwhelmed by the baked goods or other food, but the coffee really is outstanding. My espresso drinks are always piping hot with the perfect milk-coffee ratios. And when I order drip coffee, they always ask if I want milk--and then add just a splash of freshly steamed milk--so much more delicious than stirring in cold half-and-half!
author: Alison S.

description: The mocha coffee with REAL whipped cream with the ambiance of Vallejo St is a reason to visit San Francisco... walk around the corner to Stella Bakery for a cream puff.
author: Jim C.

description: Eh, a coffee place.  The dessert was not very good.  The pizza was just chilling out there, it looked really old.  The cappuccino was yummy though!
author: Jen F.

description:
Got an a smooth latte here yesterday on a beautiful weekend afternoon. 

1) latte was already brewed, and milk already steamed before i'd ordered. the place was bustling so it's doubtful that it had been sitting around long but still kind of disappointing

2) there appears to be a charge for getting a latte to go. 

$2.85 on the menu, $3.30 for me out the door. i'm totally ok with paying extra for disposable cups (b/c they're evil and we should minimize usage anyway) but it wasn't clearly noted (although my over-the-sholder reading friend says she saw the sign in the cafe...so maybe i'm just blind).

I'd go back again. I'd love to sit and enjoy the cafe experience - it seems like most patrons were there to chill.

The staff does seem like they get tired of the stream of tourists so I wouldn't expect a very warm friendly greeting from any of them.
author: aileen c.

description:
I read the Yelps here and made my way via GPS to this supposed coffee landmark in the city to get high on life before an engagement party on Russian Hill.

I'm a big espresso fan and have become accustomed to a certain quality level in the shots pulled by the barista.  Stumptown coffee is the standard bearer for me whether I'm in Italy or the West Coast.  

I felt I got robbed on North Beach.  My rental Chevy Malibu risked life and passenger door to park itself in an illegal spot in the densely packed surrounding neighborhood so that I could say with great satisfaction "I've been there".

It's more like "wtf lesson learned".  The so-called barista behind the counter vibed quik-e-mart operator more so than espresso mecca man.  My shots got served in a freakin' paper cup.  The color and smell of the pull itself had qualities no different than those at SBUX.  In those desperate times I get "un cafe" at the mega corp chain, I don't even dare to look into the cup for fear of the gag reflex factor.  

At least at SBUX, they put a lid on it.  If you SF Yelpers think this is good coffee, you don't know good coffee.  Bo knows good coffee.  So do I and this ain't it.
author: CY K.

description:
On the side, I teach photography class and one of my student wanted to meet here to do our Little Italy walk and I was really happy because it's one of my favorite San Francisco find.

I've always had this theory that people who have good taste in food or real good coffee are natural born creative types. This student has the technical down on how to use his camera and just need coaching on the creative side. He asks all the right questions and when I give him my thoughts he seems to implement them quite easily.

He gets an A+ for making my day easy and so wonderfully caffeinated :).
author: Brandon M.

description: The point: Historically & culturally relevant with good coffee. Service sometimes leaves much to be desired, hence the 4-star rating instead of 5. Be aware that it is cash only.
author: Becca M.

description:
Tall soy 2 pump vanilla lattes need not apply here.  

This place serves fantastic coffee in it's most basic form.  Caffe Trieste is conveniently located just off Columbus Street. If you like coffee in it's basic form, then this is the place for you. Great atmosphere, coffee, people and all around good place.  Also, if you like to people watch then you'll certainly have more than a few to watch.  Characters also come with the coffee.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Cafe Disrespect

House of Swill

I asked a regular once why he came back to Trieste day after day.  He answered me with just one word:

"Masochism"

People LOVE to go here for the notoriously bad service and for the attitude.  It's part of the Trieste experience.

I've nicknamed this place many things over the years, but you have to experience it to believe it.

I don't remember what the coffee tastes like because it's been so long since my last disappointing cup of overrated hot brown water.

+1 for a few great staff members and for the regular neighborhood peeps that hang out there.

For those of you who think your Yelp review of Trieste will make one iota of difference.  Forget it.  Give up.  This joint will be around long after we're all turned to dust or ash.
author: Justin C.

description:
Italian coffee?  Heck yes!  This coffee shop IS the business...so is their Caffe Fantasia ($4).  It's a little pricey for a cup of coffee but I wanted something different.  Something you can't get at your local coffee shop.  Just by the name of it, Caffe Fantasia, ya already know what you're in for.  To my tasting, there was a hint of almond, chocolate and espresso.  Yup, yup...ALMOND.  I LOVE almond-flavored anything!  Don't forget to mix it with a spoon.  Its what makes the coffee ridiculously delicious....when all the flavors intertwine!  It was like coffee from heaven.  Seriously.  My little brother ordered the Hot Chocolate.  It tasted like Caffe Fantasia but without the espresso!  The shop also had different italian pastries.  I got the decorated strawberry cookie.  So cute!

This place is SO Italian.  And I'm talking about the ambiance.  Reminded me of Bucca De Beppo where picture frames covered the entire wall.  On a Sunday afternoon, the place was packed as well as the line being ridiculously long.  It was worth the wait.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Kanani N.

description:
Guy in line behind me: Don't you feel inspired?  Like you could write something great by just BEING here? 

Well, no, I don't.  I hate myself for going here, ever.  The bathroom reminds me of a neighborhood job I used to hold circa 2001.  Where has life gone since then?  The only good thing about this place is the customer dressed like a medieval duke or a pirate.
author: new b.

description:
kinda sad i didn't actually get anything that this place is known for. i did though get a root beer. don't mind the look they give you for just walking in, getting a root beer and walking out. whelp. 
four stars because i didn't really think the vibe walking in there was that great.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
I know, I know, this place is supposed to be awesome. And maybe that I think it's not is more my fault than Trieste's fault. But the first time I came here, I felt like the place was kinda dirty (flies buzzing around). That was a few years ago. The second time I came was this morning. No soy milk (yeah, they're probably trying to ward the hippies/yuppies off, whatever, I just like the taste better). I got a regular latte instead. It was "meh." Also I didn't feel entirely welcome here for some reason.

I think my dislike of this place is more intangible though. Just not my style for some reason.
author: Stu M.

description: Great neighborhood cafe!  I enjoyed my cappuccino here immensely .  Next door you can buy fresh roasted coffee beans- I bought a pound of the Dark French Supreme to take home.  :)
author: Kat S.

description: Great atmosphere, cool crowd and real italian capuccino. I love this place.
author: Gio S.

description: I bought a half pound of their Italian Roast from here for a little less than $8.  Really smooth yet full bodied.  I would definitely come back again when it's time to reboost.
author: Christine N.

description:
Stumbled across this North Beach landmark, and was immediately drawn in. I'm a huge espresso fan and this was the best I've ever had and I've had a lot of espresso form a lot of places....

I loved the romantic antiquity of the place, its atmosphere screams of arty types, lovers in love and the average guy.... you can feel the ambiance, the history, the heart of North Beach here.

Best of the Best...
author: Me Y.

description:
There are a lot of reasons to hang-out at the Caffe Trieste, and they don't always have anything to do with espresso or coffee.

Among the denizens there are several serious artists, writers, and iconoclasts. Yes, there are a few has-beens, several wannabes and, alas, a good number of lunatics. I'd call that "local color." I affectionately think of them as the "Extra-Triestreans."  ;-)

If there is a short-term art show at, say, the Live Worms Gallery, someone who hangs-out at The Trieste organized it. If there is a poetry reading in the neighborhood, someone who hangs-out at The Trieste organized it. If there is a larger North Beach arts-related event, someone who hangs-out at The Trieste organized it.

There are people here who have no idea that Life exists West of Stockton Street. If you just dash-in for a cuppa, you're not going to meet these folks. Like the cappuccino (the best in town), or the teas, you gotta get steeped in the place.

Like a dog-eared copy of "On the Road," it is showing signs of wear. I'd call that "ambiance." As a genuine North Beach Landmark, there may be none greater.
author: John H.

description:
No soy.
Bitchy 'tudes.
Terminal congestion.
Uppity regulars.
A San Francisco landmark?

I think not.

   To those of you calling this place "charming" and one that "makes the Bay Area special", please go back to L.A. or wherever you're from and stay there.  

   To the baristas who are so buried in their drama they can scarcely look up to take your order, stop with the surliness.  You weren't a ghost whiter for Jack Kerouac, and I'm sorry for that.  But you're here, now, and I'm asking you for some coffee.  You dig?   

  I'm SO over it!
author: Lea N.

description:
Caffe Trieste is a sweet little city gem that's been around all my life. In fact, I got a little curious when Trieste first opened. So I checked their website.  Turns out the original Caffe Trieste was the first espresso caffe in the United States..  It opened in North Beach in 1956 and was one of the hang outs for the beat scene, when Burroughs, Ginsberg, and  Kerouac were running around this hood. So this place is basically a San Francisco landmark.

We used to bop around North Beach as well, when I was a young-in...

One night, we parked and strolled over to Savoy Tivoli and took a table out front.  We managed to order drinks and tried to meet some girls.  But we were way too immature to make any real progress in that area..  But that didn't stop them from letting us into one of those dirty strip clubs on Broadway.. Watching girls dance to the Talking Heads was a little surreal.  So, thanks for the memories North Beach. And thanks Savoy Tivoli and for serving us back in the day.  

Thanks for the pitchers of beer and jack and cokes, and providing us the unnecessary fuel to run wild on Grant street.  Later in the night , a couple of us headed down to Caffe Trieste for some coffee to straighten up for the ride home.  Their strong coffee and pasteries saved our little asses that night.  

Now fast forward to today; I headed over to Caffe Trieste after a nice afternoon lunch with a friend in North Beach for an espresso.  Not only was the espresso amazing.  I asked the guy behind the counter to hook me up with a little milk in it.  He told me to say when.  Keep going, keep going.....okay good.  That was the best espresso I have had in a long time.  Of course it was basically a custom macchiato.

He added the foamed milk to my liking and I added just the right amount of brown sugar.  Loved it. Sipped it. Then shot the rest.... Stop by the original CaffeTrieste for a slice of local San Francisco history and some the best coffee in town.
author: Georgio N.

description: It's such a classic Italian-American cafe located in North Beach, San Francisco. It's even got to f's instead of just one!
author: Denise C.

description:
Let it be said that Caffe Trieste is TOO GANGSTER for Yelp. 

My only hope is that if I stay in SF forever that I'll be a Caffe Trieste burn-out/OG chillen every morning drinking my cappuccino talking smack to the young North Beach-ers (like myself currently).
author: Natalie T.

description:
After having to leave Cafe Sappore due to their 8:30 closing time, and realizing I would not get through my backlog of work without more coffee, I headed to the only other cafe I know of in North Beach that was open, with WiFi.

Not sure what to make of this place. I may give it another go in the hopes that I was just there on an off night, cause the coffee is good and I can work late without staying in the office with all of the overachievers (wouldn't want to give the wrong impression......I do constantly say I work to live, not the other way around). 

Heres the scoop;

The guy who was taking the coffee orders stopped completely, with a line of people, to take a personal call. My motto is don't mess with an addict and her coffee, no good can come of it....but he seemed to be completely unphased by the potential wrath he could have faced had I not had a latte just an hour ago. 

The staff also have an uncanny ability to block the way to the restroom at the exact moment someone needs to get by. I saw this occur several times, and they didnt seem horribly concerned or eager to clear the pathway. Speaking of restrooms, lets not....I will only say it was bad, and we shall not speak of this again.

I was stopped by some random guy who asked me to watch his friend pull his finger......his stretchy rubber finger. This is the only thing that may have been par for the course here, because I am convinced I am a total freak magnet.

So, that was experience #1 with this place. I'll give it one more chance to raise its star rating, but fool me twice shame on me, so I hope my next experience is better.
author: Drue C.

description: Great place, best coffee, nice pastries. Authentically seating. Only disadvantage: cash only. But several ATMs very close.
author: Kermit T.

description:
In our exodus from the Mission, the lady and I feared for the loss of top notch coffee in the surrounding area.

Mercifully, North Beach has Caffe Trieste.  Flavor-wise, it's on par with the likes of Four Barrel and Ritual and the queue moves a lot faster than the latter.

Granted, it still falls short of the dizzying heights of Blue Bottle...but there's one close enough at the Ferry Building if needs must.

Added bonus - this place has beer and wine.  Great place for a nightcap on Fridays and Saturdays if the hustle and bustle of the proper Grant street nightlife seems a little full-on.
author: David K.

description:
This is one of the few places that was open this morning on my walk into work. There were a bunch of older men sitting out front enjoying their coffee/espresso drinks and plenty of cigarettes. We had to walk through the cloud of smoke to get into the coffee shop. There were two ppl ahead of us. One guy taking order and cash payment and one guy making the drinks. Wait wasn't too bad for our two medium coffees since all he did was pour. Price was more than I expected just for drip coffee, $2.40 for one medium cup.  They don't offer skim milk, 2% was the low fat option. 
Pastries were in boxes from wherever it is they order from. They had transferred some of them to plates which makes the presentation better. I think they should display all of them on plates to make it look more appetizing but I am sure they sell enough to not care about my small suggestion. We didn't try the pastries so cannot comment on taste.
author: Bling L.

description: I checked this place out after I read an article listing it as one of the top coffee shops in San Francisco. Although it is a first rate local cafe with great ambience, the coffee isn't comparable to blue bottle or four barrel.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Trieste is a love hate for me. I love the coffee, best prepared espresso and coffee in the neighborhood, hands down. Also, it's the real North Beach down there. It's where the crazies, the locals and the crazy locals congregate. 
The place has real history which anyone who has ever been there can't deny. It just exudes Emperor Norton. 

A warning: the line takes for ever. I have waited 15 min to get an Africano with only 3 people in front of me. And after reading this review, they'll probably make me wait longer. Oh well, I can but only speak the truth. So I only go to Trieste when I have 15 min to spare on a coffee. But shouldn't it be like that? I mean, should coffee be an express thing, like getting gas or stopping by the ATM? Shouldn't getting and drinking a good coffee or espresso something to be enjoyed? I think it should, but I don't always have time.

If you're looking for a cheap and quickie (cuz we all do sometimes) then go somewhere else.
author: Carla P.

description:
I had the white chocolate mocha. Love it! 

The place is packed with people and got really busy even on a Tuesday afternoon. 

Will be going back!
author: Angie L.

description:
Caffe Trieste is a pretty good coffee shop in Little Italy / North Beach.  I stopped in here last weekend with a friend to enjoy the ambiance that others have favorably reviewed here and to reenergize myself with a latte. The staff was friendly and the coffee was delicious - full of flavor, strong, fresh, and very satisfying overall.  The latte was well crafted (though definitely a bit small for the price) with the proper mix of milk, foam, and espresso.

Unfortunately, when I visited the café was absolutely packed (all tables taken and no real place to stand...) as a woman sang at the back of the café (which is small). Since there wasn't much space, my friend and I were forced to grab our coffee to go (the few tables outside were also taken - generally, the scene was chaotic).

My 3 star rating is based on this experience - great coffee with an inability to sit / enjoy the coffee inside the establishment. If you're looking for fantastic coffee on the go, definitely try this place; if you're looking for a place to sit down and catch up with a friend, consider going elsewhere.
author: Rishi N.

description:
I have to say I love a place where the man making your coffee flips off the girl in front of you in line, to her face, and goes on making his wonderful coffee drinks as if nothing happened. The finger in a public place usually is followed by a tip from me, as long as I'm not the one receiving it. In that case I don't think a tip would be involved. 

I don't care that I have to wait 15 minutes, or that the line barely moves, or that if you don't know your order you'll get the stink eye. The coffee is really good! It's really worth all of that. So are the pastries, especially the raspberry one.  

Sometimes the music they play is is Greek too, which I love. It makes me want to jump out of my little wooden chair, join hands with the other patrons, and form a big circle... just like when my family attends weddings. 

For some reason, I don't think it would go over so well.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Amazing coffee, great seating, friendly service, and the chance to feel like you're a part of San Francisco and literary history while you're at it--all of these make Caffe Trieste a must for any local or out of towner (like myself).  It's unfair how much I like this place, and I really enjoy sitting and watching the community that Caffe Trieste inhabits--older folk, aging poets, young punkers, random denizens all frequent the place.

I was also personally amused by all the writing on the walls of the impossibly tiny bathrooms.  None of the usual obscene graffiti--it was a series of impassioned and at times ridiculous political discussions left in pen by other people who had to relieve themselves.  Something like that just make me smile.  Who writes their own thoughts on Marxist theory for posterity while on the john?  Refrain from adding your own comment (the management can't be a fan of the graffiti), and squeeze out of the claustrophobic bathrooms and enjoy the breezy, relaxed feel of Caffe T.
author: Teej T.

description:
It appears that this place is pretty polarizing, what with complaints about service and whatnot. Anyways, I was in North Beach recently with a few friends and when we passed by Caffe Trieste we knew that we had an obligation to try it out. However, we aborted our first attempt when, literally, a bus-load of geriatric tourists rolled up and funneled into the place. Nevertheless, when we went back, about half an hour later, the place had quieted down and we were able to order our coffee. 

I got to the front of the line and the barista, while not exuding warm fuzzy kindness, was perfectly friendly and even joked with me a bit (I ordered an espresso, only to be told it consisted of four shots, at which point I unordered said espresso by saying "shit, I think I want to sleep sometime in the next week"). I got a cappuccino instead. 

Now on to the coffee. My cappuccino was made to order and was very good. The coffee had a very rich and complex flavor and the whole thing was very aesthetically pleasing with little swirls in the foam and whatnot (not that I need such flourishes: see Lulu's review for reference). 

Almost as important as the coffee, however, is the history of the place. The photos on the wall depict a coffee house with a rich history; apparently Francis Ford Coppola wrote much of the script for "The Godfather" here. 

All in all I was perfectly content with Caffe Trieste. The prices were about the same as I would pay in Santa Cruz, which is awesome considering the touristy nature of North Beach, and the staff was friendly. I would definitely go back.
author: Nick C.

description:
I think the only reason people like this place is because it has a local, community atmosphere. And if that's what you're looking for, you'll love it. However, some of the locals who go there would be better off in a mental institution, and it can get kind of scary at night.

The cafe itself is kind of nasty and I actually think their coffee tastes better at their other locations. And this location refuses to carry any soymilk, I assume because they're so obsessed with looking "authentic" (would Kerouac be anti-soy?) Well, they do have authentically bad attitudes. The last time I went, the barista guy was eating chicken wings at the counter and served me a chicken-grease-covered latte. I haven't been back since. 

BUT- the one on Market at Gough is much better and they also have live events, so I recommend you go there.
author: Shindō Nicholas S.

description:
Hands down the best espresso I've had in SF. The atmosphere is funky, but comfortable, although it can get pretty crowded. There is also a delicious selection of food and alcohol!

As much as I would love to give this place 5 stars, because it is without a doubt 5 star espresso, the service brings it down a bit. The best I've ever gotten is a neutral to slightly morose barista, but sometimes the're downright pissed off at I don't know what (not me, I'm damn friendly). At least they don't take it out on me or my coffee.

Bonus: there's a nice (albeit metered) little strip of motorcycle parking out front. So yeah, overall, this place is great. Check it out!
author: Ben Y.

description: Love this place.  The best cappuccinos.  All the other Caffe Triestes kinda suck, but this one is great.  The atmosphere is classic San Francisco, which is hard to come by these days.  The people working the counter aren't the friendliest in the world, but they deal with tourists all day so I don't expect much, or care for that matter.  Just make me a good cappuccino, keep the canned friendly service and crappy coffee for Starbucks.
author: Joe F.

description:
Good Espresso:  4 Stars

Drunk man ranting about  war, politics, and chickens:   -1 star

Mouse crawling across the floor at my feet as I am sitting here, at Cafe Trieste, writing this review:   -1 star. 

Character:  Yes, please.

Rabies:  No. Thank you.
author: Sarah J.

description:
The coffee is okay.  The pastries are not good and not fresh.  If you want to use a laptop there, don't bother.  There are 0, maybe 1 plug.  Its loud and in the evening they have live music.  The last time I went there some freak kept taking pictures of my feet while I was trying to work, then my battery died so I left.  The service also not great.  

If you want to hear live music and people watch, go here.  If you want really good coffee better service and you maybe want to use a computer and not be bothered with bands and feet fetish freaks, go somewhere else, maybe Caffe Roma.
author: Amy J.

description:
Sometimes when you live in a city, it takes you a while to visit all of its classic spots, and such was the case with me and Cafe Trieste.

I had heard about it on and off for years, but since my day to day routine involves a car, and therefore parking, going to North Beach usually just gives me anxiety, especially on the weekends.  

With family in town for the weekend, I broke my personal rule and took them to North Beach, and happened to park across from Cafe Trieste.  I loved it from the minute we walked in - the coffee aroma is wonderful, the tables are crammed all over the place, and people there seemed hunkered down for the day with their laptops or notebooks, sipping cup after cup of frothy cappuccinos and lattes.  Definitely my kind of place.

My cappuccino was absolutely perfect, from the rich roasted taste of the coffee, to the creamy foamy head at the top.  I savored every sip.

I know that this will be a destination for me, as nearly 24 hours after having been there, I am already craving one of their coffees.  I can clearly picture it:  I will be the one in the corner with a book, a cannoli, and a big frothy cappuccino in front of me.  

Note:  Cash only.
author: Liz S.

description: This place has some history and great atmosphere. The staff was a bit snooty. They don't have nonfat  and  they don't have soy milk so  they didn't get my money.
author: Patricia S.

description: Great cappuccino and white chocolate mocha. I grabbed some to go and some pastries and was pleasantly surprised. Good joe and a rich history, i'm sold. On a side note CASH ONLY, so no plastique.
author: David P.

description: To be fair, we didn't get coffee. We stopped in here so I could admire the spot where Francis Ford Coppola allegedly wrote The Godfather script. Cool little spot. We got waters (we'd just walked a mountain and tons of steps and were way too hot for coffee) and a cookie that was just okay. So four stars for nostalgia but two stars for the cookie, hence the three-star rating.
author: Elena M.

description:
I was going to try to be original, but decided that my sentiments exactly mirror someone else's and therefore, I repeat:

"So maybe Caffe Trieste was the first espresso cafe in San Francisco, and maybe Francis Ford Coppala wrote the Godfather script here, and from the looks of the place things haven't changed much at Trieste since those days.  And that's the problem.  Nowdays there's a cafe on every corner of San Francisco, many of which offer coffee that rivals Trieste's.  Not to say that their espresso is lousy, or their drip coffee is bad, but is it worth waiting in a long line (of tourists) when there are better places?  The real kicker is they do not serve soymilk -- if you're lactose intolerant or a vegan (or both) go elsewhere."
author: Lauren L.

description:
Biters drink "Gibraltars". 

The rest of us drink Africanos.
author: Chris R.

description: Good atmosphere... Great coffee, food.
author: John C.

description:
Solid cup of coffee.....served in a glass shaped like an hour glass.  Do people serve hot coffee in glasses that were meant to water?  I was afraid that my glass would break.

My latte was perfectly layered in three tiers: espresso sunk to the bottom, the center and rich perfect milk chocolate color, and the topped with perfect white foam (it's hard to make good foam).   

The reason why Starbucks took over the world, is that neighborhood coffee shops stopped putting in passion, consistency and care into each cup.  This place still has it.  Did I mention that they also make homemade whip cream?  As all true coffeehouses SHOULD.  

But there is more to this place than just coffee, you can feel the history of this place, weathered walls and photos of ghosts passed hung on the walls...definately a hippy bohemian hang out.  I'm sure that many great poems, songs, and waves of artistic depression were born here gazing through these windows
author: Sandy C.

description: When I was at Caffe Trieste, I ordered a combo - tuna melt panini and a half salad. Now the food presentation, food quality and taste, and quaint cafe-esque ambiance was on the spot. The crowd is interesting; it ranges from gay men to local families to college students to tourists. There are people who just go there to drink a cup of coffee/tea and read or use their free Wifi. We were in the area and stopped by to eat a late lunch, but really got to soak in the laid-back SF atmosphere. I give it 3 stars because the service was incredibly slow. There were only 2-3 people and tons of customers waiting to get their food or to make an order. It took a good 20-30 minutes for our food to come. Otherwise, I'd give it 4-5 stars, and if I lived in the SF area I'd definitely drop by regularly for a quick lunch.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
I too wanted to relish in the history of this place- but that seems to be the shtick here- I get you're supposed to like this place because of Kerouac et al...

The coffee? meh.  I've had much, much better.  The service?  Every time I've been here the baristas seem like they not only hated their current employment status, but also hated there current life status...oh, the self-hatred that drives an artiste.

Come here once and that's all you'll need.
author: Knathan R.

description:
There's a lot of crap that people want done to their precious drinks, and being a barista myself, I know why people may think the baristas here are assholes. They don't have soy, and they aren't sorry, dude! It was SO refreshing to go to a neighborhood coffee house and see that these coffee-slingers were NOT going to give you rice milk, or a certain amount of pumps, or no foam. Didn't mean they didn't smile or say hello! 
Though crowded, I'd gone twice in a week and been able to find a table no problem, and the no-bullshit means the line gets through quickly and without shouting orders. The espresso is strong and delicious, as are the pastries (which will sell out quickly). There IS a .15 cent charge for a paper cup, but I didn't mind because in a place like that, why wouldn't you want to stay and enjoy the atmosphere?
author: Kate K.

description: I'd give this place five stars for the location and atmosphere, and 2 stars for their pizza and coffee. The coffee was way too harsh, and the pizza was just meh. I expected way more of a place with such great history located in the middle of an Italian neighborhood. To be fair, maybe their pastries are amazing, I don't know, but they didn't look anything special.
author: Mike J.

description:
I wish this was a more unknown hang out, but it's always packed with locals and tourists alike.  I guess young Mr. Coppola thought this was a nice, quiet dive... and soon after he brought with him the amasses.

I love their thick ham n cheese sandwiches served on foccacia bread, which they heat on the pannini grill.  Tomato salad and pepperoncinis are served on the side, which I love to smoosh inside my sandwiches for a sour flavor.

Service can be a bit informal, but they just want a fast turnover to deal with the ever growing line.  Grab a bench seat by the window to people watch and observe the barista skills.  They play some fabulous crooner jazz music on their juke.  Or for a little more privacy, take a seat toward the back, connect to their free Wifi, and maybe you too can pen your own classic, Oscar-winning masterpiece.
author: Chris T.

description:
Grumpy. Caught in rain. Splitting headache that can only be quelled by coffee. Can't find f*cking coffee shop in all of Chinatown. Brainshattering Chinese New Year fireworks not helping. End up in North Beach where there are more coffee shops than old bordellos. Thank god for Cafe Trieste. 

Wasn't impressed with the long line after trekking across town in rain with splitting headache, but holy deliciousness, was it worth the wait. I was enticed into veering from my usu cappuccino breve to try the Africano--double shot of espresso with steamed half and half. This thing was so smooth and hot, I wanted to make love to it with wild abandon. Optimism in life and love of country restored, all for $2.50 and a wet walk. 

In case you weren't sure, this is not the place to order a frappa-latta-sugar-free-vanilla-soy-chai-half caf. Grab your balls and order a proper coffee and love every last sip of it.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
What is with all of the positive reviews here, I am just blown away. Are they going to the same Caffe Trieste I am going to?

TO ME IT IS ...

Way, way, way overrated. I have been here several times to hear Momma and Pappa play on Saturday's and while I love to hear them sing, the staff is always rude and pushy to drink the minimums. You just can't relax there anymore.

And the food is terrible. Old, dry and stale as far as I am concerned. Never had the coffee here but how much different can coffee be from each other? I love coffee and straight it all tastes the same to my mouth.

Its "glory days" are in the past with all the beats and bums hanging around. I have even seen fights here before. Go, take your pictures and get out. Nothing to see.

Sorry, the reputation is not the reality here unlike many other North Beach places that I have been to and I love North Beach.
author: Terry H.

description:
Trieste gets away with murder.
It's too cliche', too famous, too crowded, too slow, too hot, too cold, 
too
my
favorite 
place
to 
dance
on
the bar.
Too Africano perfection.
author: Adrienne S.

description: Legit coffee with awesome whipped cream. They toast the bagels well here.  The place is well worth the hype. I shall return.
author: King G.

description:
Good strong cappuccinos; made my coffee-loving high octane cousin all jittery.  Great Italian operas in the jukebox.  Service is fast and sometimes not-so-friendly, location's off the busy Columbus Street.  Classic North Beach establishment.

The place is always full of people so getting inside may take some work and pointy elbows.  However this coffeehouse certainly had great vibes and people seem to be enjoying each other's company.

Downside: drinks are pricey and the place charges $.10 for paper cup.  So if you plan to get your drink to go, make sure you have an extra dime in your pocket.  Also they tend to keep the change thinking that they're entitled to a tip.  While the monetary amount may be small, taking without asking is essentially stealing.  This knocked off 3 stars.
author: Vvn W.

description:
Their coffee is overpriced and they don't have skim milk - typical bay area coffee house that decides to control your diet intake by not having skim milk or splenda.

i went there about 1 month ago, i stopped drinking coffee 3 weeks ago and stopped splenda intake yesterday.  but i was, at the time, i need of those two things, and they didn't have it.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
Caffe Trieste is what I think of as the classic North Beach cafe. The coffee drinks are good. The pastries are so-so, not made on the premises. 

But the people who work here! They are true gems. A little rude, very funny, and feel just like family even though you've known them for two seconds.
author: Gloria L.

description: I haven't been here in years but I used to come down for a coffee in the morning or a glass of wine in the evening and just people watch. My tour group stopped by this morning and I got a house coffee to go. Just as good as I remembered it all those years ago. A regular size cost me $1.95..great pastries abound and the staff was great. I must return and sit for a few hours soon..
author: michael s.

description: Coffee here isn't bad but it's too much of a scene that knows itself.  If I was in that scene I might have a different opinion, but as it stands I have bought coffee here numerous times and never feel like I'm a regular.  I think some of the guys now recognize me, after maybe the 20th time I've been there, but it's never "hey, how's it going?!"  It feels ostracizing.  Add to that the "Oh, it's Caffe Trieste.  It's got history and pictures on the wall and sometimes a band is there playing music" and you get a place that seems more geared toward the clique of old hippies that dream of a Grant Avenue that no longer exists and tourists who go there because the guidebook told them to.
author: Kevin W.

description: Service was quick and friendly. Lots of regulars and old school customers. This place place is living history. Kerouac, Ginsberg, and I even saw Lawrence Ferlinghetti here. He seemed a bit out of it, but he's 90+ so it's understandable. A nice place to take a break, drink a cappuccino, and read a few papers.
author: Tim O.

description: Oh my days. Those were some gooooooooood cannoli. That's all I know. Go get the cannoli. Eat the cannoli. CANNOLI!
author: Julia K.

description:
Absolutely the best espresso evah! Looked like a good mix of locals and tourists too. A must see & do if you are in town for 2 or more days.
one nit-pic: I saw folks with laptops and mac books, but I could only get Edge on my iPhone.  Not that I needed to be connected, but most people seem to have a need for wi-fis at a coffee shop these days
author: Steve H.

description:
The actual cafe is pretty quant and cute, the coffee is decent but a little expensive for one cup.

YES, they have free wi-fi but only two outlets in the whole place and if you aren't sitting at the table right by them they won't let you put the cord across the small aisle to the outlet...I got yelled at for it even though it's not a high traffic area and my cord was not taught and about to trip anyone.  

Get some more outlets.
author: Amanda M.

description:
This review is for the coffee and ambiance and service only - not the groups of Italian girls who frequent this place and talk in their Italian accents while you try to concentrate of ordering your double latte.
Friendly service 
Inexpensive
small cups (wish they had larger Italian cup sizes)
Good Espresso
;)
author: Life L.

description:
Caffe Trieste has declined over the years... Although a couple of the counter folks are great, the majority of the employees are slow, and seem determined to keep the line so long and slow moving that it will drive business away.

While the place still has the charm of its early days of the 1950s, unfortunately that's the only charm it has left.  They do offer free wireless, but its an unreliable connection --  and don't even think about asking the counter staff about the wireless!  They have no idea and don't appear interested in helping.

Still its a fun place to people watch if you're prepared to be accosted by the neighborhood crazies...
author: H.A. ..

description:
Mama mia, that's one strong cup of coffee!  Or maybe I just don't have much tolerance for caffeine. Anyway, if you want some Old World Coffee, Caffe Trieste is where to go.  

...Caffe Trieste made a cameo in the movie "40 Days and 40 Nights starring Josh Hartnett." Check it out!
author: Eric G.

description: It is superb coffee but very busy and on the tourist trail. Lots of locals drop by in the writer / hippie / poet / artist vein.  Usually a few laptops.
author: Dave B.

description: Not super impressed. Dumpy place with bad cappuchino. Cool that there is free wireless but where is the character everyone is yelping about? Not sure how Cafe Trieste is an "International landmark". North Beach has tons of great cafes and coffee shops so I wouldn't bother with this place.
