author: Debbie C.

description: Finally, we've met. Hello best espresso in America! I'm thinking in moving to North Beach just to be near you.
author: Andrea C.

description:
No soy, no problem.

My coffee drink of choice is a grande soy latte but Caffee Trieste doesn't offer soy.  Oh well, when in Rome, er, I mean North Beach.
My drink was creamy and oh so delicious...I imagine just like they are served in Italy.
author: phil h.

description:
Not to be missed on your next trip to SF.  Great atmosphere and best coffee that I know of in North Beach.  

Go on a weekend and enjoy the mini Opera with a cappuccino or a double espresso      (p.s. if you miss one of the Operas, check out the jukebox -- it has an eclectic music mix with numerous Opera selections....)
author: Rich n Nancy C.

description: Best place for a quick coffee break. this is a landmark in north beach, its prob one of the oldest businesses in the area and its still running strong. Good service and good drinks.
author: Q W.

description:
I used to live around the corner from here for about 5 years.  Part of me misses the place so much, but that was before.  Fabio, Papa Gianni's son, is  not so slowly ruining the place.  I mean how the hell could you sell the roasting machine you had there even if it wasn't being used anymore?  What, just so you could start selling more of that tacky merchandise?  Uggh.  Sonia please smack some sense into him.  God only knows what will happen after Papa is no longer with us (sorry, a very horrible thought I know).  When granddaughter Ida left, you knew there were big problems brewing.

However, I still love SOME of the crowd that hangs out there.  Sometimes the self declared Commies are a bit much, etc.  But most importantly, the cappuccino is still the best I have ever had.  Still have to give it 4 stars for being the institution that it is.

R.I.P. John Franco, your memory lives on strong!!
author: Andrew L.

description:
step into old Italy... the Italian American version that is.
ok, so we don't have satriale's in SF.
But we DO have a corner of boho life that North
Beach used to be while everything else goes
track lighting and national franchises.  Trieste is to a cafe what City
Lights is to a bookshop.  It's an institution.
so the food is a little crummy and institutional -
avoid the pastries -- but the coffee is great, and the atmosphere,
priceless.  This place hasn't been gussied up since the 60's
(or that's how it feels), and that's why you come here.
Plus the cafe africano, which is divine.
author: James F.

description: Like most of the coffee shops, Caffe Trieste is small, and because of its fantastic coffee, it's also crowded. So the day I went there, there was long line(seems it's always the case)which was a good sign. The espresso and Cappuccino were all very good.
author: Kenneth L.

description: Coffee here is unparalleled, as is the food. The secret, in my opinion, is in the equipment and technique. They have a great steamer, brewer and toaster. The staff possesses the right skills to know how--with what amount of foam or espresso, and at what temperature everything should be presented. People are really friendly and the decor has a vintage twist. Definitely would recommend it to all coffee lovers
author: R S.

description: My family and myself stumbled upon this cafe one evening after dinner nearby and decided to stop in because it seemed comfy and quiet, a good place for some intimate conversation. The only downside is that it took only cash and we didn't know this until after we ordered, good thing we had the extra cash on us! The Chai Tea that I ordered was honestly one of the best I've ever had in my life and their chocolate chip cookies? To die for! A hidden gem in SF!!
author: Denise A.

description:
back for more...i had an africano then a 4 shot latte. i really love the espresso here. the service can be a bit "whadda ya want", but the smaller asian guy who is freqeutnly behind the counters is pretty hip. he recomended i skip their cannollis and head the stellas down the street.

i thank him for the guidance to the yellow brick road of sugar heaven.
author: Shane B.

description: Really cool caffe. The barista was very helpful and it doesn't hurt that The Godfather was written here.
author: Andrew M.

description: This review is for coffee only. My husband and I both got cappuccinos. The espresso was very tasty--reportedly roasted next door. The place has a ton of personality, and is definitely divey. The small tables in the front make for good people watching on the street. The jukebox is charming--and works! Walls are covered with charming photos. I would go back and hang out. It's small, but if you can snag a table, it's a good spot to stop and relax. I'm sure it's full of tourists, but since I was one, I didn't mind and couldn't tell!
author: Kate P.

description: This is my favorite location because they make the best drinks...their espresso is wonderful- soo much better than Petes or Starbucks that you shouldn't even compare!!
author: Layla L.

description: Okay, came here because it's suppose to be one of the romantic spots to have a cup of hot coco, well, it's a nice and cozy place with a lot of history packed.  It's old and crowded.  Has bunch of hippies selling their art with more hippie fans/admirers/stalkers taking photos of the hippie artist.  After living in Berkeley for 4 years, I have to say, not into it, AT ALL.  Good service, okay hot coco and sweets.  Probably wouldn't come here again tho.
author: Young N.

description:
we're from out of town (San Diego) and went here on suggestion after dinner at The House (see that review as well).

The espresso was good. I really enjoy a good cup of coffee in an authentic mug, not feeling like I was in a rush.

This place is a truly unique spot. The crowd was quite a surprise. From the super friendly woman who specialized in tribal art and fabrics, to the "homeless" men who hung out. It felt like we were part of a big family. While the woman entertained our 20 month old daughter, a regular who happens to be homeless also conversed with us. I wouldn't say we felt concerned for our safety, but it was truly a unique experience. Everyone was so friendly that I kept the same eye on my daughter as if I was in the local starbucks. Truly a neighborhood coffee shop that is a must visit for outsiders & locals alike. I wish we had a place like this in San Diego (The Living Room in La Jolla is the closest we have).

Very nice they also have Bailey's type liquor as well, that's a bonus!
author: Rather O.

description: Good coffee. Rude service.  Live music is nice but costs $7 per person and no place to sit.
author: Oren R.

description: The coffee shop is an interesting mix of eclectic peoples: accented tourists, comfortable regulars, students, businessmen, families, etc. I ordered a chai latte, which was one of the best I've ever had. The favors of the chai really come out but the latte keeps the sweetness factor down, thereby creating a perfect balance. There's only two outlets in the store, so it's not really laptop-friendly, and the place has a vibe of disheveled, chaotic charm.
author: Jing P.

description: Old school, gritty, and classic, Cafe Trieste won't disappoint.  All of the comments on here about the gruff clientele and abrasive staff just makes me like the place better.  This is not for the faint of heart or somebody who is seeking a "feel good" coffee shop atmosphere.  Trieste is the real deal- a place steeped in history and defined by the regulars who frequent it.  It somehow maintains a tremendous authenticity despite being located in touristic North Beach and popular amongst celebrities and politicos.
author: Mike B.

description:
Well, i got coffee and an fresh-squeezed OJ, and both were OK.  It was a crowded saturday morning, and i was just one of many getting a fix.  

3/5 coffee
4/5 atmosphere
3/5 service
3/5 value

They do have Free Wireless - http://www.yelp.com/list_details?userid=mkQ-J4uMULsJvc9V8gMENw&list_id=xJ_tC-4_YAdDCurRxaQBNw
author: chad n.

description:
This place does a coffee drinker right.  Four stars to Trieste for consistently granting my wish of a just-hot-enough, yummy, chocolately, espresso-rich mocha.  Although it might not have been the fastest or cheapest cup of coffee I've gotten, I definitely appreciated the quality of my cup and the dollop of fresh whipped cream on top.  

I enjoy the comfy vibe of this place - the aroma of fresh poured espresso, dark wood, a little dim, and lots of sippers at tables chatting, reading, or writing.  It's a nice change of pace from the pretentious laptop jungles most cafes have become.  The location is great for people watching and its right on a quaint strip of Grant Street that is tourist shop-free.
author: Deborah L.

description: This place is for real.  If you want to hang out with a strangely diverse group of hippies, locals, and curious tourists, this cafe is a great spot.  Besides the crowd, the cool pictures on the wall, and the location, are enough to impress.  Staff was also friendly.
author: Liz Z.

description:
This is a cool local place, obviously with a lot of history, but I wasn't impressed with the coffee. 
On the upside, I like that it gives people of like-minds a place to congregate and hang out...writers a place to write, musicians a place to create music, artists a place to imagine, and weirdos a place to be weird. But for me, I just want some good coffee, and I will not be coming back here for it. It's a shame, because I live less than a block away, so I was really hoping to love the coffee because of the cool vibe and close proximity to my house. Darn it.
author: Julie F.

description:
This place is a an institution.

An institution that I hadn't been into in several years, so I dropped in last night to get the most perfect cup of coffee. I took one sip, and the taste made me think I was back in Siena, then I looked around realized I wasn't, and took it to go.
author: Dixon T.

description:
This place has character.  Good for the faded beat ambiance. Expect people to be muttering to themselves or yelling at each other nearby.

Overheard quote from today's visit:
"Ambitious people don't know who the fuck they are...why? because they're ambitious!"

The coffee is probably the second best in NB after Caffe Greco.  Service is generally pretty good, though if you're tightly wound and get upset when the barrista chats with a customer for 30 seconds, you might consider going elsewhere.

Don't go when the band plays...it's a ripoff.

-Chris
author: Chris C.

description: After City Lights Bookstore during the early 60's, headed to Caffe Trieste. My lessons in life and as a San Franciscian, was at this caffe. Artist, poets, musicians, famous. All inspiring. Visited today and my table that I always sat at was available, even while it was packed. Two Italian older couples came in. So excited, just like home, even though I did not understand the language, their smiles was convincing. Great place to have coffee, read a book or paper or to soak in the feelings that is North Beach.
author: William B.

description:
I have so many memories of coming in here as a Kid Back in the 80's

My dad & stepmom would be @ work at the on Broadway club and my step mom would give me money to go here and pick up there coffee..

It was my chance to get out of my granparents house and act off the hook with no repercussions...

I would walk around Broadway and trip off of the hawks trying to get people to come into Carol Doda's or one of the other strip clubs that 
used to be down there. There where people

They never questioned why it took so long for me to come back with the coffee

My dad and stepmom where drinking this strong coffee back in the day. This is till hands down one of the best places in the city to get a
latte.

Im sticking to it the line is worth iT
author: Kim R.

description:
Whoa UPDATE:  Saw that Cafe Trieste will be taking a spot across from Zuni's on Market near Valencia.
______
Did  anyone head over there today?  Today is the 50th anniversary of this landmark.  Cups o' Joe for 25 to 30 cents, same prices as they were when Giovanni Giotta opened it in 1956.  And we thought it would be raining all day---it's gorgeous out and not too late to head over.  Check out these stats:  
# of cafes
Caffe Trieste: 4
Starbucks Corp.: More than 10,000*
# of employees
Trieste: About 40
Starbucks: 96,700 

Ciao!
author: Engracia A.

description:
You have to try this place to get a real feel for North Beach. 

My suggestion is the mocha with their homemade whipped cream on top.
author: Tom M.

description:
I always take my dad here when he comes to visit.  He really likes it on Saturday's because of course, the opera and the cappuccino's.  Lots of characters, and you can sit and day-dream of anything and everything while your emotions spiral to the tune of whom-ever is singing.

I actually like the fact that some things will never change and that is exactly why I tumble in from time to time.  If I wanted a 5 star cuisine everytime I went out - well, I think I would live a very disappointed and boring life.

So with that, I love the people who strive to sing a better song than from the last time I came in - and seeing that the location is ideal for stirring the soul, this is a great SF  place to watch when there is a new election.  You should have seen all of the mayhem that went down here when Gavin was elected.  I thought someone was going to get shot!
author: Yelper A.

description:
Espresso.  That's that.  Sturdy, sinfully sweet, and full bodied.  The crema was a little thin, and I jumped on it hot off the press too.  But, definitely not hype.  Quality with quaintness.  

I came and saw the owner and his wife.  They were taking pictures, just like the picture in the joint.  Was really cute.  Then I couldn't help but think, "I wonder how many times he cheated on her?"...made the moment a little sour.  Nonetheless, it was their anniversary I think.  But back to the coffee...

My friends got some cappuccino, and I took a sip.  Pleasant, and rich.  Live music too, when you can catch it (we didn't).  And good coffee IS really that hard to find, if you're a connoisseur like me.
author: Jay M.

description:
The original and still the best. Great Coffee, Great Food, Great Music, Great  Atmosphere. This place should spank Starbucks in the ass and scream out WHO'S YOUR DADDY!!!
Can be difficult to get a seat on the weekends but that's minor relative to the great coffee your gonna get.
author: Brian J.

description:
I really want to like this place more. I mean, it's North Beach! It's Trieste! It's legend! And then I try the slightly overstrong coffee and think there are better alternatives. It's perfectly fine as a standby, but there are better alternatives in the area. 

Also, it's not a good sign when you order a shot and the guy asks if you've ever had a real espresso before. I almost offered to show him how to make one.

PS. About that espresso roast (and a note to all roasters, period): Espresso is not, and should never be, a dark roast.
author: Geof M.

description:
Classic. Reeks of history. Great photos of Bill Cosby making espressos behind the counter on the wall (before a set at the old Hungry i?).

The first espresso coffee shop in the world, or the USA, or the west coast or California or something. Anyway, It's been here a long time and they definitely serve up the espresso right. No filtered coffee here. Great atmosphere in the heart of North Beach. Tastes even better when you know you're supporting a real San Francisco institution. 

The opera on the weekends is really great too. Kind of a folksy affair without all the pretension associated with the form. Just a bunch of old timers belting it out 3 feet from your face. Highly recommended.
author: Darren K.

description: Good coffee. Get it to go. The place is dirty. Definitely seen better days.
author: Dave H.

description:
From my journal notes, now:

I have had my coffee and am sitting in a new cafe for me (Caffe Trieste in North Beach).  I got to hear the bells from the Catholic church next door, and the cafe is playing a combination of jazz and opera over the loudspeakers, and I found a place to sit and write, and life is good.  I am milking a room temperature cappuccino and remembering life and what is important.  This woman in line has a wine-red leather bag that I am admiring.  I will always be looking for the perfect bag, and may never find it.

The regulars come in.  People sneeze, cough, and talk.  The sky burns through the last of the clouds and raises to pure blue.  There were many times that I wanted to come in and experience Trieste.  The cafe is long-ways, with a mural at one end of Mediterranean  fishermen in the harbor, photos covering the walls of people who have visited and sang at Trieste on Saturdays with the piano.  There are about ten open tables inside right now, a slow period right now, and I am sitting next to the door feeling a cool breeze while also sort of sitting in the sun.

The menu is on the wall on four different large cream-colored signs with items some of which I will have to look up later, things I might have heard of in cosmopoliton magazines or Neil Simon plays or short stories but of what definition I am really not sure.

We are on the corner of Vallejo and Grant.  I look down the street behind and I am looking down Grant toward Chinatown.  I look up the street behind me on my right and I am looking at Tower Hardware.

Interesting spellings on the menu signs...Old World?  New York?  Hard to tell.  A great place for a writer who doesn't mind the tourists.
author: Jo S.

description:
Not Great. Not Bad. 
It is a shame to be near a view and not have one, and they still manage to woo the tourists...Thank You Sky Magazine!

Grab the coffee to go and hit the pier. Trust Me.
author: Luke H.

description:
3.5 Stars
They make excellent drip house coffee. It's too bad that their large cups are alittle bit small...I think they are 16 oz instead of 20 oz?Also their coffee is alittle pricey,too.I paid $4.60 for 2 cups.I thought it was odd that the barista asked me if I wanted my coffee black or with milk because usually they just pour your coffee & you add the milk yourself. I told him that I wanted coffee w/ milk but he forgot & over-filled the cup. He realized his mistake & poured the overage back into the coffee pot instead of pouring it out. Huh?Also,they brew the drip coffee using a commerical drip machine where the coffee pot sits on a burner.Sits on a burner?and the pot was noticably coffee stained.The place was kind of old & dirty,but the coffee is excellent.Plus! they had the pink fake sugar packets Sweet N Low. It irritates me when so called fancy coffee houses don't carry Sweet N Low because of it's potential cancer linkage? I'm glad Caffe Trieste don't try to limit MY FREEDOM TO CHOOSE.
author: Winston W.

description:
The espresso is top notch and the service is decent. I've gone here for years and have never had a bad experience with the Baristas. These Barista's constantly deal with the bums and tourist all day long. If your looking for service that kiss' your ass you aren't going to find it here. 

If you looking for quality coffee and some history of SF. This is the place.

Or hey, "Go back to L.A.!" Come on.
author: Matt S.

description: It's like taking a step back in time! Coffees are great but the real draw is the people watching and the great memorabilia on the walls.
author: Anita L.

description:
The Africano is solid.  2 generous shots of espresso and about and equal parts of extra-rich (where-do-they-find-this-stuff) milk.  This place is an institution.

The only reason why I hold back on the fifth star is that I think they need to get more on the ball with cleaning and busing the tables.
author: Moe J.

description:
Great atmosphere. It is one of my favorite coffee shops in the city. 

There is a coffee shop right across the street from my brothers house but we would rather walk 4 blocks to come here for the wonderful coffee!

They make a strong cup of expresso - much better than any starbucks!
author: Emily W.

description:
Boy did I feel like a tool after finding out the script for The Godfather was written here.  I'm so glad I brought my "large-and-in-charge" hardcover copy with me to read pretty much everytime I've been there over the past few weeks.  I was wondering why people were snickering at me...along with those tourists inconspiculously taking snapshots.  What are the odds?

The service here could be better.  I think it is entirely possible to have 2 people serving customers to make the line go just a LITTLE faster.  They make a damn good cup of coffee though, and I love the live music on Saturday afternoons.  After listening closely to the band, a song I thought was a traditional Italian ballad was actually the "Hawaii Five-O" theme song.
author: Kerry D.

description: I liked the atmosphere. Kind of worn in, like a comfy sweatshirt. This is definitely a locals place, so be prepared to feel a little out of place. Once, you get settled, its an interesting experience. Old men sitting around talking about the crazy world..with no where really to go.  And thats great. Leave the busy starbucks mentality at the door and double soy latte whatever at the door. this place is real, real simple.
author: Stefan M.

description:
Not a lot of cafes can properly put together a good cup of cappuccino.  I usually end up with lattes, too much milk, sometimes with milk foam that look like soap suds.  This is never an issue with Trieste.  Cappuccino here is always good.

Thank you, Trieste!
author: Erick ..

description:
Pros: 
They were cool about us taking up their big middle table for four hours to play Mah Jong (We *are* the local color).

The wine is cheap and not too bad.

Guys at the counter were laid back and fun.

Excellent juke box full of jazz and opera.

Cons:
Not a good food selection, especially around dinner time, especially for vegetarian options.

My espresso and Irish cream drink was barely warm.

The guys behind the counter were a little too laid back and disorganized.
author: Lauren H.

description: What the hell?? I ordered an ice coffee. They took the hot pot of coffee and just poured it over ice. the melted in minutes. Lame.
author: Dave R.

description: I got an americano for $2.55. Definitely one of the best places that I have had coffee. I'd say it's even better than Cafe Strada in Berkeley. I only wish that they took card.
author: Grace G.

description: Men and women scribbled something on papers while others busy with their laptops... *typing sounds everywhere....* I felt so out of place. There's a bunch of writers when I was there. A man or two with their manuscripts... Tense situations as if the deadline was on their throat already. It's a nice atmosphere being surrounded by such talented and creative people! Cappuccino was okay. Table was decorated with mozaic tiles. Cute... Would come back for the cool productive ambiance. Next time, I'll bring my laptop fully charge so I can write as well
author: Cliff T.

description:
There are a few institutions that make San Francisco and North Beach what it was and what it continues to be, today. Trieste is one of them.

Yes, if you go on Saturday morning at 10AM there will be a line as long as Mama's filled with tourists and yes, there are a few freaks hidden in the corners. But, if you go as part of your morning routine or in the afternoon for the odd book-reading session, your visit will be vastly different.
author: Eric ..

description:
Admittedly, I was drawn here by the history.  There's still some part of the beat generation-enamored college kid in me who, whenever he's in North Beach, finds himself gravitating to City Lights and other Kerouac / Ginsberg / Ferlinghetti haunts nearby. I'm sure the locals are sick of it (unless they're all folks like me who've simply taken it one step further, succumbing to their nostalgia and just moving into the neighborhood to soak up the vibe all day, every day). 

It wasn't until my most recent trip, however, that I finally stopped by the storied Trieste.  And, you know, discount my rating however you like for viewing the place through tourist-colored glasses.  I'm sure if I lived in the neighborhood and just wanted a quick cup of coffee and a good danish on my way to work, I'd see it differently. 

Anyhow, long review short: my fiancee grabbed an espresso and some blueberry coffee cake (which I nibbled on -- good stuff!  Moist, just the right amount of sweet, and good size for the price).  I noticed that the Trieste serves a New York egg cream (essentially carbonated chocolate milk, and maybe the best thing ever), and couldn't resist the chance to finally try one.  They were nice enough to make something of a production of its construction, which was cool ... I was able to see how it was made, and they seemed to understand that, hey -- this is a beverage with a little bit of colloquial history, and should be treated with a smirking sort of reverence. 

As for ambiance, I give high marks.  On Saturday afternoons, the Trieste occasionally hosts live music and other performances, and there was a great little band playing traditional Italian and eastern European  folks songs when we walked up.  I poked in long enough to grab my beverages and ogle the literary wall of fame, then grabbed a seat at a sidewalk table with my fiancee. We whittled away an hour or so just enjoying the nice day, listening to the music and enjoying our food, people watching on a sunny afternoon in San Francisco.  Doesn't get too much better than that.
author: Sean F.

description:
I like it.
Coppola writing his Godfather screenplay, probably because Jack Kerouac used to hang there. Joe DiMaggio having some espresso.

The workers have always been more than nice, a good book and others conversations tidbits on a foggy sat night is a nice mind break.
author: Rhubarb M.

description: Enjoyed a pot of tea! Coffee is also good.
author: Mrs. Dawn H.

description: Locals' hole, nice quiet vibe on a Sunday. There were easily five people writing the next great American novel....papers strewn all about, frantic writing and rewriting, muttering to themselves. The espresso did the trick though, so thumbs up.
author: Matthew S.

description:
This place has been staked out for years but I am compelled to write after reading some of these recent reviews.  I am less then a month back from Italy, drank espresso and cappuccino til my blood boiled every day while there, and the first cup drank back in the states was in their doors.  The results were not shocking...its legit.  

Long lines, slow down your life for 5 minutes and read a paper.  Too many tourists, what's new in North Beach.  Laid back service and mediocre food, its a caffe.  This place holds a level of integrity and legitimacy in neighborhood that is desperately short of such.  I respect all the other opinions out there but I think the character of this place deserves some props and some extra time to reflect on where it somes from.  If its still not your thing, check out some edger shops on Valencia or in locals only hoods out of the guide books.  Portrero has a great place on 18th with more mags then you need and some good tunes to pair.

Have to give props to the piano in the back at Trieste.  Makes me want to pick it up again.
author: Porfirio R.

description: This is another place my mom has been taking me to since i was a little one. We come on Saturdays to listen to the singing and have a coffee, or pastry. It has a very crowded small feeling, which after living in Italy myself i absolutely LOVE because it is very typical. The people who work there are wonderful and we have come to know them over the years. They sell coffee and t-shirts, etc in an adjoining place next door. Love it, good experience.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Best espresso in the city. Closest thing I have had quality wise outside of Europe. Caffe Trieste is an original "hole in the wall" cafe located in the heart of North Beach, but what original place in North Beach isn't? The place is a dump but nobody cares. The espresso is that good.

They have pictures and press clippings of some of the older days of the cafe and the neighborhood. If you even take the time to find it, a picture of Francis Ford Coppola writing some of the original screenplay to "The Godfather" inside the cafe drinking espresso. Real SF history.

Honestly when you can have espresso this good, why do people go to Starbucks?
author: Xavier P.

description:
Cafe Trieste is a place with a long and rich history. I have heard many of the rumors/superlatives - "First espresso cafe on the West Coast", "Best Coffee outside of Italy", "Kerouac's home away from home", etc, etc, etc. I don't know if all of them are true or not, but I do know that most of the pieces fit with this place. 

Most of them. First of all, are you in or are you out? I sometimes feel like I need to be worried about sitting in someones seat! If you are not a resident of North Beach getting coffee here on your morning walk to the financial district or stopping by for a beer after work, you might not be 'in' and the service can be a bit gruff. I remember better service here when I used to come several years ago. Recently I have starting going back to San Francisco 6 or so times per year and I stop here every time. The attitude of the staff has changed over the last 10 years. 

All that aside, 9 out of 10 times I have been here, I strike up a conversation with friendly locals and tourists alike while drinking my Americano or cappuccino or straight espresso. The coffee is very good - but to say its the best, well, Im not sure i would go that far. This is a must stop for anyone from out of town when spending an afternoon touring through North Beach or after dinner somewhere on Columbus.
author: Jon H.

description:
I guess it's an alright spot. I am currently working with a fascinating media team and we're using this place as a setting for a few episodes!

Their bathrooms are ok, but what's up with the towel dispenser? Apparently there are none. A large selection of menu items awaits you here, and seating is slightly under average sizing, I'd say.
author: Carl Z.

description: some of my fondest memories were made in every crevace of cafe trieste! every barista is the friendliest person you will meet! the live music on the weekends is so special. people pour their hearts out here and the artistry flows as much as the espresso! one of the greatest spots on earth! best drinks in sf, great eats, best juke box (they have opera dude, i mean, come on!!!), lovely human beings! for those of you who 5stared this haven, you totally get it!
author: Qui K.

description:
Definitely a café worth going to in North Beach. The coffee is great, the atmosphere is great as well and it's loaded with history! Many of greatest creative people of our time worked there- from Kerouac to Ginsberg and Francis Ford Coppola. 

It's a tiny place and sometimes it's tough to get a table, which is a pain especially when you want to work.

But, it's worth checking out for the history alone, but the coffee is great too! It's a win-win!
author: Tom B.

description:
I'm actually going here tomorrow night for the first time in awhile, so I decided to peruse the yelp files on a quest for curiousity's sake to see what you all thought about the place. 

One line got my attention, written by Eric G., "The real kicker is that they do not serve soy milk." Yes, Eric, that is the kicker, and if you are a vegan or lactose intolerant, yes go elsewhere. But if you are neither of those things, and you want to find a crew of coffee and dairy enthusiasts, people uninhibited by dietary restrictions and popular pseudoscience, stalwart generalists opposed to compromise when it comes to coffee or anything else, then come to Trieste where the coffee flows like wine. 

I might have to update this tomorrow night, but probably not.
author: Dibital N.

description:
On my visit to San Francisco I was looking for a place to have a good coffee and enjoy some laid back music. Accidentally and very luckily I ended up in Caffe Trieste.  Following a great yelp review of Graffeo coffee I told myself, why don't I go there and get myself a pound of that good stuff. Though I am more of a tea drinker, when I do have a coffee, I'd rather prefer a good one. After getting some coffee for me and my friend I asked one of the guys in Graffeo for a suggestion of a nice place, where I can seat down, enjoy the atmosphere and hang with people; after pondering for a minute he told me...why don't you go to Caffe Trieste, that's the place for you. And boy was he right on the money...

great coffee and the way it supposed to be, most of all some great music, I hit the jackpot, Cafe Americain was performing there on that Wednesday playing some beautiful mandolin music and I had one of the best evenings in San Francisco.
author: Hamid E.

description:
Where else can you sit next to a guy wearing orange goggles and matching orange tennis shoes? 


They have really tasty coffee and friendly servers as well.
author: melissa h.

description:
I grabbed a coffee and pastry here last night.  After many drive-bys, I can see why it's so busy.  The coffee is stellar.  They even frothed my drip coffee!  Too bad I'm lactose intolerant...

Expect to pay WAY too much, but you get what you pay for.
author: Simon Y.

description:
When ever I get sick of working from home, and feel like I'm climbing the walls. I  grab my laptop and head on down to Trieste for a coffee. 
I never get all that much work done here, but the people watching, and chatting to the locals is second to none. The coffee's not too bad either but it can be hit and miss depending on who's making it.  Free wifi means I can con myself that I'm actually working. Also come check out the fantastic live music, and feel like you've been transported to the set of a surreal crazy movie.
author: MissSkip Z.

description: This was a highlight of my amazing trip to SF -- up there with walking across the golden gate bridge, alcatraz on a sunny day, $3 lunch of dim sum in chinatown.  I was told the best thing to get was their latte, which comes in a glass, and it was absolutely delicious.  the vibe here is amazing, even without knowing of it's colorful past.
author: Benny G.

description: Don't really find its coffee unique, plus staff is an importance consideration for an overall coffee experience for me as well, and don't find their staff impressive.
author: Michelle K.

description: Best Italian coffee (espresso) in all of San Francisco. Order a latte and have a great conversation with just about anyone in the place. Awesome place to hang out especially in the sun at one of the outside tables. I always stop by Trieste whenever I'm in North Beach or frankly just heading in the downtown direction.
author: Julie Z.

description: Solid, authentic neighborhood cafe. Strong coffee. Nicely done, sir.
author: Avata R.

description: A latte does not have soy, and good coffee is for girls
author: Joe D.

description:
I love that this place gets bad reviews. It's already too crowded...
The best is going there on a Sunday morning... getting a good cup of coffee.... and hanging with some of the characters. I miss NYC... and this place reminds me of the East Village. You can get into great conversations with the staff... with the other customers... you just hang, don't be an ass... and you'll meet good folk. 
The people who give it bad reviews sound pretty uninformed... one goof says coffee is coffee... it all tastes the same... Really? Could that guy just stick to reviewing car washes or something....? Someone else was whining about the food? The pastries are the BEST! ... someone else was whining about being charged money for paper cups? Hello....??? I love that they are part of the solution instead of being part of the problem!!! Seriously... would you prefer they gave you a free styrofoam cup? People who complain about Cafe Trieste...just shouldn't go.... you won't ever get this place and are the reason there is a happy shiny Starbucks on every corner.
author: Theresa N.

description:
I responded to a help wanted add on craigslist, next thing i know i'm working at the most famous espresso bar in San Francisco.  

What can I say about this place?  All the desserts are worth the $4.75.  Its an amazing place.  The service can be a little rude, but its because the line seems to grow faster than the seconds that pass and customers need to understand this.  PLEASE have your money ready and when you order. Nothing backs up the line worse than a person digging through their pockets for 4 cents.

I have worked in customer service for years and hope to bring a more possitive light to the sevice.  The old gritty atmosphere is what makes it, so it is a bit dirty(something else i hope to improve)but the history is in the dirt. some might not understand that and to you my advice is dont come by. If you do get it, check out the Saloon across the street, the oldest bar in SF.

The Trieste is a tribute to the way things used to be.  If the crowded atmosphere bothers you, you obviosly never been to New York, or a classic greek diner.  Perhaps the countryside is more for you.  The line may be long but the best damn coffee awaits at the other end.  And as for the homless and drunks, tell me 3 places in SF where you dont see them.  And what is seen as rudeness is actually the edge it takes to work at a place like this.  ive been there a month and ive met some crazy characters, met some famouse people, and over all ive been having the time of my life.  So stop by and see me, I'm Tom(The Plantman)and Im there most weekend nights after 4pm.
author: thomas f.

description:
This is my all time favorite coffee shop. I have been coming here since I was a kiddie and I keep coming back every time I am in the area. It truly reminds me of a coffee shop you would find in Europe...funky with a lot of character. 

I would highly recommend the Mocha with homemade whipped cream. I usually do not like mochas because they are too sweet, but they make it just right here. They also have glasses of good tasting table wine for 2 bucks!

 This is a great place to sit back, sip on some tasty beverages and people watch. If you haven't been here, you're seriously missing out on the best espresso in SF.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: OLD SCHOOL and I like it!! Going here harkens back to the 1960s. Seriously I think of writers/poets/musicians that hung out here back in the day.  The interior looks like it hasn't been updated since then. They have live music sometimes and the older North Beach crowd likes to hang out here, sprinkled in are some ironic writer types and regular folks.  They make a mean cappuccino and have a nice selection of pastries, focaccia  slices.  Worth a visit!
author: Ka C.

description: Except as an historical artifact, why would you go here? Unpleasant baristas and less than mediocre coffee. Pass.
author: Denise N.

description:
The first night we walked in, in a good mood after a great meal somewhere else, and got glared at by the help. So we walked out. A couple nights later, we sat down to perfunctory coffee and dessert. The guy was rude, or at least abrupt, again, and had an incident with a different customer. 

There's a fan hovering over the food area with possibly the filthiest fanguard I've ever seen in an eating establishment.  I have mildly dirty fanguards at home, so it's not the sight of a little dust that bothers me. It's the realization it hasnt been cleaned in years, not days or weeks,  leaving to doubt what else doesnt get cleaned.   

It's old San Francisco with cool walls and tables in back, but with employees who suck out most of the inherent charm. With a hundred cafes within walking distance, why folks choose to catch a buzz here escapes me.
author: Matt S.

description: Sucks because they don't have non-dairy creamer and were quite rude when I asked them if they would ever carry it. Some of us actually get very sick from milk products and it would be nice if they could at least offer lactose-free milk. Something, anything would be nice. I won't be back.
author: Candace C.

description: A couple of weeks ago I went to meet, The man, The Myth, Suman G. for beers in North Beach. He happened to be getting his study on at Caf Treiste.  Not to far off the beaten path but not a haven for tourists either. As I sipped my Caf Au Lait I started to dig on the art work and thought I would peruse the photos on the wall.  The place is obviously a neighborhood joint. Then I came of cross a familiar face. "Nuh ahnn...is that, that Francis Ford Coppola!" Come to find about he wrote the Godfather in here. Are you kidding me. Nice! I'm definitely making it a point to return and try the food.
author: Mingus R.

description: Great coffee, friendly crowd, and free wireless!  And cheap wine!  You can't go wrong here.  Plus great music on Saturdays.
author: Rose Q.

description:
Caffe Trieste has great history, Coppola apparently wrote the Godfather screen play here, Ginsberg and Kerouac probably came here for a cup of coffee at one point. (City lights book store is right down the street)

If you are new to the city, try it out just to see what it is all about, but don't expect much.

I have been to this coffee shop over 30 times.  I really wanted to like with place, especially because of the history, but I have no choice but to give it this review:

The staff is EXTREMELY rude.  I am always very nice, polite and patient but the clerks are really rude for no reason at all.  I have been made fun of, ignored, and overcharged.  It is like you are not ordering your drinks from a Barista but from a very annoyed bartender.

The customers are either two things
1) Tourist who want to experience the cool North Beach beatnik environment but soon find out that it has long past
2) Washed up Beatniks (who are now in their 60-70s) or want to be young hipster beatniks who think that retracing Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg's footsteps is going to help them become better writers

If you can get past the annoying customers and the clerk which will treat you like shit, then the Coffee is often quite good.  I believe the coffee is good because they roast it on site, so it really is fresh.  If you are going to buy their coffee by the pound you should really buy it here to get the freshest roast, if you buy a pound of their coffee at the Safeway in the Marina it will NOT taste as good due to the freshness.


More memorable moments at the Trieste:
- I asked for soymilk and one clerk says to another "Soymilk? what the hell is that shit, it is not even milk, who would drink that crap?"  (a simple, "sorry we don't have soymilk" would of done just fine)
- (this happens almost every time I go there) I stand there and I am ignored for the first 2 minutes
- Once saw a 60 year old want to be beatnik have a heart attack at the corner
- A 60 year old deathly thin beatnik woman (beatnik because she was dressed in all back and was wearing a black French beret) stood up and announced that the "Bill of rights was not worth wiping her ass with"
author: spazzy p.

description:
Oh...and i just love the bitching about the lack of soy milk.  i'll be disappointed if they ever cave and buy soy milk--you don't make real cappuccino with that shit.

i'm also quite amused that so many people seem to believe that the staff are being rude to them.  How self-important of you!  If you put up with scores of likewise self-important tourists who seem to think that paying two dollars for a coffee entitles them to basically shit on you, you probably wouldn't be keen on playing mickey mouse either.

Bottom line--Trieste is Trieste.  If you don't like that, go somewhere else, but don't whine about it...
author: J. Brandon L.

description:
Go in there and stand in line. You'll see many interesting North Beach characters sitting around gabbing...Very charming. It's a scene you like and want to experience. You order an espresso drink. It is made quickly and given to you in a charming little glass...nothing pretentious. You notice that the espresso machine or the floor or the bathrooms may not have been cleaned recently, but eh, so what? You sit down. You taste the extremely bitter espresso drink or just-as-bitter cup of coffee. You've had better. You may have had better very recently, like the last time you went to gert a cup of coffee anywhere else. You do your best to drink it even tho it doesn't taste too good. The atmosphere is so alive that you want to stay. Was that an Alioto sitting in the corner? Was that Lawrence Ferlinghetti over there??Surely it isn't all just way-too-self-important regulars and tourists in here.... You finish the coffee. You walk down Vallejo Street and your stomache starts churning. You walk towards your house. Hope that you live nearby, because you might get sick. Maybe you will get lucky and not be sick. You think back to the way the "barristas" emphaticaly slammed the tiny spooon down on the counter next to your drink. They were so confident. The drink MUST have been good. You were wrong--not them. The Trieste makes great coffee. Right? WRONG!!! THis place might have been progressive when it opened 50 years ago, but since then people have grown to appreciate good tasting, not burned or bitter coffee drinks. They expect their barristas to be nice, not arrogant and tip demading.  BITTER,  LOUSY COFFEE AND ARROGANT BARRISTAS EQUALS NO REPEAT BUSINESS FROM ME!
Nice atmosphere....Go there and hang out. (bring a drink in from somewhere else!)One star for that..
Needs a year long bath....Maybe the giant roaches in the bathroom will disappear after that.
Needs to improve their coffee so that it doesn't taste as if it was made by a two year old.
author: james b.

description: Oh my lord.  I cannot believe how bad the service is here.   We stopped by this afternoon to grab a cup of coffee and get out of the rain for a few minutes.  There was a huge line of people, which we patiently waited in. Once we got our coffee, but before we paid, one of the guys decided it was time to count all of the money in the cash register.  This huge line of people was standing there waiting on him.  The other guy (who seemed horribly salty from the beginning) couldn't ring us up until the guy finished counting.  Here's the kicker - while we're all standing there, the guy making the drinks doesn't even start taking drink orders from the people behind us.   Everyone was literally just standing there watching the other guy count the money.  If you need to do a shift change, have more than one cash drawer and count in the back!  It was just ridiculous.
author: Squirrel L.

description: Just gave the Market Street location a rather dismal review and realized I've never commented on "old faithful." This place is a San Francisco standard, better than an episode of my favorite TV show. I have not had a better cappuccino anywhere in town and no place can match the good old SF North Beach vibe.
author: Robert M.

description: The atmosphere is just so-so, but they make a mean espresso - very dark and rich.  A great way to cap off dinner in North Beach!
author: Tia W.

description: I like that Cafe Trieste has history. I do not like that the barista was rude and that they didn't have soy milk as an option (come on people..it's San Francisco - give a girl an option). The coffee drink I got was alright  but a bit too sweet for my liking (it was a hot beverage with frothed milk and amaretto which came highly recommended). I think my favorite thing about the whole experience is that it kept my hands warm while walking in the rain..
author: Natalie G.

description: This place was my essential e-portal while I was getting moved into my new internet-less nob hill apartment. Seems like nothin's free these days, save for the wifi here. Iced mocha is, regrettably, made with powder :(  but the baristas were very nice about me data-squatting and were really fun to talk to.
author: Alex B.

description:
I've never had a better cup of coffee anywhere. Simply the best. 

Okay (here's to those that try to compare Trieste with their taste(s) for Starbucks, and all the other coffee places opened by people who really have no knowledge of what they're doing): that's not what coffee is suppose to be. Espresso is finely ground; firmly packed -- dripped as a thick/almost syrup drink-- it takes longer than the "little bit stronger than brewed coffee" that is passed for what goes into those drinks bought elsewhere. Nonfat milk does not foam and is not conducive to a good latte, cappuccino -- not ever! Whipped cream is thick and put on [Mochas] with a spoon. Iced coffee is over cubes. Blenders are for booze.  

Though I miss the original owners -- she always used to greet me with "Cece" and give me an extra large piece of wine cake... the young men that work there currently are probably the nicest; quickest thinking, get it right barristas in the City -- they're just really busy and I have watched (not regulars, but...) customers hem and hah ... because their day is blown, for they truly believe soy is suppose to be in a coffee drink -- and being behind them, I find myself thinking more impatient thoughts about them than I have ever witnessed one of Trieste's employees letting on to being annoyed (facially or verbally). The coffee is always fresh roasted/not stock-piled for months... 

When I lived away from SF, Trieste air-mailed lbs and lbs of beans to me wherever I lived... in the interim, my Xmas shopping list has become pretty easy -- I buy/ship coffee to friends. When friends come to visit SF, Trieste (not Starbucks,etc.) is where they request to go. Gladly!
author: Katherine H.

description: It doesn't get any BEATER than this.  This is the real deal blend of past and present North Beach Beat culture.  The coffee is not my favorite, but the atmosphere and clientele banter provides the realy eye-ear candy buzz.  Drop in to start the day, revitalize the afternoon or end the mind-bending evening in San Francisco.
author: Ken K.

description: The place looked good from the outside. But inside I found people in costumers trying to look cool and smart, the service sucked (perhaps because I'm a tourist and not a local?) and the place was filthy. The table I had to sit to put sugar in my coffee was so nasty, as if it hadn't been cleaned all day. There are many superb coffee shops in SF. This is not one of them. Will not be back there.
author: Keli S.

description: A good place for meeting someone on a first date.  The coffee's among the best in North Beach.  On Saturday afternoons they have live music, but you're not allowed to order less than a certain amount if you come in then.
author: Rego S.

description: The coffee is pretty good...but since I hate all of North Beach my rating is tainted by that.
author: Rich S.

description: What an eclectic and wonderful spot! Great coffee and atmosphere. I now want to go back to Italy even more.
author: Jason A.

description: Stepped in tonight and noticed the beatnik feel emanating not from City Lights but from beans being brewed up. Not much of a coffee drinker, but  the smell led me here and I was quite happy with the smiles I saw and colors keeping me awake. I'll be back.
author: Tomasz F.

description: making coffee and serving at local speed i get what i want, when i want it, quickly. thanks guys, i love living here to drink this coffee
author: Justin K.

description: Cool place and really authentic.  Great espresso, my only problem is that I am a soy latte drinker and they DO NOT HAVE SOY!  What!  Who doesn't have SOY!!  Other than that, it was a great time with friends outside.
author: Jackie B.

description: Who are these people that hang out at Trieste day and night?  They don't seem to have jobs, yet I can't believe they are all independently wealthy, so I've concluded they must be in the same rent controlled apartment they've lived in for 25 years, and they just hang out at Trieste all day and somehow manage to make enough cash on the side to pay their $300/mo. rent.  And their 10 coffees a day.  Yes, I know, I'm just jealous.  Oh, and Trieste has good coffee and great people watching, which is probably why they hang out there.
author: Erica G.

description:
I love Caffe Trieste. I spend a considerable amount of time in North Beach, and when people ask me where to go that isn't touristy but rather true to North Beach's quirky characters and old school Italian, I point them to the direction of Caffe Trieste. 
The coffee is good, the service friendly, but it's the overall vibe of Caffe Trieste that brings me back. Today for example...a rare day in the city where it's actually HOT. I went to Caffe Trieste for an iced tea. My friend and I sat outside amidst some kooky locals--a toothless old lady who dresses like she's 20, a poet who gave me a poem about a bull fighter, and an old guy who never seems to leave this cafe. So I suppose what I really love about Trieste is that is feels very representative of North Beach--you'll see families, yuppies, crazy local people everyone comes to know...they're usually all meshed together at Caffe Trieste.
And if you don't really appreciate this sort of experience like I do, and just want a good cup of joe, well...this is the place for it too.
author: Sophie D.

description:
on wednesday or thursday night this week, when it was so warm out that people were still in their daytime skirts and smiles, i sat outside at caffe trieste with a couple of friends, and watched as the customers proceeded to drag every piece of furniture that was not attached to the floor out onto the sidewalk.  the caffe often has a band in the evening time, and on the weekends it is a group of proper ladies playing italian opera music on a group of about 10 or so instruments.  this night, however, it was a four piece string group of guitar, acoustic base, standup base and a mandolin that was playing for tips, and they dragged their chairs out to the street as well.

they started with an old southern sounding version of "summertime" accompanied by a lady who i was told was the owner of Jazz at Pearls down Columbus a bit, and with her patterned dress and thick, lugubrious alto she killed it from sitting in her seat.  people walking down by on their collective way to elsewhere paused more than a beat to crowd around, as the quintet ambled their way through some recognizable old songs, and some i didn't know.  

the coffee is always fantastic here, and living a block away, this and Washington Square have become extensions of my living room, so I am regular enough to know the names of most of the staff.  i expect great coffee and friendly, interesting people of all ages and kinds when i stop by, including the local flavor and mildly insane who populate any neighborhood if you look closely enough and can actually hear what they say.  but on a night like that, with the songstress beaming and shaking her hips as she let loose and washed beautiful trills into our ears, the band shaking and dancing, and people still wearing the sunshine on their faces, it was all i could do to remember to eat my gelato from down the street before it melted.
author: matt w.

description: Ehh.. what's the craze about? It looks a little dark inside, and there are too many wanna-be hipsters here, not even real hipsters. Too many tourists now, too. The foccacia sandwich was good and it came with juicy tomatoes on the side, but when I asked it to be heated up, the cashier put it in a microwave. ?? Sandwich in a microwave? There was a toaster grill which he used later, but ehh.. I don't drink coffee so I can't talk about that. I think I will try the foccacia sandwiches at the Bohemian Cigar Shop Cafe.
author: O K.

description: The world's greatest cafe. Also, Coppola wrote much of the screenplay to "The Godfather" here. Amazing espresso.
author: Adam Z.

description: A nice place to sit and have a coffee. Lots of characters and one of the best cups of coffee in North Beach.  I don't recommend the place for women though.  The boys are hounds there and will definitely harass you.
author: Matt B.

description: As I sat there sipping on my coffee, I was surprised when I overhead a guy speaking on the phone in English.  For a minute I thought I was in Italy.  This place is so authentic, I made me feel like I was in another country.  The coffee, drinks, and food are so authentic.  The place is plastered with framed photographs of Italians, and it is worn with care (ie - small bathroom with a little lock and door you had to kick open).  I love the feeling of this Italian gem.
author: Julie R.

description: I like this cafe a little better than some of the places right on Columbus. There are some good pics on the walls and it's a little more straightforward than some of the places nearby. You can get a good piece of pizza on a paper plate without all the frills/cost of the more formal caffes nearby. If you are a coffee/espresso lightweight like me, their espresso might be a bit much for you. There were a lot of people around with their Powerbooks, typing furiously and looking like they were writing the Great American Novel. It was a little kitschy, I guess; I'd probably try somewhere else for a North Beach snack/respite next time.
author: Kathleen B.

description: I've been told over and over again by my friends that this place has some of the best coffee around, and it really does. Considering this was coming from coffee snobs, I had very high expectations. Caffe Trieste did not disappoint. The great coffee, friendly service, and unique history of this place makes it better than the average coffee joint.
author: Kristen R.

description: My dad comes here all the time whenever he is in the area and gets a coffee.  This place seriously makes Starbucks and the likes of it taste like....toilet water.  Always jam packed here with people lounging outside or inside the cafe.  Very cool place that has years of history behind it.
author: Anna H.

description: This place is the bomb.  I don't know what else to call it.  I started coming here when I started staying over at my boyfriend's house right up the hill from it.  It's on my way from his place to the bus--perfect.  The coffee is delicious and really strong, and I love how they top it with steamed milk!  Their pastries are really good too...I broke down and got one the other day when I was a little hungover.  To top it off, the people who you wait in line with are NOT the starbucks bankers....they are normal, everyday people who are not on their cell phones or blackberrys, and every time I have been here someone has started a friendly conversation with me.  Now that's what I call a nice start to my day!
author: Emma H.

description: Quaint and charming place to strike up a conversation with a neighbor while sipping a perfect mocha made with real whipped cream. The pastries didn't look so inspiring, but the coffee and ambience was perfect for a quick one on the way to somewhere else.
author: Amy J.

description: No soy milk option in the past, not in the present, and not in the future.  It's the classic Italian "we're such coffee purists and we know what's best for you" bullshit.  Great, I'll go somewhere else.  F you.
author: Bob G.

description: An original and a classic.  Delicious lattes with Old San Francisco flair.
author: Rebecca S.

description: star for good coffee...star for speedy service...don't get discouraged by the line..it moves fairly quickly...another star for the history it has....star for the interesting music....star for friendly service...even with my million requests...minus a star for the sloppy food display (not very appealing)....minus another star for sometimes trying to pass off pre-made drinks...
author: Hen A.

description:
1 extra star for the history, decor, and live music. As for the rest...

I really want to love this place. 

It  was the first place I discovered in San Francisco where I could crash-land, read a book, or spend an hour or two with a friend. I used to love it, because compared with places nearly anywhere else outside of SF it really is a great cafe. But this was before I moved here two years ago, and I've learned a lot since then.  

What I didn't know then is that there are a plethora of amazing local cafes in this city, all of which offer what Trieste and its regulars seem to think it is. It's easy to believe that many of the 4- and 5-star reviews are coming from people who just don't know what else is out there in this lovely city.

The coffee tastes better at Blue Bottle Cafe - the last couple times I've been to Trieste the house coffee was not only not-great, it was actually pretty awful. Burnt, watered-down, and, worst of all, not hot. I can't speak for the espresso drinks, as I'm a Dale Cooper black-coffee-and-cherry-pie kind of guy.  

Blue Danube is a more comfortable study or lounging spot - I don't know if it's a greed thing, but Trieste has packed so many tables in that you literally cannot fit in between them to get a seat. On top of that, there are only 4 outlets for laptops in the entire place. 

Cafe La Vie is better for the friendly baristas - simply put, the service here sucks. This is the biggest reason I avoid this place now. I've never once gotten so much as a "Hello" out of the baristas there, and I've got a good rapport going at all my other regular places. I'm not looking for someone to kiss my ass and I don't expect my regular caffeine-pusher to be my new bff, but there's a base level of bonhomie to be expected anyplace that's supposed to be a comfortable hang-out / third-place kind of spot.There's a general vibe of disaffected surliness here, and I don't know whether those guys really dislike their job that much or if it's some kind of lame keepin-it-real affectation. Either way, that's fine at a bar or a diner, but that doesn't fly at a neighborhood cafe. 

Lastly, Ritual already steals the title as mecca for the ultra-douchiest. Trieste douches, you are past your prime. 

I was talking to a friend about this last night, and I understand why Cafe Trieste and much of North Beach in general are as they are. No matter how many locals spurn the place, there will always be a steady stream of tourists to support it. It's the last reason I kept going, I actually like interacting with visitors, especially all the international tourists that come into Trieste so often. But when nostalgia alone is enough to keep something profitable, everything else will inevitably slip. From what I can tell and have heard from locals, Cafe Trieste has been slipping for 20 years now. 


My general rant about most North Beach landmarks applies here: Kerouac, Bukowski, Scorsese, blah-blah. Mel Brooks said it best when he wrote Spaceballs: 

"What the hell am I lookin' at?...
Now. You're looking at now sir, everything that happens now is happening now. 
What happened to then? 
We passed it. 
When? 
Just now. We're at now, now. 
Go back to then. 
When? 
Now. 
Now? 
Now! 
I can't. 
Why? 
We missed it. 
When? 
Just now. 
When will then be now? 
...Soon."

In 2009, this cafe is weak-sauce.
author: david p.

description: This is everything you'd need short of going to Italy and drinking an espresso of cappucino.  They have WiFi!  Good place for literary practices, it is in the mortar.  All of the poets go /went here, they have live musica and usually have opera blaring from the jukebox.
author: Angel Q.

description: I know this place is a neighborhood icon. Honestly, I wanted my first time there to be on a Saturday afternoon during the regualr live music sessions. But I wenty on a week night. The place is always packed with colorful locals, and the coffee's good. But the pastries seemed pretty average, and the lighting in there during the evening is pretty crappy. I think I'll go back, however, during the weekend afternoon rush.
author: Andrew K.

description:
i like the fact that this place is old school italian...they serve up some decent espresso, pastries and panini. i can bring my laptop here (free wi-fi) and work in the corner all day long (like i am *working* right now...teehee!).  they have an eclectic collection of music you've never heard on the jukebox and sometimes live jazz at night...great place to go after having proper italian dinner in North Beach. i like this location better than all the newer ones that have opened in the city and east bay. 

great people watching...you never know what kind of characters will be hanging out here between the tourists and the locals...today the guy in line in front of me asked the guy behind the counter if he was jack kerouac's son (he must be since this IS north beach after all). his comeback (with an accent i couldn't place) was..."well not legitimately"

less one star for using paper plates. they wouldn't do that in italy.
author: Isabel C.

description: Not much point, really, in reviewing a piece of history, plus I confess I went there on sort of a pilgrimage. But I was pleasantly surprised by the excellence of both the cappuccino grande and the chocolate croissant we ordered. Add to that the cheerfully grungy ambience, the garrulous customers, and the corny guy behind the counter in their adjoining store. Delightful.
author: Tony K.

description: Yeah, I know this place has a lot of history, but its really not an excuse for discriminating on out of towners. I took a couple friends here on Caffe Trieste's 50th anniversary weekend. Supposedly, prices were at 35cents for a cup of coffee, as a friend visited earlier in the day with the report. However, we ended up paying $5 for ours. In fact, the person in front of us actually didn't pay at all. Obviously, you either have to know someone, or give a secret handshake as we never figured out why we weren't offered the special price. No matter, I will still be back, as it is in the neighborhood and very convenient on the way to work...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Their drip-coffee is not good and it they serve it in this crappy styrofoam cup.  Let the tourist have it, I'll take a cup or pound of Cafe Roma's caffeine over Trieste any day.  I had one espresso drink there, which was an Americano.  Once again, served in a crappy cup and tasting a little burnt.
author: Jeremy P.

description: Said to be the first espresso house on the west coast. This is the oldest one out of 5. Great atmosphere, amazing espresso, just a great place all around.
author: Baris B.

description: I was only here long enough to have a cold drink and share a cookie, but I still enjoyed myself!  I really loved the ambiance.  The crowd was chatty-yet-quiet overall, but was made up of a diverse blend of people.  My kind of place.  :)
author: Heather T.

description: The baked goods are only so-so, but the cioccolata fantasia (I'm sure I screwed up the spelling; my translation is "beyond epic hot chocolate") and the fact that this place is a North Beach institution make Trieste worth a visit.
author: Heather M.

description: When I just want coffee to-go from somewhere in the neighborhood, this is the place.  Not my kind of place to to sit for coffee though.  The regulars here seem to be aware of you but not in a pleasant, inviting way.
author: kenny k.

description: Great coffee house. They'll let you hang out all day - plus it's a fantastic people watching place...
author: Elizabeth D.

description: Don't know what Justin's talking about, I had great service. If you've never had their SNOWBALL, I highly recommend it. Actually, they said it's only available in the winter months. Someone else told me about it but I wasn't too enthused by the description. The taste changed my mind and I ended up eating more than my share (lol, back to salads I go). This is such a cute hangout, except for the lack of street parking (garage nearby on Vallejo, with tight spaces). Not to be missed if you just moved here, or go on a walking tour of SF.
author: Sabi M.

description: "Go for the scene---hippie Jack-Kerouac type hangout. Interesting. Rather rude service"
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Really the only thing I like about this place is the hot milk toddy. There's nothing better than a frothy almond flavored milk mustache.
author: C. Z.

description: I love to go to this cafe and drink delicious Egg Creams and smell the writer's block in the air. Orgasmic caramel cheesecake, try it and you'll thank me.
author: Colleen B.

description: A coffee shop with booze. That's right you heard me a coffee shop with booze. Ingenious. Ordered the double Irish creme espresso, thinking I was going to get a double shot of espresso with some wonderful thick irish cream (of the dairy variety not alcohol) and was pleasantly surprised. So if you like your coffee on the strong side, if you know what I mean, go here and skip Starbucks or another chain.
author: Rob H.

description: This cafe is one of the (thank goodness!) many places in SF I can retreat to when I want to feel like a step back in time. The cofee is flavorful and smooth, and if you don't watch out has the effect of rocket fuel. The whole Italian- Bohemian thing is right up my alley! The sweet munchies offered are ok. It is the froccasia sandwiches that make a meal. Oh... and they have live opera every other saturday. Yup, great place.
author: Charise B.

description: Okay, I love any place with the word Cafe in it.  Cafe Claude, Cafe Bastille, Cafe De Nord, The Buena Vista Cafe, Grand Cafe-- shall I go on?
author: Princess P.

description: I really like Trieste. Good cheap wine and a juke box with beautiful oldies. Oh, and the coffee ain't bad either..
author: Malika K.

description: Next time I am in San Fransisco I will definitely be heading over to North Beach and Caffe Trieste for a glas  of wine in the afternoon.  Charming atmosphere, literary history, great people watching , and baristas who honor their profession, all make this place exceptional.
author: Minnie M.

description: You can almost feel the artistic energy in this place. I sometimes think Ferlinghetti will walk in at any moment (is he still around?). The best java in the city, and the most eclectic coffee house crowd. If you're an early riser, you may catch the Dolphin club members getting their morning fix.
author: Arlene C.

description: caffe trieste is a taste of the old country right here in the city. the coffee is good, the pastries pricey but good BUT the real reasons to go are the people and the music. mandolin players, accordian players, opera singers and even the staff is great; friendly, efficient and in good humor. you can sit and read and people watch through the large windows. i love this place.
author: John G.

description: A hip and cozy cafe.  I had the best time sipping on chai outside and watching the world go by.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Whenever I'm in North Beach I love stopping by this place. It's old, It's dark, but that's why I like it. Oh, and their coffee is good too...
author: Richard T.

description: A classic North Beach cafe with a lot of character.  Good espresso--overroasty beans to my tastes but still good. Tends to get loud and crowded.  One of those places that make the bay area special.
author: Anonymous P.

description: What can I say! I love my cafes! This place has a given me some great memories......I've been going to this place since I was a baby in my mama's arms. It's a great place overall!
author: Jennifer C.

description: You almost feel like you are taking a step back in time by going to this spot.  They make a killer cup of every variation of regular espresso drinks.  Their stuff is the kind that gives you the jitters.  I normally go with the Mocha with the slab of real whipped cream.  Ummm Gooood!
author: Jason A.

description:
oh c'mon! no one reviewd this place yet? 

this place is a n.beach staple. funky old atmo with killer old photos on the wall. often, esp weekends, there is italian music of some sort and inevetiably some old guy swings by to croon in the native tongue. 

great informal sidewalk scene fortunately protected most of the day from glaring sun. free wireless and solid drinks supllemented by golden boy pizza.  great way to pass some time, and meet some interesting n.beach people.
author: tommy p.

description: A North Beach classic, great Espresso and coffee shop with a lot of character. Almost always crowded though. Free wifi with purchase.
author: Ossama A.

description: Espresso was ok. Nice atmosphere, and looking at all the photos on the wall is fun. But the floor was kind of dirty and there were a few too many bugs flying around (at 10pm on Saturday) for my comfort. It was a good place to take my visiting friends for some San Francisco history, but I don't think I'll make it my regular coffee joint.
author: Whitney R.

description: From a coffee-centric perspective, the servings seem small for the price, though my drink is fine, insofar as I have an opinion on coffee. There're tiny flies just owning the air (nearly Holloween, mid-afternoon), though luckily they're mostly interested in people with food. There are more interesting people here than I've seen in any coffee shop so far. They seem comfortable, and friendly, and have made this place interesting.
author: Brian S.

description: Not only is the expresso as strong as Peet's, but it tastes better. . The area looks nice (and cleaner) in the day time.. though the seating inside is too small - minus one star. The mocha is too good. Hell, I'll drive through downtown and take 30 minutes to look for parking just to get a cup.
author: Fotos C.

description: Not that this place needs another great review, but here is mine. For a long time I would come here for a latte or two Sat. mornings after taking my dog to Crissy Field. Sadly my dog passed and I'm doing yoga instead of heading to the city. But there is just nothing like heading here for a morning coffe with the paper, chatting with locals. I was born in Oakland and lived in the city for year, but still always feel like some sort of tourist in SF. In a good way.
author: M F.

description: Classic spot for coffee in North Beach. The staff can be a little short with you, but to me, that's part of it's charm. Even if the line looks long, stick around; they move people through really quickly, and the coffee is definitely worth a bit of a wait.
author: Brianne K.

description: If you want a great cup of espresso, Caffe Trieste is the way to go!
author: Ryoko Y.

description:
the coffee is good.  the people... not so good.  old beatnik locals wander around, sometimes exchanging loud insults with other beatnik locals, and, occassionally, directing insults at non-beatnik locals.  it's irritating.  the internet is usually shaky, so I'd highly recommend trying to steal wifi in the park or something.  

I like the Idea of Caffee Trieste, but I prefer to avoid the reality.
author: Maggie D.

description: The five stars is mostly for its mocha decaf coffee. I would love this place if it weren't filled with tourists and in general, too many people, for my taste. I like to get my drink and slowly have it somewhere quieter. The mocha is IMHO one of the best!
author: G Z.

description: Some of the best coffee in the city on one of the best corners in San Francisco. Early cappucino, late wine, at any time of day this is what SF is all about.
author: Brandon R.

description: Had a cappuccino here yesterday afternoon after a long absence.  It was wonderful & perfect.  Trieste in the Beach was the very first coffee house I walked into during my very first visit to San Francisco back in the 80's, and indeed, it hasn't really changed since, and hope it never will.  As everyone knows, it is a particularly colorful square in the colorful quilt that is San Francisco culture, a coffee sanctuary or shrine to the city's past as well as an ongoing signpost to both it's present and its future.  Sure, it's expanded into several more spots in San Francisco as well as in Sausalito and wherever else.  There's only one original Trieste, and this is it.  Coffee strong and mind awakening, black & white pics all over one wall, a wall painting on the back wall, masaic table tops, windows to the ceiling looking out onto Grant & Vallejo.  I grow older, Trieste remains.  A melancholy joy.
author: Roland C.

description: Nice coffee, gives u a much different experience/feeling than Starbucks coffee shops. Has a jukebox with old italian songs for the fans of this. Sweets could have been better.
author: George P.

description: This is a true "classic" among Coffee Shops and definitely one of the best in the North Beach area.  Lots of tables to sit and stay for a while, enjoying company or to get some work done at.  Italian opera along with old classics domiate the house jukebox with people of all sorts add to the  ambiance.  They serve beer, topped off glasses of wine, along with their great coffee, which I highly recommend buying  and brewing at home from their store next door.
author: Brian T.

description: I lucked into this place when there was no line, so I was able to sit and savor my latte in peace.  It was perfect.  And all lattes since have been judged against it, and found wanting.
author: Christine B.

description: The caffe I judge all others against in every way, coming here since a teen in 80's. Its near impossible to surpass the espresso drinks ( I always order a Caffe Africano which is like a less milk cappuccino, no foam) let alone match them. In addition to fantastic espresso, they have a great people like Paul in the morning, who once they know you start making your drink when they see you. And the decor is just classic North Beach old school down to the phone booth with a sliding door/pictures of the Saturday (day) Opera of times past (don't go to that unless you like serious crowds of tourists). And of course to top it off its filled with the best mix of weirdos/writers/crazys/politicos/business  to make it interesting. If someone gives this place a bad review there is something wrong with them, seriously.
author: Brian Aaron J.

description: Had a great cappuccino here. The atmosphere is definitely funky.. maybe a bit too funky for a suburban boy like myself but in no way does it feel like it's trying to be something it's not. I'd come back but would probably get it to go.
author: Victor H.

description: Best coffee in town, hands down.  Has unique flavor that is untouched by any that I have ever had.  So what if some tourists like it?  It's an institution that should be visited by coffee lovers near and far.
author: Val U.

description: Caffe Trieste is my favorite place to order a cup of plain-old, black coffee. I buy their beans sometimes, but there's just something ridiculously good about their pour. I can't replicate it at home.
author: Mark M.

description: an original. just clean up the food in the display case. i am not sure if italians still own it. i see a lot of arabs working and hanging out there.
author: S. G.

description: My 9 yo son and I stopped in here after a long walk around North Beach.  We had Italian sodas and shared a square of pizza which was great!  We sat next to some older gentlemen who were obvious regulars and I kidded them about my need to get some 'beat atmosphere'--they told me about the beat museum.  Stuart drew an awesome pencil sketch of my son!  What a fun time we had.  They were out of tiramisu and canolli--but the cheesecake was good.  No false warmth from the counter staff--but hey this isn't Starbucks(thank god!)
author: Elizabeth K.
