description:
A great hang out spot! It's a relaxing little piece of North Beach that feels like authentic North Beach to me. Everyone kind of knows each other, is friendly, up for chatting...the place just oozes charm and character.

Stop in for a wonderful coffee and check out the scene. There are usually some hilarious characters true to this neighborhood. 

Trieste is a classic.
author: Nicole R.

description: I once read an interview with the owner of Trieste, and he said he reluctantly offered coffee drinks with milk only because so many people demanded them. I agree that the best form of good coffee is straight..... but, the capuccinos here are the best I have had anywhere. When in SF, I can't miss making a visit to here.
author: Michael K.

description:
i went here last night for the first time and i loved it. some friends and i had finished a great meal down the street and wanted a bit of coffee. when we entered we were greated by the sounds of soothing live jazz playing in the back of the cafe. i ordered a cappuccino and it had phenomenal foam. staff was very friendly and the whole place just had a good vibe. it was the perfect end to a great evening. 
tip: if there is live music playing they make you pay a flat fee for drinks, but you can order it to go for the regular price.
author: Lauren D.

description: i actually dated a guy who worked here a few years ago and they would always give me free coffee and pastries when i would stop by. yum! this is a very popular NB hang out, always crowded and apparently andy garcia likes to come here for his coffee when he's in town.
author: Michelle I.

description:
cute mosaic tables.
comfy booth benches.
great light.
outside tables.
free wireless for customers.
author: Kate R.

description: Simply put, I love this place.  Great coffee and pastries, interesting customers and Barista's and plenty of local flavor.  What more can you ask from a cafe?
author: TJ S.

description: Tourist trap! Overcrowded! Periodically flooded with the thunderous racket of fuzzy opera! Filled with crotchety old-timers of the "start a conversation with preoccupied girl sitting next to you that will most likely revolve around 'the good old days,' 'young people and their flaws,' 'how the world has changed for the worse' or 'when I fought in the war' and threatens to be halted only by the irritated flight of said preoccupied girl" variety! All of these are true of Caffe Trieste, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't go. The line can be long, the clientelle can alternate between infuriating and consolatory and it's often too deafening to get any work or reading done, but the service is quick and friendly, the coffee is of course of the highest quality and if it's sunny out and you can grab a seat outside you're set for hours. Wine by the glass is also astonishingly cheap and the tiramisu is delightful. If you're stuck on what to order I recommend the hazelnut latte. You might think that flavored coffee is for lightweights but this hardened coffee drinker swears by that latte (which might even be better iced).
author: Tory S.

description: This place is historic and serves consistently perfect espresso drinks.  One of the best places to get coffee on the West Coast.  I always go when I am in town.  Service is typical SF barista brisk but they are the best and they will give you exactly what you want.
author: Lou C.

description: oh you mean my office?? would not have made it through graduate school without this place. best espresso in the city. lots of regulars who are real characters (don't be scared, they're harmless) and a juke box with old italian hits, opera, and show tunes. they got beer and wine too.
author: Mimi C.

description: most people would take their visiting friends to the SF MoMA, a Giants game,  or Pier 69... or whatever its called....  but leave it to me to scout out a coffee shop as the highlight of a friends' tourist trip to SF.   this place reminds me of coffee shoppes "back east".   if for some (highly unlikely but possible) reason you were sitting in this cafe and didn't know what city you were in... i'd say you could be convinced you were here in north beach, SF, greenwich village, NYC, or maybe the north end of boston?  the coffee drinks are great, and the key lime pie was delicious and so i took a piece of blueberry cheesecake home for my boyfriend.  its a bonus that this place is located around the corner from city lights bookstore, great little restaurants, and of course the "adult" theatres.
author: lacy b.

description: good for afternoons after the lunch crowd or late mornings i suppose whenever it isn't fuxing packt like sardines in a crushed tin box whenever that is
author: X X.

description: coffee was completley burned, service sucks and the customers are very mean, never again
author: Santos C.

description: i dare you to go in and order a torani creme de menthe italian soda, then make it a fresh soda yourself with the coffee condiments. it was once and forever my thing. i love this place for all it was, is and will forever be...
author: Jennifer N.

description: i also have a love-hate relationship with this place. on one hand, the magnitude of history and how much this place means to a lot of people and to san francisco is huge. inside it just FEELS like "your own living room," a phrase some of the writers who live in the neighborhood say. but the wait can be excruciatingly long - last month i was trying to grab coffee for my director and i on my way to my internship with the 25 minutes i had to spare, and the lined moved two people - i had to ditch the effort. plus, since i started going a few years back, the barista staff has changed a lot and some simply don't get the "north beach" friendly attitude amongst locals (their own). but the coffee is undeniably worth the wait, and if you're lucky enough to get through the line and snag a seat outside on the sidewalk during the nice weather, you'll be greatly rewarded.
author: Jenz y.

description: In 1970 I occasionally went here, and it was considered one of the very best places to meet the many interesting characters of North Beach. And now that we're actually in the computer age, this seems the perfect opportunity to ask if anyone has seen Angela the redhead lately (her real name was Heather "Jefferies" or something like that). Angela had been to Italy, had a  favorite book  titled the Book of the Courtier, and held some interest in numerology. I also remember that she had a son and a friend by the name of Richard in 1970, who I met on a train. It would be fun to say hello again to Angela.
author: H. Michael B.

description: found this cute cafe to be very chill and not as touristy as the rest of the places in north beach, I got to relax and enjoy my latte which is pretty much the best thing ever.
author: Patricia R.

description: The coffee is good but not great. I love hot chocolate, just not here. Sorry I am not a regular does that mean i don't get talked to or helped the same?
author: Baker M.

description: Love this joint, love the coffee or africano, as this what i have and free wifi.  An africano is basically a double short late.  If you like a cup of coffee with a good kick then try one next time.
author: Administrative C.

description: This place is not for anyone who thinks humanity is anything  less than it really is. Yuppies beware, Europeans leave scared. This is the real North Beach deal. Papa Gianni and his family have kept it what it has always been- a place for artistic reality, coffee and wine spritzers. Sammy Ali-Baba, the creepy man who flirts with girls a third his age sits at the front table among his unspeakably beautiful paintings. Jack Hershman sits at a table surrounded by poets and artists of all ages and sings old lore songs or recites a Kerouac poem or one of his own. If it seems empty, be sure to check the Live Worms Gallery on Grant street a block away, it may very well be where everyone is, at a Fly-By-Night opening. This cafe is family, so don't go expecting anything else. RIP B.J. & Tony
author: Luis C.

description:
if you are down for cafe's this is
old school Europe in the house with just the right flavor
author: lee c.

description:
been living in the neighborhood for 10+ years and have been in here a few times each year, usually to meet people who like the history of the place, but i'm annoyed at how inconsiderate most of the staff is, particularly the darker-haired lady who's very abrupt and rude when taking orders. plus, the line takes forever to move and the pastries, focaccia, etc. all taste like they've been sitting in the glass window for a few days.
i can appreciate the historical aspect and the fun ambiance when the staff and friends are singing off-pitch cantatas on saturday afternoons, but i'd prefer to take my business elsewhere.
author: Disko D.

description: Great local cafe with nice strong espresso drinks, always an assortment of clients, free wireless internet and the occasional live music.  Check out the cartoon about ordering coffee while waiting in line...it's perfect.
author: Kathleen S.

description: i worked here for a year and let me tell you,it was alot of bad with a hint of good.lets start with the good. most of my co-workers were awesome,Walker,in particular.if youre still there,dude,you gotta get out! i got to meet alot of famous people.jennifer lopez,mike meyers, and jefferson starship.i know,very eclectic.i met people from all over the world and that was a benefit. i hated working sundays when the owner and his family would sing in italian.tourists and regulars thought it was awesome.i needed a xanax just to get through the day. the owner always thought we were all stealing from him.we werent,but in retrospect,we should have.they had a nice policy of giving employees an unpaid vacation when,upon their return,they would 'no longer be needed'. this happened to 3 people before me.it got to the point that people would be ready to quit before theyd take a vacation.just on case they didnt have a job when they came back. i actually asked them point blank if id have a job when i came back and they said YES!. and they lied.i think yolanda,the owners sister,was unhappy because she had just figured out i was gay and she was well known to be very homophobic. i think their coffee is pretty good but id never pay for coffee there,and the few times ive been there,ive gotten coffee for free. and i wouldnt eat any of their antipasta,theyve had quite a roach problem. faniiculi fannicula!
author: Jim M.

description: This Christmas 2008 was for sure a great one.  I spent the day with family and friends.  Christmas Day did have its kinks though. Early that morning my good friend insisted that we get coffee.  Trieste was the closet place that was open. I've been there before of course, being a San Francisco native I enjoy drinking coffee all over the city.  And "YES" I know that Caffe Trieste is a bit different, however,  for as weird as it is it has history.  My experience of Caffe Trieste wasn't to great though.  I could care less about what other people are doing when I'm drinking coffee, but this Christmas I guess some of its regular customers do care about what people like me are doing when they are drinking coffee.   I want even talk about the service"MY GOD" but there was this guy sittin' at  a table next to the door who was obviously annoyed by my presence.  He let me know where I stood was irritating him, because he was trying to read the paper.  I let him know I was reading the article on the wall.  He said it was just about a man catching a fish.  I informed him I was not reading that article and that I was actually reading the article  written in Italian about the most beautiful city in the world. He wasn't impressed that some city kid who went to public school was exploring another language. No, he let me know  by stating he was still annoyed. I was just waiting on my friend so we could leave that's why I was standing by the door.  What a jerk!  Oh did I forget about the crazy guy who stormed pass me walked out and then walked back in to express to me that  he doesn't like black folk.  When I say black folks, I hope you get the picture. That was even  before I was criticized about the space I was taking in the joint. He sure needed a joint or a chill pill.  WOW what the (bleep) is that all about.  Am I only accepted at Trieste if I look like a poor black guy? I guess i better thank Santa  for all the nice people he gave me the nice clothes for Christmas.
author: Al. B.
